query: Q: What are the most common chronic diseases? What effects do chronic diseases have for the society and the individual?\nA:
answer1:
The most common conditions affecting people today include heart disease, diabetes, cancer, stroke, and arthritis. Of these, heart disease, which affects about 300 million people worldwide, is the number one killer of both men and women. Diabetes mellitus, which affects about 30-40% of all Americans, accounts for 40% of deaths from heart attacks in young adults (18 to 29). And, more than 10% of American adults suffer from some form of arthritis. Stroke of any type also kills a substantial percentage of individuals annually (5%-10%) and has been estimated that the direct medical costs related to stroke may exceed $200 billion per year. Other common chronic conditions afflicting humans include osteoarthritis, kidney problems, and digestive disorders. \r


In summary, there are many causes of death which affect our daily lives every day, such as smoking, accidents, infections, or even poor diet. These types of deaths make up only a small portion of the total number of human deaths each year. However, they are important because they contribute significantly to increased rates of morbidity and mortality. \r


The major cause of death today is cardiovascular disease, which represents about 50% of deaths caused by infectious agents (such as pneumonia), drugs (especially narcotics), alcohol, suicide, accidents, and trauma. This list could be expanded to include other causes of death; however, the following will suffice. \r


[Top]

II. Causes of Death

1. Cardiovascular Disease Caused By Infectious Agents (Pneumonia and Tuberculosis). \r 2. Heart Attack Caused By Drugs or Alcohol \r 3. Brain Cancer Caused By Smoking \r 4. Lung Cancer Caused By Smoking \r 5. Diabetes Caused By Insulin Resistance \r 6. Cancer Caused By Radiation \r 7. Autoimmune Disorders Caused By Bacterial Growth \r 8. It is believed that these complications may contribute to an increased risk of early mortality in patients with CHD." [4] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=SCHIZOPHRENIA+and+chronic+diseases&order=H&qtype=abstract \r


This means that women who develop CHD during pregnancy have more than double the risk of dying as women without CHD during pregnancy.[5][6]


In the late 1970s researchers discovered that the hormone progesterone was involved in maintaining blood pressure and that it could be used by the body to control CHD. During the 1980s scientists began using this knowledge to treat pregnant women with CHD. Many doctors felt that they were doing something good because there was some data showing that the progestin had an effect on CHD, however, others felt that their methods were not based on scientific evidence.[7]


What we know about CHD and progesterone treatment has changed significantly since 1973 when Dr. James Yancey first showed that progesterone might help manage CHD. The latest research shows that progesterone does indeed affect blood pressure in people who suffer from hypertension. In fact, it seems that progesterone can lower blood pressure by up to 3/8ths! There are also numerous anecdotal reports of patients experiencing significant improvement in their condition after taking progesterone-containing pills. However, if your doctor recommends you take progesterone pills, make sure she knows what she's talking about; many medical doctors believe that progesterone should only be prescribed for those with a specific genetic mutation associated with high blood pressure, which is called HBP1. \Nourished people in developed countries tend to be healthier than those who lack sufficient food. In developing countries, however, malnutrition is a serious problem with high mortality rates among children under 5 years of age.\pH: 0-10.5\r

\Nourishment also affects how a person functions as he/she ages. A healthy person cannot survive without adequate nutrition, but old or ill people often suffer from symptoms of illness that could be caused by their own poor health. Poor nutrition also has an impact on mental ability and physical condition.\pH: 6.8-7.2\r

"\u201cThe causes of hunger, poverty, undernutrition and other nutritional deficiencies can vary greatly from country to country, region to region, and from one part of the world to another. To some extent, these problems may also reflect differences in the level of technology available to each nation. In this regard, there are many examples where countries which are less dependent upon agriculture (e.g., India, Iran) are able to improve their standards of living through technological innovations such as the use of irrigation and better seed varieties. And countries which have become more technologically advanced (e.g., China) have been able to increase levels of income for their citizens.\pH: 7.3-7.4\r

\u201cIn order for any nation to meet its basic needs, it must first eliminate extreme poverty. The development of agricultural technologies throughout the world is necessary because farmers need tools such as tractors, harvesters, fertilizers and pesticides to grow crops efficiently. However, it is not enough merely to provide farmers with the necessary equipment. Many farmers still rely heavily on local labor and on subsistence farming techniques that require little training. This is especially true in rural areas where families depend on traditional practices and few opportunities exist for learning new skills. Therefore, even if agricultural technology advances have improved yields and productivity, they will not overcome the economic difficulties faced by millions of farmers across the globe.\u2014\u2014 \r


"\u2015\r

To solve the issue of hunger, we must promote universal access to modern farming techniques, education and training. This requires government policies that support sustainable agricultural production systems based on good science rather than tradition, and ensure that all farmers receive equal access to affordable fertilizer and seeds. It also requires governments to establish free and accessible markets that enable private investment in agriculture and ensure fair trade conditions within these markets.

Chronic diseases include diabetes mellitus, hypertension, atherosclerosis, heart disease, stroke, cancer, arthritis, psoriasis, etc. The majority of these diseases affect the body adversely as they result in a slow decline of vitality and health and a loss of happiness. We must consider that our modern lifestyle has caused many people to become sick as a consequence of their poor diet and lack of exercise. Most people are still unaware of how much stress they put on themselves by using electronic devices or watching television programs all day long, as well as by not getting enough rest during their sleep. They often end up feeling tired even though they are not sick or injured. In addition, there is an epidemic of obesity among children and adolescents.

Most adults suffer from one or more chronic conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, hypertension, cardiovascular diseases (stroke), diabetes mellitus, osteoarthritis, cancer, etc. \ nA: How will our future look like? Will it be a better or worse place? Is it possible that the world's population will decrease at some point in time due to our increasing use of technology? Are we heading towards another ice age? What about climate change? If so, what can be done about it? How will technology impact society in general? Do you think the environment and food quality will continue to deteriorate over the next few decades? \nA: It's unlikely that human beings will survive the coming generations without significant changes being made in the way we live. One of the key aspects of this transformation will be the rapid improvement of medical care and prevention of environmental problems. This will depend upon the development of new drugs, vaccines, devices, techniques, etc., which will also require fundamental research in medicine. These developments should lead to major advances in longevity, the ability to reverse aging and greatly reduce the likelihood of suffering from various types of illnesses. The same technologies could save billions of lives through preventative measures which would allow us to extend life expectancy considerably beyond today's levels. In addition, advances in artificial intelligence will make possible the creation of living computers with unprecedented capabilities. Eventually, our descendants may develop super intelligent robots to assist them throughout their whole lifetime. However, the first generation robots may provide assistance only if our species decides to cooperate. For example, to overcome conflicts between humans and other animals or between nations we might create robot companions who don't kill when necessary, but instead act as ambassadors for peace and cooperation between peoples, countries or races, thus promoting peace among humanity as a whole. \
answer5:
The best known chronic diseases include coronary heart disease, stroke, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, cancer, asthma and many others. In recent times there has been a great deal of interest in finding ways to prevent or control these chronic illnesses. However, even though there is some evidence that preventive actions can be beneficial, it appears unlikely that they will have any long term effect on our population over the next century (1). CVD mortality rates continue to increase, particularly among middle aged people who are not yet at risk, although this trend is moderated by economic development and other factors (2), thus suggesting that we need to find a way of preventing premature death. Smoking remains one of the greatest contributors to cardiovascular disease, and smoking cessation is an important strategy for reducing mortality from all causes. There are also significant health benefits from consuming whole grains, vegetables and fruit, including lower incidence of colorectal cancer, stroke and dementia (3). This review examines the potential risks associated with chronic diseases and focuses especially on what these diseases mean for individual's well-being.\r

View PDF\r

\nThe most prevalent chronic disease in India is diabetes, followed by hypertension, cardiovascular diseases and cancer. In terms of income, high blood pressure causes more problems than any other chronic disease. It is important to know that chronic conditions can also affect productivity. For instance, chronic low back pain has been shown to be a drag on productivity and productivity losses related to the above-mentioned diseases.\r


Q: How much money does one need to save for retirement? What is your personal saving rate?\nA: Saving for retirement is not as easy as you might think. You should put aside 30% or so of your total salary every year in an Individual Pension Scheme (IPP) in order to have enough funds at hand to retire comfortably and enjoy life. An average middle-class Indian earns Rs 65,000 per month after tax; so a pension plan would mean that he/she will receive around Rs 18 lakh annually. This is just an example - this figure varies depending on how much you earn each month.\r


Q: Who contributes to Individual Public Provident Fund(IPPF)? Why do people contribute to it?\nA: IPPF was introduced when India had a GDP of Rs 3 trillion. While most Indians earn less than Rs 2 lakh per annum from their jobs, some earn nearly twice that amount. To help them make ends meet, the government decided to set up a system where citizens who earn under Rs 20,000 per annum could set up an Individual Public Service Plan (IPPPS), which means they would provide services like health care and education without having to pay extra fees. There are many such plans available across the country.\r


Q: Is there anything else I can do if my savings aren't sufficient?\nA: Most Indian employees only invest part of their earnings into a pension fund. So even if you start off with 10% saved, you may end up with less than 5%. The best thing you can do is take advantage of a financial advisor who is well trained in all things pertaining to IRAs. They can advise you about what assets to hold in your 401(k). If you want more advice, check out MoneySmart's Financial Advisor Directory.
answer7:
Chronic diseases account for more than one-third of deaths in India. The most common chronic disease is hypertension (high blood pressure), which affects nearly 25 million Indians, including about 16 million adults. The incidence rate of hypertension among children has declined from 3% to 2%, but in adults it has remained at 20%. Diabetes mellitus accounts for 1.2 million new cases each year and causes an estimated $16 billion loss annually. It also leads to a significant burden on healthcare system resources (HIV/AIDS alone costs Rs 21,000 crore every year). Other common chronic diseases include heart failure (1.8 million people); cancer (9.3 million); liver cirrhosis (7 million); stroke (6.5 million); Alzheimer's disease (4.5 million); pneumonia (2.2 million) and tuberculosis (2.1 million). The average life expectancy is 73 years, and half of all men will die before they reach 65 years. \r


Q: Why is India spending so much money on health care when its population is growing rapidly?\nA: In 2002, total public expenditure was 8.77% of the Gross Domestic Product. This is the highest proportion since 1979. The share of GDP devoted to health increased steadily between 1983 and 1992 while the overall increase in healthcare expenditure came mostly from increases in the private sector. However, since 2004, when the government assumed responsibility for universal primary health coverage, public expenditure has been falling behind the growth in the economy because of rising inflation. As a result, the percentage spent per capita has fallen from 9.3% in 2003 to 7.4% in 2009. Public funding continues to be inadequate, with only 27.5% of Indians having access to quality services such as free medicines and diagnostic tests. Although government schemes cover some basic services, there remain wide disparities between states with little coherence or efficiency. Private providers provide less than 10% of primary health care; however, many low-income patients do not know that this is possible. A lack of awareness about available options limits cost effectiveness, particularly for those who cannot afford long-term medical treatment. Some believe that underfunding of health insurance makes it difficult for poorer families to secure comprehensive health protection against disease. Most poor households are not covered by any health insurance policy, although state governments guarantee them subsidies for their elderly and disabled family members (see http://www.mfa.gov.in/healthcarecost/index_t06.htm ). answer8:
The most prevalent causes of death in China include cardiovascular disease, respiratory disorders (such as tuberculosis), stroke, diabetes mellitus, infectious diseases (including HIV/AIDS) and cerebrovascular disease. Chronic diseases account for 25 percent to 30 percent of deaths every year in China. According to the National Health and Family Planning Commission, nearly 300 million people across the country suffer from some form of chronic disease at any given time. The majority of these patients are under-aged or elderly and do not receive adequate medical treatment. In addition, there is a great demand for primary care professionals such as doctors and nurses due to the aging population. \nB: This is the first installment of a two-part series exploring the future of China's healthcare system. Part 2 can be found here \u003cbr\u003ePart 1 can be viewed on the Chinese version of this website. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

1. What does the term'social insurance' mean? Social security is an insurance program for social welfare purposes that was established by the government as early as the Qing dynasty (1644-1911). It has been implemented since then under different names like civil service pension scheme, military service pension, agricultural workers benefit, public employees benefits, disaster relief plan, etc. A national health insurance scheme that covers all citizens aged 18 years and older, including individuals with disabilities; provides treatment for non-economic ailments which includes but is not limited to mental illness, cancer, heart attack, stroke, paralysis and other serious illnesses, and pays medical bills; and provide financial assistance to people who need it, such as old age assistance, maternity leave, unemployment compensation, education subsidy, disability allowance, family planning funds, and so forth, has been implemented through various programs over the past decades. These programs have resulted in rapid economic growth. They have also contributed significantly towards improving social harmony, and have helped improve China's standard of living and quality of life. In recent years, though, many citizens have complained about excessive expenses and lack of adequate services provided by social welfare agencies. As a result of these complaints, the government introduced a number of measures aimed at ensuring universal coverage. Some examples of these measures are the expansion of coverage, strengthening of the basic coverage structure, setting up of new insurance products and restructuring of existing ones. Also, a reform of the administrative personnel within these departments has recently taken place, creating opportunities to recruit talented personnel and ensure improved efficiency in handling operations. Chronic diseases such as diabetes, cardiovascular disease, asthma, stroke etc. all lead to a loss of life due to complications and disability caused by them and can cause premature death due to various medical problems.

The World Health Organization (WHO) has classified chronic diseases into four broad categories, based on their impact on health-related quality of life or overall health status, with "high" risk of serious morbidity or mortality, "low risk", "medium risk" and "low risk". These categories reflect the prevalence of health conditions that significantly affect people's physical and mental well being and therefore contribute to their welfare in terms of economic productivity. The WHO classifies chronic diseases according to several factors, including underlying causes, genetic susceptibility, etiology, incidence patterns, prognosis, treatment strategies, cost effectiveness, public health impact, and global burden of disease estimates.


CVD (chronic heart disease): There were 6.5 million deaths from CVD globally in 2012 and this number is projected to rise sharply by 2030, with an estimated 1.2 billion people at high risk of suffering from CVD in 2050. By the year 2100, there will be 10.6% more people living with CVD than today in low income countries alone. Heart attacks are the main type of CVD causing approximately half of all deaths worldwide, while strokes account for another one third, and pulmonary embolism accounts for two thirds. A combination of factors contributes to CVD in developing nations, such as poverty, lack of access to healthcare and poor diet, and its highest rates occur in Asia, Africa and Latin America. This is particularly important when considering that the world population is growing faster than the average rate of increase of these regions and some populations could face a doubling of their age cohorts within decades. As a result of increased longevity, it is predicted that the burden from CVD will continue to grow over time.

Chronic liver disease: In 2010, the number of deaths from acute hepatitis B was estimated to reach 843 000 globally, accounting for 11% of total deaths due to infectious diseases. Although there is no specific estimate available for acute hepatitis C, around 20 000 new cases occur each year. It is estimated that one person dies every nine minutes from cirrhosis or related liver disorders in developing countries â€“ nearly three times the amount of deaths per person that would occur if only 10% of those who die from cancer had liver disease. These diseases also pose a huge financial burden, especially because they can require complex treatment and long hospital stays
answer10:
Chronic diseases are those that occur with long-term or continuous existence. The body is able to heal itself, but it is unable to stay in good condition at all times and will eventually break down completely. This is a result of our genetics which dictates how much we can take from the environment when given enough time. We are also affected by other factors such as environmental toxins, stress, and overwork, and these often lead to some form of chronic disease in which a person's genes dictate their physical condition and susceptibility to disease.

Q: How does chronic pain affect your life?\nA: Pain is an inevitable part of life. However, it is not necessarily bad if you manage it properly and learn the skills required to avoid it entirely. Some people, however, get caught up in pain and become addicted to it which can cause them to neglect their work or their relationships. For example, many people suffer from insomnia because they wake up constantly in excruciating pain. Others may be plagued by poor eating habits due to frequent stomach aches; some people find themselves spending hours every day driving around in circles looking for parking spaces! In addition, chronic pain affects both mental health and physical health. It causes people suffering from depression to feel worthless and hopeless, leading to suicide attempts. In contrast, healthy individuals rarely experience this level of emotional distress (i.e., sadness). Therefore, there are some ways that one can prevent chronic pain by managing one's diet, exercise, and sleep habits so that one doesn't run into it in the first place.

Q: Why should I care about my health?\nA: Everyone has a basic human right to live without experiencing any type of harm or discomfort. Even the slightest bit of damage to the body will greatly diminish the quality of life a person has experienced thus far. That being said, everyone's needs differ slightly so knowing the difference between what is necessary and unnecessary is crucial in helping one determine if he/she truly wants to go through with a certain task. The following questions and answers will help you determine if you need to undertake a particular activity and what your options would be if you decide to make it happen.

1. Does it benefit me personally? \nA: Without question, yes. If you're going to die soon, then doing something helps to ease the impending doom. For those who have never used one, the app is a lot like using an iPhone â€” you've got your home screen, with all your favorite apps and their icons; the left side of the screen has quick access to the settings; and on the right side is the main menu (with a handy search function). You can swipe from any icon in that menu to open it up for more information or look around a bit before hitting the back button. If you're looking at the top of the main menu, you'll see options to add new accounts, sign into an account, get support, download the latest version of the app, and even change the wallpaper. To help make it easier to find these things, each option includes a shortcut to the page of related info. For example, when you tap "add" on the bottom left of the main menu, you'll immediately be taken to Account Settings if there's one available â€” otherwise, just go straight to Add Account. The app also lets you import accounts into the OneNote app so you won't need to sync your devices again.

The rest of the app looks very much like other OneNote users expect it to look; everything is organized and accessible via swipes down from the top of the screen and upward toward the bottom. There are several categories, including your notebooks, notes, calendar items, reminders, images, audio files, videos, photos, voice memos, text messages, and documents. In addition, each category has its own sub-categories that let you sort your content by date added/deleted/viewed/read.

There's no clear way to filter through these categories, but I'm happy with what I found; a few times, a note would show up as a reminder for something else I was working on but I didn't want to bother going back to it to pick up where I'd left off; this wasn't really an issue, though, because the categories themselves weren't particularly cluttered.

To create new notebooks, you simply drag a photo from your Camera Roll onto the blank space below the name. Notebooks created in OneNote aren't automatically saved across devices, nor are they stored locally on the device itself. Instead, once you save them in OneNote, they remain synchronized between your devices until you delete them â€” which means there's only ever one notebook per device. But then, you don't necessarily always have to keep separate copies of your notebooks and OneNote syncing saves them

2) "The Daily Activity App," by Mark Williams, is the only app with a health section. It's designed to help you stay motivated through your day. The app helps you track and quantify how much sleep you get each night (if you don't get enough, you can use it as an alarm clock!), which helps you adjust your sleeping patterns to suit your needs. If you have trouble falling asleep or staying asleep, this may be something you'd like to keep in mind. You can also set goals for when you want to go to bed so that you won't be too late. And if you're getting up early on a weekday morning, you'll find that you wake up earlier and more rested! I especially love the fact that you can set different activities for specific days of the week. For instance, I will try to do some walking and running during my lunch break when the gym isn't open but I'm not exercising at all. This way I can still eat healthy and get protein from foods I enjoy without being punished. I guess I could also include a workout routine too but then I wouldn't need to worry about the calories and calories out (which is quite important!).

I used the app the first time I started tracking my physical activity. Now I can't imagine my life without it. I see myself using it every day (except weekends), except when I'm doing chores around the house. ðŸ™‚

Answer: You are very unlikely to develop diabetes. The reason is due to an enzyme called glucokinase in your pancreas which breaks down dietary carbohydrates and converts them into glucose in the bloodstream so as to provide energy for your body. If this enzyme was missing or damaged it could lead to high blood sugar levels which can be dangerous. However, there are many other factors which can also contribute to diabetes such as obesity and a poor diet. It's important to keep up with your daily exercise routine and have good eating habits, not only do they help to control your weight and cholesterol levels but will also reduce the chances of developing diabetes. (4/20)

Q: I feel sluggish all day long, what should I eat? A: Your metabolism is slowing down and thus your hunger level rises. This is due to how many calories you consume each day, your body is still working hard to burn off those calories. Eating more will only make you hungrier and less likely to lose any weight because now your body has fewer resources left to work with. There may also be some chemical imbalances occurring inside your body because these changes affect hormones like leptin and ghrelin which determine how much food you need to take in in order to feel full. As well, you may find that when you eat fatty foods you feel hungry sooner than when you eat starchy foods, so you might want to cut back on your intake of fats and sugars (such as white bread). (5/20)

Q: My belly feels bloated after meals and I don't know why? A: If your stomach doesn't empty properly then your intestines will continue to function normally but your bowels won't. When your bowels aren't functioning normally then they become blocked and this blockage causes a feeling of fullness. When your gut is blocked the body tries to remove waste products from your system by passing urine through your skin. If you experience this sensation then you've got to let your bowels out regularly - even just once every four hours is better than letting them sit and cause discomfort. Many people have discovered that their tummy gets flatter if they wait until they're finished eating before flushing the toilet. Make sure you flush your bowels at least every couple of minutes while you're eating, as otherwise your bowels may stay blocked longer which will increase your chance of having bowel problems later.

Dietary fiber is an important component of a healthy diet. The American Diabetes Association recommends that individuals consume at least 10-15 grams of dietary fiber per day, which can be obtained in many different ways, including from fruits and vegetables. Fiber plays many roles in the body, such as helping to maintain bowel regularity, preventing constipation, providing energy to support strong bones, supporting proper blood sugar levels, and helping with weight management and maintaining a stable weight (1). In addition to serving as a source of fiber, fruits and vegetables are also rich sources of vitamins, minerals, antioxidants, phytochemicals, and other nutrients. Fruits and vegetables contain numerous bioactive compounds, most notably lycopene, Î²-carotene, vitamin C, zinc, folate, lutein, zeaxanthin, anthocyanins, flavonoids, and polyphenols (2). A study published in 2009 found that eating a diet high in whole grains, fruits, and vegetables significantly reduced the risk of developing diabetes by 27% compared to people who ate a low-fiber diet (3). Whole grains are a complete food consisting of complex carbohydrates that are easily digested and absorbed (4) and include wheat bran, oat groats, barley flour, rye flour, cornmeal, oats, amaranth seed kernels, millet, sorghum, peanuts, pumpkin seeds, and sesame seeds. Fruit juices have no calories and provide many of the same beneficial effects as whole fruit. However, they may vary slightly from one variety to another because some varieties are naturally sweetened and others are not. Foods like apples, pears, oranges, bananas, grapes, blueberries, peaches, plums, and papaya are all excellent choices for reducing your risk of becoming diabetic if you limit yourself to two servings a week (5). There is limited evidence on whether or not consuming more than four servings a day of fruits and vegetables reduces the risk of developing type 2 diabetes. Researchers did find, however, that a higher intake of fruits and vegetables was associated with lower fasting glucose concentrations in overweight women (6), but further research is needed before we can say that this provides any additional health benefits. For example, these findings do not prove that each serving of fruit or vegetable is better for reducing insulin resistance than any other portion size. It would take several years of well-designed studies to determine how much fruit and vegetables help reduce diabetes risk (7). Bottom Line:

What is the role of omega-3 fatty acids in obesity?

Omega-3s are found primarily in fish, so a diet that excludes fish and includes animal foods can be an effective way to reduce the level of omega-3 fat consumption in the body. This may help prevent or delay the onset of metabolic syndrome and other diseases associated with the development of chronic inflammation, such as atherosclerosis (hardening of the arteries).


Dietary supplements containing alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) have also been shown in some studies to lower triglyceride levels in both healthy individuals and those who had recently developed heart disease. ALA has also been shown to lower blood pressure. A supplement containing 800 mg of ALA each day was studied in overweight women after they were advised to avoid animal foods. The dietary intervention resulted in significant weight loss but did not affect fasting blood sugar levels. After one year, HDL cholesterol increased by 3% and LDL cholesterol decreased by 5%. However, no change occurred in triglycerides, which remained unchanged in these women. At the conclusion of this study, it was concluded that omega-3 fatty acids could be considered to protect against cardiovascular disease when combined with a low carbohydrate diet. These findings support further investigation into the potential benefits of ALA supplementation.


References:


1) Murgatroyd D et al. Omega-3 Fatty Acids in Atherosclerotic Heart Disease Prevention: A Randomized Controlled Trial, Circulation. 2010 Feb 20;122(10):1479-94.

Diabetes mellitus (DM) is a chronic disease characterized by insulin resistance and associated with morbidity, mortality, and reduced quality of life. The prevalence of DM has increased substantially worldwide over recent decades; it now affects about 1 in 5 adults, with more than 150 million people living with this condition.1-3 In many countries, the prevalence of DM has reached epidemic proportions, resulting in an estimated 3.6 billion cases annually, or 1 in 8 persons worldwide.4 To date, there is no consensus on how best to manage DM.2 However, these issues are not new. Several decades ago, physicians recognized that, when treating patients with certain types of DM, they should avoid treatment if their blood glucose levels were too low for diabetic control or if the patient was unable to monitor his/her own blood glucose level accurately.5,6 However, in those situations where patients were able to take their blood glucose level with them, there was still a need for management strategies to maintain appropriate glucose control.7 More recently, more research has focused on understanding the factors that predispose individuals to develop diabetes, including genetic susceptibility8-10 and environmental influences such as diet11-15 and lifestyle choices such as obesity16-18. Because so many factors contribute to the development of DM, effective management of DM requires multiple approaches. The aim of this editorial is to provide current information about the relationship between diabetes, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and cardiovascular disease (CVD). We also address questions surrounding the potential benefits of weight loss interventions for DM and CVD prevention.

Type II Diabetes Mellitus Type II DM is defined according to the International Diabetes Federation (IDF)/World Health Organization criteria as one which occurs due to either noninsulin dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM), acquired pre-diabetes (APD), or both NIDDM and APD.19 A diagnosis of diabetes can be confirmed by HbA 1c,20 fasting plasma glucose,21-23 or use of insulin or oral hypoglycemic agents.24 Some researchers have suggested that only 1% of NIDDM is associated with impaired glucose tolerance (IGT), while up to 15% of NIDDM is related to hyperglycemia; 25 however, other investigators have questioned whether these differences would result in meaningful differences in outcomes between NIDDM and APD.26-28 Despite debate regarding the clinical significance of NIDDM, its etiology remains the same across all major

I think it's fair to say that these questions are a bit more complex than they appear at first glance. The answer you get from your doctor is likely going to depend on your age and whether or not you have a family history of the disease. For example, if you have any other kind of diabetes (e.g., gestational diabetes) then your response will be different, as will yours for anyone else in your family. If you're over 65, it's likely that you'll have fewer problems with high blood sugar and less risk of complications such as heart attacks and strokes. That said, even people who are genetically predisposed to diabetes may still develop this condition in their later years, and some people can become diabetic without ever having had symptoms. It just means there are many variables involved in determining a person's risk.

So how do you know what your risk is? Here's how I've done it so far. In October 2006, I was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes and became very aware of all the potential pitfalls, including those outlined above. To help me make sense of my situation, I consulted two of the best scientists in the world â€“ Drs. Michael Graedon (NHS Blood Pressure Clinic) and Peter Reuter (University College London Diabetes Centre), both highly qualified experts in the field. At their urging, I went through a complete medical screening process and found out which medications I'd been taking and whether I was currently exercising regularly, eating healthily and maintaining a healthy weight. When I checked off each item, I felt reassured about the possibility that I could manage my disease. And yet, just days before Christmas last year, when my blood sugars were higher than normal after consuming an apple-filled lunch, I decided I didn't want to continue being a slave to them. So I changed my diet, exercised more often, got rid of most carbohydrates and switched to a low-glycaemic index food plan. And since then, things have improved dramatically!

The first thing I did was check my blood glucose levels. They were already starting to go up after breakfast but were dropping again by midafternoon, around 5pm. At 6pm, they jumped back up towards the normal range. My initial fear was that my low-glucose diets were causing me to enter ketosis, where your body becomes adapted to burning fat instead of carbs. But this wasn't happening.

The study was a cross-sectional design, with participants being recruited from the community. The participants were not randomised to receive either intervention or control treatments; instead, they received an education package and a standard healthcare screening questionnaire before baseline (the first observation of which was in 2004). Participants who did not return for follow up were excluded from analysis. Data collection took place at both the baseline and post-baseline stages of the study.

We used the self-reported height and weight as described previously. 17, 18 Briefly, we asked each participant whether they had ever been told their height or weight was below normal or above average, and asked them if they knew someone else who felt this way. We also asked the age-and gender-matched comparison group how often they were aware that their own BMI was underweight (0%), overweight (1%) or obese (2%). When the answer was yes, we compared body mass index values between these groups using linear regression analysis. This enabled us to assess the relationship between BMI (in kg/m 2 ) and other measured characteristics across the entire range of BMI (<18.5), over three categories of obesity (>25% BF) and â‰¥30%. Weight was also measured at baseline, with a calibrated scale; BMI was calculated using the following formula: weight in kilograms divided by the square of height in meters. Height was measured in centimeters. BMI is the most commonly used measure of adiposity globally. 18

To investigate the potential impact of different interventions on physical activity, we analysed all data including those collected at the two pre-treatment visits (2004â€“2005 and 2006â€“2007). To provide evidence about the impact of our interventions on dietary behaviours and nutrient intakes, we assessed total energy intake and macronutrient composition from both the clinic and home scales during the same two periods (2006â€“2007 and 2010â€“2011). At baseline, participants were instructed to complete a short online survey on food and exercise habits. This questionaire included questions on usual diet, consumption of specific foods, time spent at rest, activities undertaken while travelling, and the level of physical exertion required to undertake particular activities.

At baseline, participants completed a detailed medical history form and underwent comprehensive blood measurements. After a 24 h fast, they returned for follow-up examination after 3 months. At this visit, participants provided informed written consent to participate in the clinical trial. Participants who refused to take part were invited to return within 6 weeks. query: Q: Is a ketogenic / keto diet suitable for people with diabetes?\nA:
answer1:
Yes. A ketogenic diet is the recommended way to manage Type 1 diabetes in adults and children with insulin-dependent type 2 diabetes, but it can be used by anyone who has diabetes regardless of their glucose level or insulin requirement. It is also safe for those with diabetic kidney disease.

Ketosis: What Is The Benefit Of Ketones For Diabetes? Ketone bodies are produced during fasting (or if you're eating low carb) as your body breaks down fat stores so that more energy can enter your cells and muscles. Since there's not much sugar circulating in our blood at this time, we use up some glucose reserves as fuel. Once all of the glucose has been metabolized, however, we need to get rid of any excess glycogen (stored carbohydrate) because there isn't enough available to power us through our day. However, since the liver will try to store any glucose you have stored, we don't want to burn off too many calories. By burning fat instead, we'll release ketones into our bloodstream which, according to the National Institutes of Health's "Diabetes Prevention Program" report, "will boost energy levels, help control weight gain, and reduce inflammation." In fact, Dr. John McDougall recommends using an oral glucose tolerance test after four weeks of using ketosis in his book "The China Study," which showed that the improved health and decreased risk of heart disease were the result of the ketones and not the reduction of carbohydrates. You may hear claims that ketones cause headaches and nausea in diabetics; however, studies show that these symptoms disappear once they've gone away on their own. When ketones are elevated in the blood, there are two primary ways in which they contribute to improving one's health: Reducing insulin sensitivity â€“ As discussed above, increasing ketones helps increase insulin sensitivity and therefore reduces blood glucose levels. Therefore, reducing or eliminating sugars from our diets could potentially lower our chances of developing high blood pressure, type II diabetes, stroke, heart attack, kidney failure, cancer, arthritis, fibromyalgia, arthritis pain, muscle cramps, joint stiffness, sleep disorders, brain fog, memory loss, lack of concentration, and mood swings.

I've been following this diet now for over two years and I'm still at my weight of 195 pounds (in August 2011). I did a test in early November that showed that I am getting about 12-13 grams/day of carbs from all sources â€“ not including my morning coffee and breakfast burrito. The last time I measured my blood glucose was 3 weeks ago â€“ and since then, I haven't had any problems. In fact, since eating less, I got about 20% better.

You can read a lot more about the benefits of this diet here. Please note, however, that this blog post has been updated for accuracy and clarity and this article is no longer being updated so please see the above link for current information.

\nIt is important to note that the exact definition of "diabetic" varies from one person to another. There are many ways to measure blood sugar and it can also vary by how long you have had diabetes, your current medication status or the type of diabetes treatment you are taking. If you think there may be some problems with a ketogenic / keto diet, speak to your doctor about your options. A good resource for more information on this subject is www.askthenutritionist.com/diet-and-nutrition/diabetes/.

What should I watch out for during a ketogenic / keto diet?

The key point here is not to worry too much if you experience any side effects, even those that don't last very long. It's best to see an experienced dietitian (or physician) before making any changes in your diet. Side effects such as headaches and fatigue are common when low carbohydrate diets are changed, but usually subside within 2 months and are not considered dangerous. For many people, these issues do not appear until the end of the first month and they tend to resolve themselves without intervention. Some people find that their hair becomes thinner. This is due to the increased amount of water that is lost during a fast. As well, it's possible to develop other health conditions as a result of a low carb or keto lifestyle, so always consult your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

In addition to these short term health concerns, there are also longer-term consequences to the high fat diet you are following. Your brain will continue to use up glucose from fatty tissues until you're able to burn protein sparingly. In time, your brain cells may start to shrink. Eventually, though, you'll get used to it â€“ and the weight loss will stop!

First, this lifestyle must be followed by a diabetic control program. Second, these diets can cause severe weight loss and changes in blood glucose levels. Third, it should be noted that these diets do not work well if one does not have enough carbohydrates or protein, which are required by the body. Yes. The dietary plan proposed by Dr. Atkins and adopted by many athletes is good for people with diabetes because it provides adequate amounts of essential fatty acids, protein and carbohydrates to provide an energy source that doesn't result in excess weight gain or high blood glucose levels. It also eliminates the need for insulin injections and/or diabetic medications. For those who have difficulty keeping the diet low enough to allow sufficient calories from fat, a diet higher in carbohydrate (about 40-45%) may be more appropriate. This allows greater body fat storage and allows for a slower rate of fat loss than if all calories were from fats and proteins. However, ketosis can be achieved on a low carb diet even when the person does not use any medication. A very healthy adult should aim for a carbohydrate intake of no more than 20% of daily calorie needs; however, a few weeks before starting the diet, the amount should be reduced so as not to put undue stress on the kidneys.

Ketosis

Ketones are produced during starvation and the rapid oxidation of fat. They are used by the brain to metabolize carbs, which leads to feelings of satiety, but they become toxic at high levels, resulting in symptoms such as headaches, vomiting, diarrhea, fatigue, cramping, anxiety, irritability and depression. Ketone bodies in the urine can indicate an infection, especially in infants and children and in cases of cancer treatment. Some studies show that chronic ketosis results in increased brain metabolism in nonobese patients.

Breathing Rate

The breathing rate is affected by several factors including the air volume, the temperature, heart rate, muscular tension, airway resistance and the presence of obstructive lung disease or pneumonia. The higher the oxygen content of the air, the faster the heart beats (oxygen consumption). Oxygen is needed for the respiratory system to function properly and is critical for healthy cardiovascular functions. If the oxygen supply is compromised, the body's metabolism slows down, leading to exhaustion and lethargy. Higher breaths per minute increase the risk of dying from hypoxia. Breathe slowly and deeply into your diaphragm for three breaths, then hold them for ten seconds. Repeat this every five minutes for one hour until you feel better.

In case you find yourself getting exhausted while using this method, try breathing through both nostrils while standing up. In this way, you will maintain a constant flow of oxygen throughout your lungs.

answer6:

When we look at the history of diabetics, it's clear that they have been eating some kind of carbohydrate-based food to manage their blood sugar levels (even if it was just sugar). For instance, during World War II, diabetics were encouraged by physicians to eat whole grains and legumes and avoid carbohydrates in general. In fact, as late as the 1970s when a major study showed that low carb diets worked better than high carbs (and also showed that most diabetic patients don't respond well to either type of diet), doctors still recommended them. And since then, it has become more common to recommend low carb over the past several decades.

However, research shows that even on these very restrictive diets, many diabetics will eventually develop type 2 diabetes. This is because, although insulin sensitivity improves significantly on lower carb or no carb diets, once you go below 60 grams per day of carbohydrates, your cells actually begin to use glucose to create energy instead of fat â€“ leading to hyperglycemia. Since type 2 diabetes occurs when glucose can't be used for fuel, this means the body needs an additional source of glucose to keep itself functioning properly. This extra glucose comes from the foods we ate before we started our carb restriction! When we restrict carbs, this extra glucose is stored in adipose tissue (fat) and liver where it creates fat storage. This results in a vicious cycle, making it difficult for people to lose weight while reducing their risk for developing type 2 diabetes. So how do we reverse this process?

In recent years there has been a huge rise in interest in using intermittent fasting to reverse type 2 diabetes. Many experts believe that intermittent fasting is not only safe but may actually help reduce or eliminate diabetes altogether! One of the biggest problems associated with Type 2 Diabetes is oxidative stress. The key point here is that insulin resistance causes oxidative stress and insulin promotes antioxidant defense against free radicals. Therefore, when we get into a metabolic state where antioxidants are lowered due to insulin resistance, we are less able to fight off free radicals which leads us to build up excessive amounts of oxidative damage to our tissues. Even though dietary carbs typically promote healthy lipid profiles and cholesterol, they also increase free radical production so this could potentially lead to increased triglycerides, LDL and HDL particles.

By removing carbohydrates for longer periods of time (e.g., 24 hours) we can turn down inflammation while simultaneously boosting antioxidants to prevent further damage. As long as we're keeping protein intake moderate (~45 g/
answer7:
A ketogenic or low carb diet is generally considered to be appropriate in the treatment of diabetic ketoacidosis and certain other conditions. In general, this type of diet involves eating less than 50% of your calories from carbohydrates. If you have type 1 diabetes or prediabetes then you may find that some ketogenic diets are not suitable because the high levels of insulin can cause blood sugar levels to drop too quickly (hyperglycemia). Because of this, it's important to follow a strict diet. Some experts recommend a 20-30% carbohydrate deficit (with more if you have pre-diabetes) although it must be noted that most people who follow this diet do so on a very low calorie intake â€“ around 1500 kcal per day is typical.

What's The Bottom Line On Keto Diets For Type 1 Diabetics?

It seems like I've only covered one side of this story here! If anyone has any questions about whether or not an alternate form of food is better suited for their diabetes symptoms then please leave a comment below. As always, let me know what you think!
answer8:
Yes, it is. The ketogenic / keto diet is an effective way of controlling blood glucose levels in individuals with type 2 diabetes. Although the exact mechanism behind this effect isn't well understood, research suggests that it has to do with insulin resistance and increased lipolysis, which leads to decreased production of fatty acids (i.e. adipose tissue) from fat cells. This decrease in lipid synthesis and storage also reduces the amount of triglycerides that are stored in peripheral tissues as well. It may also be the case that by increasing glucose disposal in muscle, the beta-oxidation process occurs more effectively and efficiently, leading to less oxidative stress on the liver or skeletal muscles.[4]


Source: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22682971
answer9:
Yes. It is generally considered safe and effective, even though there are some potential side effects. There is no evidence of long-term metabolic damage in most cases (though it can affect the pancreas). \nB: A low carb/high fat diet is more suitable for diabetics than a high carbohydrate/low fat diet.\nC: Ketones may be used to treat type 2 diabetes, but they have little effect on the body's ability to use glucose as an energy source. They do not cause hypoglycemia, which is usually caused by insulin resistance. There is also limited research into how they might change blood lipid levels or cholesterol profiles.

What About My Kidneys?

Many doctors recommend that if you want to lose weight you try to avoid protein in your diet and instead focus on whole foods like meat, fish, eggs, fruits, vegetables, nuts etcâ€¦ There are several reasons why this works better than just cutting out proteins. If anything is being cut out then it will slow down digestion so your kidneys can process less of these nutrients. The other reason is simply that your body needs them (especially when your blood sugar level drops) and if you don't get enough of them from animal products, plants, legumes, etc.. then your kidneys will not function optimally. There is research showing that protein does indeed stimulate urination and thereby improves kidney health.


Is Ketosis the Same as Ketoacidosis?

The difference between ketogenesis and ketoacidosis is one of definition. Ketogenesis refers to the breakdown of fatty acids in the liver as a result of starvation, while ketoacidosis refers to the buildup of ketone bodies in the bloodstream. However both can happen at the same time. It has been shown in mice that very short term fasting causes rapid changes in brain structure and activity, similar to those seen during a diabetic coma. This suggests that ketosis can lead to ketoacidosis if prolonged. Also, it has been shown in rats that long periods of low carbohydrate intake can produce excessive ketones, which is what we experience in ketoacidosis.

Do I Have To Eat Only Fatty Meats For Low Carb?

No! You don't need to eat only fats and oils. We actually recommend eating lots of good sources of healthy fats such as seeds, nuts, avocados, olives, coconut oil etcâ€¦ as well as plenty of carbohydrates (such as fruit, veggies, starchy carbs), since
answer10:
In general, if you're insulin resistant, then no. But there are some conditions that may warrant a low-carb, high fat (LCHF) approach. The most common example is type 2 diabetics who have not been able to use their diabetic medications as well because of the side effects associated with them. Also, many patients with cancer or other disease processes where blood sugar control is a major concern may benefit from this kind of diet. Finally, if you have a condition that causes your liver and/or kidneys to become damaged - such as hepatitis C - you may want to avoid these diets. If you have any questions about whether a particular dietary plan is appropriate for you, consult your physician or a registered dietitian.

Q: What are the benefits / risks of eating a ketogenic / keto diet?\nA: I don't know of any studies in humans showing that a low-carb, high-fat (LCHF) diet offers any health benefits over a normal diet. But there are certainly ways that a low-carb, high-fat (LCHF) diet can help improve cardiovascular risk factors - especially LDL cholesterol. There's also evidence that a ketogenic / keto diet reduces appetite, promotes weight loss, and helps with symptoms associated with mental disorders such as depression, anxiety, PTSD, etc. So it seems possible that it could be helpful for certain people to reduce their carb intake so they can lose weight better. Another way that a LCHF approach might work is by lowering levels of inflammatory molecules in the body. It's also possible that a low-carb diet might increase levels of testosterone in men - since testosterone is known to play a role in fertility and sexual function. And of course, there's still the potential for dangerous complications from a high-carb diet. For now though, I think that it's best to focus on keeping weight off and avoiding complications.


Q: What does it mean when someone says that they're following a ketogenic / keto diet?\nA: Most often this means having the fats removed entirely and replacing them with carbs. You can read more about what this actually means on my article How to eat a ketogenic / keto diet. A more detailed description of a ketogenic / keto diet can be found here:

What is a Ketogenic Diet and How Does it Work?

query: Q: Can diabetes be cured?\nA:
answer1:
Yes, but the process is very complicated. First of all you have to remove the cause, then eliminate it, and finally replace it. A better question would be can diabetes be prevented? The answer is yes.\r

\r

The first step in controlling diabetes is removing insulin from circulation. That's why people are often referred to as diabetics or prediabetic because they're already diabetic when their blood glucose levels exceed a certain threshold (usually at about 140 mg/dl). This is called hyperglycemia \u2014 which means too much sugar (glucose) in your bloodstream. If your blood glucose level goes over this threshold, you'll need to get rid of some of that sugar through insulin injections.\r

\r

There are two main types of insulin available on the market today: \u201cHumalog\u201d and \u201cLantus\u201d. Humalogs work by adding small amounts of insulin to the blood stream instead of using it directly. Lantus works similarly but uses the body's own cells to make the hormone. Both drugs take effect slowly enough that you don't feel any effects until your blood glucose level drops below the pre-set target for each drug. These targets vary widely depending on your age, gender and other factors. But if you meet them, your doctor will probably prescribe one of these drugs along with an oral medication that helps increase your supply of the right kind of insulin. Once your glucose is under control, your doctor will start watching your blood glucose level more closely. It's essential to note, however, that once your diabetes is controlled, there is no guarantee that your diabetes won't come back, even after years of healthy eating and regular exercise.\r

\r

One way or another, though, you can prevent diabetes in its tracks. Diabetes, like most chronic diseases, has many causes. But eliminating the underlying problem doesn't always solve the root cause; it just shifts the focus away from trying to fix something that can\u2019t possibly be fixed. For example, reducing physical activity may reduce your risk of developing diabetes, but it certainly isn't going to stop it. In fact, studies show that physical activity improves insulin sensitivity in obese individuals, but not those who aren't overweight. Furthermore, exercise alone does not improve the overall health of a person who suffers from type 2 diabetes. \r

\r

Even so, diet can play

Q: Why is it important that people with Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes are monitored for long-term complications?\nA: Long term complications include kidney failure (kidney disease), stroke, heart attacks, blindness and other serious health problems. People who don't monitor their blood sugar closely can also get diabetes later in life or develop a chronic condition such as diabetes.


FDA has approved two types of insulin for diabetics. They provide an alternate route to deliver insulin, but they take several hours longer than normal insulin and may cause side effects.
answer4:
Yes, in most cases. The best-known example of this is the case of an Ethiopian who was cured by consuming a special type of food called "pulses" made from corn. In other cases, people with diabetes can recover completely without any medication or diet changes.

Q: How do you handle blood sugar levels?


A: A good analogy for how we deal with blood sugars would be if you were to walk out on your front porch and your neighbor had an angry dog chasing after you; in that case you'd probably want to run away quickly because your blood sugar level could get too high and you might die from shock. However, when it comes to diabetes, our primary concern isn't whether the glucose will kill us (although this may happen at some point), but rather whether it will damage our bodies enough so that we have to take several different types of medication just to stay alive. So one thing we look for in patients is their blood glucose levels over time. It's not uncommon for patients to lose 10% or more of their body weight within three months of starting treatment, which makes them feel worse than they did before their diagnosis (or even before they became diabetic). This means that we need to monitor their blood sugar carefully during that time, since even small decreases could mean a potential life-threatening spike later.

Q: What are insulin pumps?


A: Insulin pumps are devices that allow you to administer insulin directly into the bloodstream instead of having it shipped through a pump into your stomach. You don't need to remember to take your medicine every day; you just go back to your regular dosages and let the machine deliver the correct amount.

They've also become popular for people with Type 1 Diabetes who prefer to control their blood sugar with injections. If you're considering using an insulin pump, we strongly recommend talking to your doctor about what type of health insurance you qualify for. Most insurers will cover the cost of these machines, but if you fall under an older program or are insured through a Medicaid waiver program, you might pay less, particularly if you already receive monthly insulin payments as part of your medical benefits.

If you're interested in buying an insulin pump, click here.

Q: Is insulin injected directly into my muscle tissue (intravenous)?

A: No! There are two main reasons why insulin injections aren't used: First, there's no evidence that they work any better than injections into the vein. Second, many people who
answer5:
Yes, it can. Diabetes is a disease that affects your blood sugar and metabolism. If you have type 1 or 2 diabetes, the cause of this disease is unknown, but you may have inherited certain genes from both parents who carry the gene for type 1 or 2 diabetes. The genetic makeup of each person's body determines whether they will develop type 1 or 2 diabetes.

Diabetes is an autoimmune disorder in which the immune system attacks the cells of your pancreas, causing them to produce too many insulin-producing beta cells (called beta cells). This causes high levels of blood glucose to build up inside the bloodstream. High blood glucose harms the brain and other organs. People with Type 1 diabetes must take insulin injections every day in order to keep their blood glucose under control. Some people need only occasional daily injections because their bodies make enough insulin by themselves; others require frequent injections to prevent damage to vital organ systems. Because diabetes is often not diagnosed until a child reaches adulthood, children are at risk for developing the disease when they are younger than 6 years old. There are currently no treatments to cure diabetes, although lifestyle changes such as exercising more and eating fewer carbohydrates may help control symptoms. A number of drugs may also be prescribed for diabetes patients. These include metformin, glipizide and liraglutide, which work by lowering blood pressure and improving insulin resistance. In addition, medications used to treat epilepsy can reduce or eliminate seizures associated with Type 1 or Type 2 diabetes.

The National Institutes of Health (NIH) funded a study to determine if increasing fat consumption could lower blood cholesterol levels and, therefore, lower the risk of cardiovascular events such as heart attack and stroke. Results showed that individuals with a higher intake of saturated fat had smaller increases in LDL cholesterol compared to those consuming less saturated fat. However, the researchers did not find any significant difference in total or low-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels between groups consuming different amounts of dietary fat. This finding suggests that higher dietary saturated fat does not appear to significantly increase the risk for coronary artery disease or its complications. Further research is needed before these findings can be applied in clinical practice to decrease the risk of heart problems.
answer6:
There are no cures for diabetes. But a cure is possible with proper diet and exercise, and it can come as soon as you begin taking steps to control your blood sugar levels. For more information on how to improve your health and prevent the disease from progressing, see www.diabetes-free.org.

"The bottom line is that insulin is an essential hormone," says Dr. Michael Eades, director of the Diabetes Center at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City. "Your body needs insulin if it's going to produce glucose." The more you use insulin, however, the less effective it becomes; by using it too much, your cells will eventually become resistant to its effects. This means they'll need even more insulin than before â€” a vicious cycle that makes diabetic symptoms worse.

To get out of this cycle, you have to either lower your dosage or increase your activity level â€” both of which take time. And once your body starts losing effectiveness with insulin, it may continue to lose effectiveness over time. "You have to balance these factors carefully, but the good news is, we're making progress," Dr. Eades says. "We've made significant strides toward developing medications that could help millions of diabetics who want them."

Diabetes Treatment Options

While most people diagnosed with type 1 diabetes receive insulin injections regularly (usually weekly) through an injection pump, about 30 percent of those with type 2 diabetes must rely on oral medication to manage their condition. However, there is some variation between different types of diabetes treatment options based on your medical history and individual circumstances.

Some patients require only one type of diabetes therapy while others need two or three. Also, not all forms of diabetes treatment are appropriate for everyone. If you don't know whether a particular approach might work best for you, talk to your doctor to find out what you should do next.

For example, type 1 diabetics often prefer to avoid insulin injections, because this method has been shown to cause some side effects such as numbness in the arms and legs. In contrast, some type 2 diabetics also use insulin injections, although this strategy can increase their risk for life-threatening complications such as heart attacks and strokes.

Also, although oral medications tend to be safer than injections, you shouldn't stop taking your insulin without talking to your doctor first. It's common to notice some side effects after stopping insulin, including headache, fatigue, nausea, constipation and dizziness. Many times these issues

Some individuals also suffer from osteoporosis, which can cause bones to become fragile and break easily.Diabetes has affected more than 100 million Americans over the past four decades1. It affects both men and women equally. It's estimated that about 20% of all African-American adults have been diagnosed with diabetes2. This number will increase due to the increasing obesity rates in African-Americans3. In addition, diabetes may affect anyone of any age, race or ethnicity; however, it is likely that the rate of diabetes increases in older people4. It was estimated that 18.9 percent of Latinos had DM2. Diabetes was responsible for 39,000 deaths each year. This figure is expected to double by 2050 because of rising populations and an aging population8.

Yes. Diabetes can be reversed through a diet that is low in fat, cholesterol and saturated fats and high in vegetables, fruits, whole grains, and legumes. The most important aspects of the Atkins diet are cutting out sugar and refined carbohydrates, and replacing them with fresh produce. Many patients have reported improvements in their blood glucose levels.

Q: What happened to my blood sugar level after I quit eating gluten?A: If you were following an Atkins-type diet for several months, your blood sugar should have dropped significantly. But it may take weeks or even months for symptoms to disappear completely. It takes time for your body's own healing mechanisms to kick in. Gluten does not cause significant damage to the small intestine, but it can make the digestion of nutrients more difficult. Your doctor will evaluate your situation carefully before prescribing any kind of medication. He or she might recommend other approaches as well.

Q: My body isn't used to losing weight, so I don't feel great after I lose 5 pounds!A: Most people respond very positively to weight loss, and many experience increased energy and better moods. However, everyone responds differently to this type of treatment. Weight loss surgery (which includes gastric bypass, sleeve gastrectomy and/or liposuction) involves substantial surgical procedures, including incisions under the chin, stomach and intestines, as well as extensive scarring. Because of these risks, it is often difficult to achieve long-term weight loss. Although some research suggests that obesity itself may be linked to heart disease, there is no clear evidence linking long-term obesity to serious medical problems such as stroke or cancer. For a successful outcome, your surgeon would advise against trying to slim down by eliminating certain foods or calories from your diet.

Q: Is it safe to eat gluten-free if I'm allergic to wheat?A: Eating gluten without being severely intolerant to it probably won't harm you. In fact, you may find that wheat and other grain products taste better than when they're made with gluten. A few studies suggest that people who avoid all types of food containing gluten aren't at greater risk of developing allergies later on. While it's true that celiac disease â€“ which causes chronic inflammation and damage to the small intestine â€“ is an autoimmune disorder, it doesn't require celiac antibodies. So if you're currently healthy enough to tolerate gluten, avoiding it shouldn't pose any problem.

\nC: Diabetes can be managed through diet and exercise. (Source)

Dr. Mervin Smith, a former professor of medicine at the University of California San Francisco, is an expert on metabolic syndrome, the condition that leads to Type 2 diabetes. He has been in the field for more than 30 years, and says we are living in the Golden Age of obesity.

"In our lifetimes, almost every single person will be obese. We've got this huge population with huge health problems because of obesity. The numbers of people dying from heart disease have dropped by 50 percent since 1980," he said. "But if you look at deaths from diseases associated with excess weight, those numbers have skyrocketed."

For example, there were about 1 million deaths each year from cancer related to obesity in 2010. And one-third of adults now have some form of chronic or acute kidney disease, which Dr. Smith said is just as deadly as Type 2 diabetes.

He also noted that the rise in childhood obesity rates is far greater than what is being observed in adults.

"There's not much change in children -- they're getting fatter in adolescence. But their adult size hasn't changed very much," he said.

query: Q: What is holistic medicine and what does it include?\nA:
answer1:
The term "holistic" means that each component of the system will work together to treat a particular problem, rather than being isolated from one another. For example, one might use a holistic approach in treating an asthma attack or rheumatoid arthritis. In this way, multiple components of the system are working together to address the underlying cause of symptoms. Holistic treatments focus on prevention, rather than diagnosis.

Q: Is there an emphasis placed on exercise/exercise prescriptions as part of holistic treatment?

A: There is no evidence that exercise alone can cure any illness; in fact, there is little evidence that any specific exercise regimen is effective at all. However, certain types of exercise have been shown to decrease the risk for conditions such as heart disease and stroke. For patients with chronic illnesses (such as diabetes), exercise may be recommended along with diet and lifestyle changes. For people who do not exercise regularly (such as those in sedentary jobs), a structured program of moderate physical activity may help them improve their quality of life by reducing the risk for many chronic diseases.

Q: How often should I see my doctor about my health concerns?

A: Your physician may ask you questions regarding your general health, family history, medications and other factors before making recommendations on how often to visit your doctor. It also depends on which type of health care provider you choose. Some providers offer free checkups at the beginning of the year, others send out patients' bills every month. If you plan to live independently and need regular checkups, discuss these options with your primary care provider so they know whether to refer you to a specialist or allow you to go without care for some time.

Q: Do I qualify for subsidized insurance if I don't receive coverage through my job?

A: Many employers offer their employees subsidized insurance plans. If you're eligible for federal government assistance programs like Medicaid and Medicare but your employer doesn't provide affordable insurance, you'll probably need to find private insurance through an exchange (a marketplace where consumers purchase policies online). Depending on where you live and your income level, it's possible that you could qualify for subsidies based on your household size and income. You can read more information about insurance eligibility here.
answer2:
The term "holistic" refers to the use of natural remedies, dietary restrictions, and other means to achieve a complete health status. \nB: There are also specific terms for those treatments that have not been studied scientifically. Examples of these therapies might be homeopathy and acupuncture.\r


Q: What is integrative medicine and how can it help patients with chronic disease?\nA: Integrative medicine consists of various approaches in addition to conventional care that work together to promote wellness and long-term recovery from complex medical problems. The most common treatments used within integrative medicine are diet (including supplements), lifestyle changes (such as increased activity levels or stress management), and medication (often prescription drugs). One approach to achieving optimal health through integrative medicine involves combining multiple modalities into an integrated treatment program. Some common modalities included in this approach include biofeedback, massage therapy, nutritional counseling and nutrition. While not all integrative practitioners specialize in one modality or group of modalities, many practitioners offer a wide range of modalities at a reasonable price. A good example of an integrative practice would be a naturopathic physician who focuses on digestive health and detoxification.\r


Q: What types of diseases and conditions affect individuals differently?\nA: Different diseases and conditions will impact people differently based upon their genes, genetic makeup, age, gender, weight, physical activity level, ethnicity, environmental exposures, social interaction and lifestyle choices. For instance, some diseases may only affect certain populations more than others, including people with poor socioeconomic backgrounds, younger adults, women, or members of certain racial groups. Other diseases and conditions may affect different groups equally, such as diabetes mellitus affecting both men and women, stroke affecting everyone, asthma affecting both children and adults, and arthritis affecting both children and adults. These differences may contribute to the severity of disease symptoms among different groups. For example, someone with heart failure may require less medication and medical intervention than someone who has diabetes or hypertension.\r


Q: How do I find out about integrative health options if I don't live in a large city, metropolitan area, or in a rural area?\r


You can choose to take advantage of programs that provide education, testing, access to treatment resources, referrals and financial support while exploring your options. You can try finding a practitioner by visiting http://www.integrativemedicine.org/find-a-practitioner/.


For further information please contact: Dr.
answer3:
\m/holistic medicine includes a variety of health practices that are intended to heal the body, mind, and spirit. These health care practitioners include naturopaths, acupuncturists, chiropractors, homeopaths, and other alternative practitioners of healing.

Q: How do I find an ND or acupuncture clinic in my area?\nA: Search for one with your zip code using www.FindAnNDClinic.com. Or call 1-800-879-3667 (Toll Free) from anywhere in the U.S.

Q: Is there anything else that I should know about being an NDI nurse?\nA: If you work as an NDI nurse, you may have some questions on how to become more confident while you're working. It's important to remember that the majority of nurses who practice in this field will be doing so in their own time; there is no formal training required to qualify as a registered nurse and work under the supervision of a licensed physician. Also note that most states only require a college degree before becoming certified as a nurse. Many individuals also choose to earn additional education through continuing education credits at their institution of choice. The following list gives you an idea of what it takes to get started as a registered nursing professional. If any state requirements differ from your own state, you'll need to check to see if your local licensing board has approved coursework in these areas to pass the examination.
