answer4:
In holistic health care, we refer to all of the modalities that support a patient's overall well-being. A holistic approach to health care emphasizes the integration of medical knowledge, research, and practical experience in order to create optimal health outcomes for individual patients. The integrative body of knowledge includes both traditional and nontraditional approaches including complementary and alternative (CAM) treatments; natural therapies such as massage therapy, yoga, acupuncture and herbalism; psychotherapeutic tools; nutrition; and lifestyle changes, including exercise. \r

\r


Source: Center for Holistic Medicine, Department of Family Practice, University of Washington School of Nursing

In addition to a complete list of practitioners who have received training with the National Council on Complementary and Alternative Health, this directory also contains information about each practitioner's background and professional experiences.
answer5: There are various definitions of the term "holistic" depending on who you ask, but there really isn't a universal definition. It basically means that when we think about health care, we need to make sure that all of our interventions or treatments for illness have at least some of their roots in science. This means focusing on things like nutrition, exercise, sleep, stress management, environmental conditions (like air pollution), medication use, etc., rather than treating illnesses based on outdated "natural" remedies. For example, many people have heard of homeopathy as an alternative treatment option, but few realize how outdated this concept actually is. Homeopathic remedies work by manipulating substances like minerals or organic compounds such as essential oils or plant extracts without actually testing them in a laboratory or making any chemicals themselves. They rely instead on traditional knowledge derived from the natural world, which can be very hard to come by. In other words, homeopaths do not synthesize the compounds they use in their remedy; they simply take these components naturally occurring in natureâ€”and sometimes even mix them up with something elseâ€”to create an oil that has properties similar to those found in nature. Because of the lack of standardization and regulation around homeopathic medicines, one must be extremely careful when choosing whether or not to treat a particular ailment with a homeopathic remedy. In addition, no scientific research has ever confirmed or debunked any specific claim made by homeopaths, so it's difficult to know if a remedy actually works. \NIn addition, because there are no guarantees that using homeopathy will work for every illness, it also doesn't mean that the alternative medicine itself should be ignored. Some may find that taking part in a complementary therapy program allows them to reduce their anxiety symptoms while still being fully supported by the healthcare system. Other patients may benefit from regular visits to a medical doctor who provides the support they need to live healthy lives. The bottom line is that holistic medicine takes into account all factors involved in improving health. As an example, if a patient comes in complaining of chronic pain, he needs to focus on ways his diet, activity level, physical fitness, lifestyle choices, stress levels, social connections, depression and other mental issues contribute to his overall health status. If the first three indicators point to increased inflammation due to unhealthy eating habits, exercise habits, and other lifestyle factors, then more research will need to be done to determine the true cause of the pain, along with a possible solution. This type of approach eliminates unnecessary tests and unnecessary drugs, which can ultimately save
answer6:
The term "holistic" is used to describe the approach of treating a patient's whole body in harmony with one's internal health. A healthy body, mind, spirit and environment are interconnected. Holistically-minded doctors use medical science and clinical reasoning to determine which treatment options will best treat each patient's needs. They follow an integrative model based on physical, psychological, social and spiritual factors that all contribute to disease prevention and management. Examples of holism-based interventions include yoga, meditation, acupuncture, chiropractic care, nutrition counseling, herbs, nutritional supplements and homeopathy, among many other types of therapies. \N: When will holistic medicine become more accepted?\r


The concept of holistic medicine has gained momentum over the past 20 years as evidence has accumulated demonstrating its effectiveness for treating some of our nation's most complex and challenging chronic diseases. At the same time, though, this idea remains somewhat controversial because of misconceptions about what constitutes "holistic" medicine and skepticism toward conventional treatments. However, recent advances in research have provided an increasingly robust basis for belief that a holistic approach can improve quality of life by increasing general health and wellbeing. While the acceptance rate of holistic approaches is still low at approximately 5 percent (in part due to concerns regarding potential side effects), there is now mounting scientific evidence demonstrating the efficacy of these treatments against common disorders such as asthma, heart failure, cancer, arthritis, diabetes and depression. In addition, researchers continue to learn from these studies about how they work, including their mechanisms of action. Finally, there are numerous non-pharmaceutical complementary approaches available for patients who wish to incorporate aspects of holistic therapy into their overall treatment plan. For example, holistic practitioners often recommend dietary changes, herbal remedies, exercise programs, and massage techniques. Many holistic professionals also refer patients for alternative diagnoses including neurology and psychiatry when conventional care fails to provide relief for specific symptoms. Finally, clinicians should be prepared to recognize that not everyone seeking help through a traditional system will go through conventional treatment first, particularly if they believe that unconventional modalities may offer better results. As an added benefit, conventional providers must consider how to integrate new therapies or alternatives into their practices without compromising quality of care. This can mean finding ways to communicate effectively with clients while maintaining ethical standards. The American College of Physicians offers guidance for integrating complementary therapies and integrative models.\r

SOURCE: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15172749
answer7:
\r

Integrative medicine (IM) is the medical application of health care that emphasizes all aspects of a person's health, including lifestyle as well as physical, emotional, spiritual, social, cultural, environmental, and cognitive health. IM incorporates an integrative approach to disease prevention and treatment, patient education, and preventive health promotion through a wide range of modalities such as diet, nutrition, exercise, behavioral therapy, acupuncture, massage, naturopathy, yoga, tai chi, qigong, music therapy, counseling, biofeedback, and more. As health providers, we strive to work with patients to achieve their goals in both traditional and non-traditional ways. We believe we are best served by partnering with the people around usâ€”our families, friends, colleagues, classmates, community partnersâ€”and treating them with respect and dignity." \[\] http://www.fakir.org/about_us/im

This also applies to illnesses which are more likely to occur in babies and toddlers (such as ear infections, eczema and sinusitis).

answer9: "Holistic medicine" refers to a medical approach based on an integrative approach that embraces the entire person, including those areas of health where traditional Western medicine has failed. A holistic approach incorporates a variety of modalities into a comprehensive treatment plan. The goal of this system is to balance the body's functions so that individuals have greater resilience against disease and chronic illness. Holistic medicine also encompasses a multidisciplinary team approach for patients who are not able to provide their own care. In addition to using standard treatments, such as conventional drugs or surgery, holistic physicians may prescribe complementary therapies, dietary supplements, lifestyle changes, or other interventions designed to restore homeostasis in each area of the body. \NQ: Why should I consider joining the NCNA/ACBP?\nA: In addition to improving your health and wellness, you will enjoy benefits beyond monetary reimbursement. Furthermore, we support our membership with professional development opportunities through state-of-the-art training programs that prepare professionals to work effectively with patients who suffer from physical and mental illnesses. Additionally, as the national association representing more than 40,000 licensed acupuncturists and naturopathic doctors, we strive to advance all facets of medical practice by providing education to the public about alternative approaches to healing, educating policymakers about the importance of a diverse workforce in healthcare delivery systems, and supporting the advancement of scientific knowledge of complementary and alternative approaches. As a member-based organization, we encourage active participation in both advocacy efforts and legislative lobbying to protect the rights of practitioners who use complementary approaches for patient care. query: Q: What are the most common mental health problems? How can I prevent or manage the most common mental health problems?\nA:
answer1:
The National Institute of Mental Health estimates that between 12.8 and 15 percent of all American adults will experience some kind of major depression in any given year, with about 2.5 million Americans experiencing major depressive disorder each year (NIMH, 2004a). Major depression is a condition characterized by depressed mood lasting at least two weeks and associated with significant impairment in social, occupational or other areas of functioning. It often involves at least three symptoms:

1. A loss of interest or pleasure usually accompanied by weight loss

2. Lethargy or sleep disturbance

3. Feelings of guilt or worthlessness

4. Changes in appetite or weight

The NIMH also reports that suicide is the third leading cause of death for Americans aged 10 to 44 years old. Suicide is one of four main causes of death among men and women. Other major causes of death include accidents, homicides, and diseases including cancer and chronic respiratory disease (National Center for Injury Prevention and Control [NCIPC], 2006). Individuals who develop serious mental illness have an increased risk for suicidal behaviors (Paller et al., 2001; Sommers, 2005). An estimated 50 percent of people with severe depression attempt suicide during their lifetime (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC] 2003), and more than 20 percent will die from it within five years (Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, 2010; CDC 2007) as compared to 16 percent of people without depression who commit suicide. These rates are similar to those seen in previous studies examining suicide attempts (Erez-Likhovskii et al., 2002). Most individuals diagnosed with depression receive treatment. Treatment consists of psychotherapy, medications, or both. Medications commonly prescribed for depression are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as fluoxetine, escitalopram, paroxetine, sertraline, citalopram, bupropion, and vilazodone. Other medication choices include tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOI), antipsychotics, benzodiazepines, and lithium. SSRIs, which are used as monotherapy in about 75% of cases, do not cure depression but may help control its symptoms. Some patients respond well to antidepressant drugs alone, while others require several different treatments before they are fully treated. MAOIs and TCAs, typically used in combination, are considered "medication-resistant" because they tend to produce side
answer2:
Mental illness affects millions of people worldwide. It is estimated that the prevalence rate for depression in the United States is 17%, and it is likely to be even higher among women (1). As a result, there may not be a single disorder that is more common than another across all populations. While many individuals with depression experience significant distress over their condition, others have no problem functioning. The number one risk factor for developing major depressive disorder is having a family history of this disease (2). It has been reported that up to 50% of patients diagnosed with bipolar disorder had an older brother or sister who also experienced symptoms of depression (3). Most people with serious mental disorders do not seek treatment because they do not know where to go or how to get help. Many believe that a diagnosis means you must accept your condition as normal, but this simply is not true. There is an urgent need for better screening tools to identify people at high risk for suicide before the onset of a depressive episode. In addition, interventions such as cognitive behavioral therapy or medication management may reduce suicidal thoughts in some cases. It is important to realize that being treated for a mental health condition does not guarantee recovery from depression. For example, people with schizophrenia who receive proper medical care often recover completely. However, those with untreated psychosis will remain vulnerable to future episodes of the same disorder. If someone comes to you looking for assistance, please feel free to refer them to our resources page for information on available services.\nA: Is there anything else I should consider? We are here to provide support and counseling for anyone seeking information about any type of mental health concern. Our staff can help determine whether you require individual help, group counseling or professional psychological assessment. Call us at 1-800-923-7359 today!\nA: Do you offer crisis intervention training? Yes, we do. Our counseling centers routinely conduct crisis intervention trainings to ensure that clients receive appropriate, trained support when faced with a life threatening situation. These trainings include: Stress Management - A skills workshop for individuals and couples that addresses issues related to stress, fear, anger, shame, self-esteem and conflict resolution. This training includes a 15 minute talk, and follows up with 30 minutes of group time for additional feedback.

There is a wide range of mental disorders. Mental illness, including anxiety and depression, may be related to biological factors such as genetics, hormone levels (e.g., estrogen), neurotransmitters (e.g., dopamine) or environmental factors (e.g., stress). Other conditions that are associated with severe psychological distress include substance abuse, eating disorder symptoms, sleep disturbances and mood swings. Some people who have experienced mental illness do not go on to develop other chronic medical conditions. However, some chronic physical conditions may also occur in individuals who have been diagnosed with a mental health disorder. For example, certain psychiatric disorders often co-occur with heart disease, diabetes and cancer. It is important for physicians and patients to understand that any one of these conditions can trigger an individual's development of another mental condition. As part of your care at the hospital, you will receive regular and ongoing treatment counseling regarding your mental health concerns. In addition, the following treatments and therapies may help reduce the frequency of your depression or anxiety, decrease the severity of your depression or anxiety and improve your quality of life. These treatments and therapies may help reduce the risk of developing additional chronic illnesses such as heart disease, type 2 diabetes, stroke and certain cancers: Medications for acute episodes

Psychotherapy, cognitive behavioral therapy, mindfulness meditation and yoga for chronic episodes

Social support groups for family members or friends experiencing similar depressive or anxiety symptoms

Family education programs about depression or other types of mental health challenges The American Psychiatric Association (APA) has published a document entitled "The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders â€“ 5th Edition," which lists all the DSM diagnoses. This document includes a brief summary of each diagnosis, along with information on how it is treated. See Appendix C below for more information about the APA's diagnostic criteria. You can read the full text of this document on their website, www.dsm5.org. While reading this document, we encourage you to consult your doctor or mental health professional if you have questions about specific symptoms or if you need medication changes based on the new edition of the DSM. You may also want to consider speaking to your GP, a psychiatrist or clinical psychologist about your own personal experience using medications and/or psychotherapy, particularly if you feel under increasing pressure due to your mental health condition. If your symptoms change dramatically but remain present, ask your healthcare provider what medications you should try next. Also, ask about possible future changes in your treatment regimen, particularly if there have been no changes to your symptoms

Mental health is a complex problem that affects us all, regardless of age and sex. Mental illnesses include depression, bipolar disorder (manic-depression), anxiety disorders and schizophrenia. The majority of people with these conditions are young adults aged between 20 and 40 years old, but it can affect anyone who experiences stressful life events such as divorce, bereavement and loss of employment, for example. As well as these common issues we see, there are many other less obvious causes including eating disorders, substance abuse and self harm. \nBriefly summarising this section, if you have symptoms which do not match the criteria in this guide then the first step is to seek help from your doctor. This will require them to check whether the condition you're experiencing fits into one of the categories listed above; and if so, what the cause is. If you still think the condition doesn't fit then you may need to work through a series of questions to find out exactly why you feel distressed. You should be aware that at any stage in this process, your GP or psychologist could refer you to other medical professionals, such as a psychiatrist, occupational therapist, counsellor or psychologist, depending on the nature of your symptoms, their severity and how they impact on your day-to-day activities. If you choose to get professional advice about getting better from someone else, make sure they know about your condition so that they don't inadvertently treat you differently from everyone else, and that you've discussed the possibility of leaving the relationship before you enter treatment. A list of organisations where you can get support for mental health problems and a referral form are available via NHS Choices. It's also possible to get help online, either by calling helplines run by charities or government departments. Find further information below for some of the more common mental health problems. There's no substitute for talking to someone about your needs.

1) Depression \u00a0Symptoms of depression can vary widely, but for most people, feeling down or depressed is associated with low mood or loss of interest in usual things. However, even if you experience milder forms of depression - like those described above - you may still benefit from talking with your doctor about ways of managing it. Your doctor can help you learn new coping strategies and identify triggers. They'll likely recommend taking antidepressant medication, although different medicines may be prescribed depending on the type of depression you have. Read more here.

Some people with mental disorders show no outward signs that they're sick; they might not seem sad, anxious or depressed at all. Others might feel different when compared to other people in their social and work environments, leading them to question whether they really belong there. APA's membership includes nearly 130,000 researchers, educators, clinicians, consultants and students. Through its divisions in 54 subfields of psychology and affiliations with 60 state, territorial and Canadian provincial associations, APA works to advance psychology as a science, as a profession and as a means of promoting human welfare.

Many people have a variety of health conditions, including those that affect your ability to carry out daily activities. For instance, some people experience chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS), which may be caused by an immune system disorder; depression is one symptom of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD); and anxiety is another symptom of PTSD. These disorders can affect you in different ways. Some people with these illnesses also have problems with substance use and abuse, such as alcoholism and drug and alcohol dependence. Others do not have any psychiatric symptoms but report significant changes in their physical appearance, behavior, or sleep patterns. A number of other conditions may be associated with these problems, too. The following list summarizes common problems and their treatment options. \NACIH NIMH Publication #2011-13.\r

answer7:
Many of the most common mental disorders involve anxiety, depression and other mood disorders. People with these conditions often have a variety of problems with their interpersonal relationships, work, school and family life. While people who suffer from these kinds of psychological disorders may not be able to control their symptoms, they do need treatment in order to improve their quality of life.\ n \n

As an example, some people may feel depressed because they don't feel like going out anymore, so they go to bed early rather than stay up late watching television and getting into arguments with their spouses or partners. Other individuals might develop a negative self-image due to concerns about physical appearance and weight. People can also experience a depressive episode when they feel overwhelmed by feelings of helplessness over being unable to solve their own problems.\ nIn addition, people suffering from personality disorders (such as antisocial personality disorder, paranoid personality disorder, and borderline personality disorder) may tend to display impulsive and irrational behaviors that may make it difficult for them to cope with stressors such as job loss, divorce, or illness. When coping with these issues, people with these kinds of disorders typically seek help through their doctors and therapists.\ n

Another major challenge is understanding how specific behavioral problems influence one's chances of developing a mental health disorder. For instance, research indicates that if someone has experienced childhood trauma or severe emotional abuse, they are more likely to suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The link between chronic stress and mental health problems is further strengthened by recent evidence showing that certain genetic factors influence vulnerability to PTSD and other types of mental illnesses. Research shows that certain variations in genes determine whether someone is genetically susceptible to experiencing chronic stressful events. Because certain genes affect risk for PTSD and other mental illnesses, prevention strategies may be useful during adolescence and young adulthood.\ nThe National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism and the American Psychological Association recommend that teens who want to reduce or eliminate their drinking should avoid binge drinking and limit alcohol intake to no more than two drinks per day for women, and three drinks per day for men.\ nDrinking too much alcohol in small amounts while under the influence of other drugs such as marijuana increases risks for negative effects on brain function, including decreased memory and concentration.\ nFor more information, visit www.americanpublichealthsystem.org/mentalhealth/pubs/.

These symptoms typically increase during these episodes. There is also a range of other physical symptoms associated with this type of mental illness.\r

Many people who suffer from mental illness do not seek help until they become seriously ill. answer9: Mental Health is a complex area of medicine with numerous sub-disorders, many of which need specialized treatment. The most commonly recognized disorders and their associated disorders include depression, anxiety disorder (ADHD), ADHD, bipolar disorder (manic depressive illness) and schizophrenia. Some individuals also have substance use disorders as well as other psychiatric diagnoses such as schizophrenia spectrum (schizoaffective disorder). One symptom of anxiety or depression is loss of interest in activities, hobbies, or social interactions, including those that may seem pleasant or pleasurable. People may worry excessively about what they see or hear, become easily frustrated or anxious, become apathetic to people and surroundings, avoid eye contact and conversation, and experience intrusive thoughts (for example, "I don't like you"). Other symptoms of anxiety include being restless or having difficulty sleeping or relaxing, feeling overwhelmed by feelings of guilt, shame or worthlessness, feeling irritable or out of control, losing interest in going out into the world or doing things with friends, feeling hopeless and/or giving up. Many people suffer from an emotional eating disorder when they eat at inappropriate times or without eating certain foods because of fear of gaining weight. Others complain of sleep deprivation or oversleeping. Sometimes these symptoms are mild and go unnoticed but sometimes they lead to increased rates of self-harm, suicidal ideation, suicide attempts, and even violence. People with some types of physical illnesses such as diabetes, heart disease, arthritis, etc., can develop stress and/or anger issues. For people living with a mental illness, some types of medications can help reduce symptoms and improve mood. If you think you may be experiencing symptoms related to your mental health you should seek professional guidance immediately. You may want to talk to someone who knows more than you about these conditions for advice and support.\nB: \1-800-273-8255, www.mentalhealthamerica.org; and \2-877-4ADHD(4357); www.askadhd.com\ nC: \1-866-946-5646, www.crisiscentersontlouisiana.org; and \2-888-941-1914, www.nationalaccesstofamilies.net\ nD: \1-800-222-1222, www.lifeline.org; and \2-800-784-2433, www.pagercenter.org\ nE: \1-800-711-6072, www

The mental health problem is what it sounds likeâ€”the emotional, psychological, and/or cognitive impact of a mental disorder. The following list includes some of the most common mental disorders that are associated with suicide: anxiety; depression; bipolar disorder (manic-depressive illness); schizophrenia; postpartum psychosis; PTSD (posttraumatic stress disorder), phobias; attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD); conduct disorders; alcohol and drug abuse; eating disorders; sexual dysfunction; self harm; and suicide attempts.[1] Some other common mental disorders include major depressive disorder (MDD) and dysthymia, which are characterized by alternating periods of depressed mood and severe distress. There are also an assortment of developmental disabilities associated with ADHD as well as learning difficulties in autism spectrum disorder. It's important to note that while many people suffering from these disorders may not be suicidal, their conditions may increase one's risk for suicide in certain situations. These factors include: being in a relationship with someone who has a diagnosed mental disorder; having suicidal thoughts before you have ever had them; living alone; feeling isolated; being sexually abused as a child; experiencing extreme financial difficulties; and having a history of childhood trauma such as neglect and physical abuse. Suicide prevention organizations such as Samaritans provide support services and resources to help those affected by mental illnesses feel more comfortable discussing their concerns with others, and to provide a safe environment where they can seek help. They also work to create more supportive environments within the communities they serve. For information about suicide prevention and how to get involved, visit www.samaritans.org.

query: Q: what is psychotherapy?\nA:
answer1:
psychological therapy is the clinical treatment of mental disorders. It includes, but is not limited to, the use of medication and other therapies as well as structured psychotherapeutic interventions.

Treatment for Anxiety, Panic Disorder, Obsessive-Compulsive Disorders, Mood Disorder (Major Depressive Disorder), Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder with Borderline Personality Disorder and Substance Use Disorders including Alcoholism, Cannabis Dependence, Cocaine Addiction, Nicotine Dependence, Pain Medication Misuse, Other Drug Abuse or Dependency (with or without a prescription).
answer2: In my opinion, it's a type of therapy that you can use to help someone with their depression. A person might have been depressed for the last six months or so and has no hope in finding relief. After some time of trying various things (depression pills), taking medication (anti-depressants) and not being able to find relief, they decide that maybe there's something wrong with them. They go through a few sessions of psychotherapy. The purpose of this type of therapy is to try to get to know themselves better. Some people just want to talk about their feelings and don't really care much how they're going to do it. Other people are more interested in learning about themselves as individuals. You should feel free to ask questions. Most people will give you honest answers without giving up too many details that may make them uncomfortable. However, if your therapist gives you advice that you feel is inappropriate, then be aware that he or she might be guilty of abuse. I would think that anyone who tells you how to live your life is potentially abusive, but even when the counselor does not say anything outright, one has to keep an eye out for any clues. I have heard many stories from people who were abused by therapists who gave them bad advice. If a counselor tries to convince you that you need to change your attitude and actions, I would think that he/she is abusing his/her position and has violated ethical standards. \nB: Why did you choose this field?\mA: I have always enjoyed psychology. It brings me joy to see people smile at their children or hear a child laugh. Also, psychology provides a very unique experience. I am always looking for new experiences to expand on, learn new skills and increase my knowledge base. People tend to look down upon those who study other fields because they seem to be stuck doing the same old thing. Psychology is different. There is nothing stagnant about psychology. I enjoy seeing the growth in our students, particularly undergrads. This makes me happy; it means that we are continuing to grow. It also forces us to continually push ourselves. We can't rest on our laurels. There isn't much room for mistakes, especially in graduate school. Our students are like little monkeys that are constantly having to learn new things. This aspect of the program appeals to me greatly. It allows me to provide opportunities for growth and development while making sure that all graduates are ready for employment. I'm also passionate about working with young adults, which helps me maintain a
answer3:
A therapist is a person who helps people to change their life by working with the way they think, feel and behave. You can use it to make yourself happier or more successful in life. In most countries where there are therapists you will be able to find one through a search engine.

Q: What does an introvert do when he/she goes into therapy?\nA: An introverted person usually takes part in group sessions because they need support from other people while he/she changes his/her thinking and behavior. Introverts work better alone because they don't have the social skills required for this kind of therapy.


Q: How does the mind work?\nA: The mind works like any other machine - it has its own parts that keep it going and its self-adjusting function. It's like your computer, its core functions keep it running. This means that we humans often tend to use certain parts of our minds to adjust things around us, but not all the time. We also use parts of the brain for various types of thought, feeling and behaviour; the idea being that we only use the parts of our brains that allow us to think, feel and act clearly. When someone starts using the whole system they are called an extrovert. However, we still need some parts of the brain to perform basic tasks like controlling breathing or swallowing, which introverts don't need since the rest of the body controls these activities.


Q: What are the major problems associated with introversion?\nA: Most of the people who go into therapy (or similar programs) to deal with mental problems suffer from two main problems. First, they see themselves as having no control over their lives (which is why they seek help). Second, they have a hard time trusting others. Introverts don't need to trust people too much as they can handle their own affairs very well without them knowing about them, so the problem doesn't arise until people try to help.


Q: How can I tell if my friend is an introvert?\nA: A good way would be to ask him / her whether he/she likes to talk on the phone a lot or prefer talking to his/her friends over socializing at home. If they say "yes" to both of those questions, then they are probably highly sensitive.

Introverts can enjoy social events and parties, but it's different than how most people tend to experience such situations. They are generally good at
answer4:
Psychotherapy, or counseling, is the art of helping people gain a better understanding of their own thoughts and feelings by applying techniques that help to change those beliefs and behaviors. It is used in many different settings such as schools, hospitals, homes, offices, churches etc.\r

Q: What are some types of psychotherapists you can call on?\nA: There are many different kinds of psychotherapists who work with all kinds of individuals including children, adolescents, adults, families, couples and groups. Some of these psychotherapists have specific training and knowledge that enables them to provide individualized treatment but others use just general skills to treat many clients. Most of these therapists use techniques that include talking therapies (talk therapy), self-help approaches (cognitive behavioral methods) and medication management strategies (antidepressants).\r

Q: Is it true that when someone chooses to stop seeing a therapist he will never go back and start seeing another one again?\nA: No. The process of choosing not to see a therapist is an important part of psychotherapy. Not wanting to continue seeing a particular therapist does not mean that there is no more value for you in working with that particular counselor at that time or that we cannot help you. Our staff members want to ensure that you get the most out of your experience because they know that your happiness depends upon our success. As we move from session to session you will learn more about how you feel. However, it is very common during this transition period that we notice changes in you and in our relationship with you. We do everything we can to keep you involved throughout this process. That being said, once you make the decision not to see us for whatever reason (whether it be lack of interest, dissatisfaction with our results, a family emergency, financial constraints, any other factors) then our door remains open to you for reattempts.\r

Q: How often should I meet with my therapist?\nA: Once every three months is considered typical and we encourage you to maintain this schedule each month until you find your best fit within the therapeutic relationship. While we don't recommend meeting weekly, it is still good practice to keep the appointment schedule going so you are always aware of what you need to address. You also may wish to keep in touch with friends and family members who might share similar values and goals in order to give you support and encouragement.\r

As you participate in this program, you may also begin to notice that you are making progress toward reducing the levels of stress and tension in your life. This will reduce your risk of developing chronic conditions such as depression, anxiety disorder, substance abuse, etc., which can have serious negative health consequences.

query: Q: What does multiple sclerosis diagnosis include? What does it change?\nA:
answer1: Multiple sclerosis is a chronic, relapsing disease of the central nervous system. It affects the peripheral nerves and the brain. Its symptoms are often progressive and non-specific. The cause of MS is still unknown; however, genetic factors have been associated with an increased risk for developing the disease. There are three primary groups that are affected by MS: 1) People who develop the disease between ages 20 and 40; 2) people who have had the disease longer than 10 years prior to their symptoms manifesting (and who may have other underlying disorders); 3) individuals who develop MS after experiencing an event such as an injury or trauma during adolescence, young adulthood, or middle age. When you talk about multiple sclerosis, people typically think of what happens in the early stages of the disease. For example, if you experience numbness, tingling, burning, heat, weakness, or any other symptoms of MS that last more than two weeks, then your doctor will likely diagnose the condition. If this occurs, then you will usually be referred to a neurologist at a hospital or clinic where they can examine your spine and other structures using X rays or MRI scans to determine exactly what's happening inside your body. You'll also undergo tests such as MRI and CAT scan to assess how well your spinal cord controls your muscles and other organs. This is important because many times, patients do not fully recover from their MS symptoms until later on. In most cases, symptoms improve over time to allow a person with MS to move around, dress themselves, eat and drink normally, use the toilet, and communicate. But there are some situations in which MS symptoms persist for months or even years, such as those caused by spinal stenosis, tumors, infections, or damage to the optic nerve in the eye. With each new symptom you experience, we'll need to determine whether it's related to MS. One way that we might confirm a diagnosis of MS would be to perform an MRI that shows abnormalities in the parts of the brain responsible for coordinating movement. However, only about half of all people who have MS show signs or symptoms that could indicate that they've actually got the disease. Even when a patient does have symptoms that suggest MS, they're not always obvious to others and can't always be diagnosed accurately. This is why finding out if you have MS will require an ongoing investigation. Most often, your symptoms come and go over the course of a year or more but sometimes they just keep coming. And although we know that the onset of symptoms often varies from person to
answer2:
Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease. It's a collection of symptoms caused by the immune system attacking and damaging your brain cells, called myelin sheath, which surround your neurons. The body responds to this damage by producing antibodies that attack these damaged nerves in the CNS (central nervous system), called demyelinating lesions. These lesions are caused by the buildup of abnormal proteins within nerve fibers, and they can lead to loss of motor skills and vision. Because MS progresses over time and often involves progressive weakness or paralysis, you may not recognize any changes to your physical condition for several years after the onset of symptoms. At times, doctors will only notice progression from one manifestation of MS to another during a comprehensive neurologic evaluation. For example, if there are no clear changes at first, but then one day a person experiences blurred vision or slurred speech and later develops trouble speaking and swallowing, an MRI might be ordered to confirm the diagnoses. A second MRI may also be needed to determine if the worsening features have progressed into full-blown MS.

What is the cost of living with multiple sclerosis?\nA: The annual average cost of living is $15,000 for a single individual. An individual with multiple sclerosis generally spends about half their income on caregiving expenses and expenses related to transportation, food, clothing, medications, and other costs associated with living with the disease. Health insurance premiums typically account for nearly 90 percent of these expenses, while government programs such as Medicare and Medicaid cover the balance of the bill. If you're a low-income worker without health insurance, this cost increases substantially. In 2015, the median household income for individuals who did not have employer-sponsored coverage was $44,721, and the median family income was just under $90,000. People with severe chronic diseases often need special assistance from health professionals, including nurses, social workers, dietitians, physiotherapists, occupational therapists, psychologists, chiropractors, speech pathologists, etc., because of the significant financial burden associated with managing their disabilities. While having multiple sclerosis can drastically reduce an individual's earning potential, it doesn't mean that a person cannot afford to live a healthy lifestyle. Many people find ways to make work and social life possible despite limitations due to MS. If you want to learn more about how you could benefit financially from MS treatment, visit the U.S. National Multiple Sclerosis Society website or call 1-800-977-5626.

How much does it take to treat multiple sclerosis?
answer3:
Multiple sclerosis is the most common type of neurologic disease, affecting more than 1.2 million Americans. The course and severity of MS varies greatly from person to person, but there are three stages. In stage I, people with MS experience problems with balance, vision or speech. Sometimes they lose their sense of smell, taste or touch; at other times, they have severe difficulty swallowing. In stage II, a person may lose ability to move in all ways, including walking, seeing, hearing, talking or thinking clearly. At this point, people may start having problems breathing (bronchiectasis) or develop damage to nerve cells that controls muscles. Stage III includes all cases. Symptoms can range from mild to disabling. If you are diagnosed with multiple sclerosis as an adult, you will be evaluated by your physician for any symptoms you might have developed during the previous 12 months, which could indicate the onset of MS. For some people with MS, there is no need for further evaluation. People who do not receive appropriate treatment often become disabled within five years of diagnosis. Other disorders that can affect multiple sclerosis symptoms include stroke, traumatic brain injury (TBI), Alzheimer's disease or Parkinson's disease.

Eating disorders are also common. Eating disorders are characterized by recurrent episodes of binge eating, disordered eating behavior, restrictive dieting or weight loss. They typically begin before puberty and continue into adulthood. Many people with eating disorders have some level of functioning in everyday life. However, many others suffer from serious health consequences due to poor mental health and social well-being. One in five women (20 percent) report binge eating in her lifetime, compared to one in 20 men (5 percent). More than 40 percent of female adolescents (ages 15â€“19) suffer from binge eating disorder. Women are affected 2â€“3 times more frequently than men (4 percent vs 2 percent). Binge eating can lead to significant emotional distress, low self esteem, depression and anxiety disorders. About 50 percent of patients with bulimia nervosa have co-occurring eating disorders. These disorders usually begin between age 14 and 18. A survey conducted by UCLA found that about 25 percent of teenagers had been involved in a food-related activity that resulted in damage to their body. Nearly half of those surveyed said they were bullied because of their weight. Obesity can cause complications such as high blood pressure, diabetes mellitus and cardiovascular disease, as well as reduced quality of life.

How is chronic fatigue syndrome defined? CFS is a poorly understood condition.
answer4:
Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system attacks and destroys myelin, a fatty covering of nerve fibers that allows our nerves to transmit signals. The attack on myelin causes pain, loss of balance, vision problems, bladder problems, dizziness, fatigue, numbness, tingling, sensitivity to light, and paralysis. (1) 
B: What are the symptoms?
A: The typical symptom is burning sensations in and around the skin; often this occurs within the limbs. Many people also have numbness or tingling in the arms, legs, hands and feet as well as weakness, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. (2) 
C: How common is MS?
A: There was one reported case of MS during each year of childhood until 2007. In 2008 there were two reported cases. It has been estimated that there are approximately 300 million people worldwide with MS. (3) 
D: Do doctors diagnose MS by looking for lesions?
A: Doctors do not usually look for lesions but can spot other health problems associated with MS such as sensory problems, hearing loss, muscle rigidity, joint pain, depression, sleep problems, anxiety, suicidal ideation, social isolation, mood swings, and difficulty concentrating. (4) 
E: Does MS affect children differently than adults?
A: No. Children who develop MS at any age will show all the signs and symptoms listed above. However, when diagnosed before school age, children tend to make fewer changes and may be more likely to attend school normally. (5) 
F: Who develops MS first? What triggers the onset of MS?
A: Although no single cause has been identified, most studies indicate that early life factors such as genetic predisposition and environmental toxins play major roles in determining risk for developing MS later in life. (6) 
G: Can I avoid MS symptoms if I'm living a healthy lifestyle?
A: It depends on your individual response to treatment. If you're taking medication then this is unlikely to be effective because it alters brain chemistry. Even if you take an anti-inflammatory drug, your levels of inflammation and autoantibodies will continue to rise until your treatment is completed. If you have healthy blood pressure, cholesterol, thyroid function and blood sugar, you should not need treatment for MS unless you start to experience clinical symptoms such as numbness or tingling in your extremities or facial features. (7) \
answer5:
Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a neurodegenerative disease of the central nervous system. It affects approximately 5 million people worldwide and is characterized by motor neuron degeneration, resulting in weakness or paralysis on one side of your body, often affecting both arms and legs, along with cognitive difficulties such as difficulty walking, understanding speech and swallowing. MS can also affect vision and hearing. \r

The most common symptoms are muscle stiffness, fatigue, pain, loss of coordination, sleep disturbance, depression, and fatigue, which may be severe enough to prevent you from doing daily activities or cause significant functional limitations that limit your ability to perform everyday tasks. There may be other complications associated with MS that require additional treatment such as blindness or problems with movement and balance. In addition, there is currently no cure for MS. \r

You should seek medical care immediately if you experience any of these symptoms: sudden, unexplained weakness; numbness or tingling sensations; trouble seeing, including darkening of vision; hearing impairment or disability (difficulty understanding spoken language); trouble swallowing; shortness of breath (dyspnea); breathing problems, particularly when coughing; or other signs of a respiratory infection. \r

Diagnosis of MS can be complicated because many patients do not know they have MS until their condition becomes disabling and becomes life threatening. This can make early detection difficult even with rapid diagnostic testing such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).\r

There are several ways to determine whether or not you have MS. These include physical examination and laboratory tests such as a blood test for antibodies to auto-antibodies, an electrocardiogram (ECG), and a spinal tap exam. Also, you will need to provide information about medication use (including current dose, frequency of use, and duration) and use of medications you took prior to onset of symptoms. If you were diagnosed with MS within the last six months, you will likely need further evaluation by your physician. However, some individuals who have been undiagnosed for years and show very little symptom symptoms still have advanced lesions in the brain caused by MS. Diagnosing MS at this point may result in misdiagnoses. Even after this period, if there are other symptoms present, or if you have other underlying health conditions, you must continue to see your doctor until you receive a definitive diagnosis. You may need to undergo additional evaluations throughout your lifetime if new evidence emerges during this time.\r

answer6: Multiple sclerosis is a neurological disease characterized by the presence of relapsing-remitting (RR) and secondary progressive (SP) lesions. These lesions are located in the brain, spinal cord or both. In addition to these two main categories of MS, there are other types which do not meet the diagnostic criteria for either RR or SP but may be associated with them. There are also some people who have no neurologic symptoms but who develop SP lesions. A person can have one type of MS and another type at different times. For example, someone with RRMS may experience occasional episodes of disability over the course of their lifetime while someone with SP may only experience one episode of disability during that same period. \nB: This is important because many doctors will suggest one type of MS as being better than the other. Many times this can lead patients into thinking they are doing all right but it doesn't take much evidence to show that you really aren't! \nC: It's important to understand that the way we diagnose a particular kind of MS depends on which part of the body is involved. For example, the CNS has been identified as the primary site of damage in the more common forms of MS. This means that in order to determine whether your MS affects the CNS at all, your doctor should see if they get enough information from the MRI to find any abnormalities. If they don't get enough information then they may recommend further tests. The most common type of MRIs used are called diffusion tensor imaging (DTI). DTI involves taking a series of images of each part of the brain with a specially designed machine known as a T1-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). These machines detect changes in blood flow in specific parts of the brain, thereby identifying where the brain cells are damaged or injured and how the effects vary between persons. DTI measures the amount of fluid in the brain and can therefore reveal how large areas of the brain have become inflamed and distorted. Some doctors use DTI scans together with brain scans made using a technique called diffusion tensor imaging to look specifically for SP lesions. With SP lesions, it becomes clear where in the brain the affected area actually lies since they produce characteristic patterns on MRI. To identify SP lesions, SP specialist specialists use an MRI machine called a MEG and measure how much water flows through a small hole on the side of the head where the SP lesion can be seen. This allows them to distinguish between SP lesions and other kinds of MS and to make sure they're diagnosing
answer7: Multiple sclerosis diagnosis includes any one of the following:1) A report from a physician or other health professional that an individual with MS has lesions in their brain, spinal cord, and/or optic nerves2) An MRI scan of the head (with or without contrast)3) Any test for inflammation or degeneration of the brain and/or spinal cord4) Other tests, including blood work5) The results of a clinical examination by another health care provider6) In some cases, the results of all these tests may be combined into a single report7) A patient's self-report8) A person who is not a health care provider9) In rare instances, the symptoms may cause confusion.10) If you have had multiple sclerosis, your doctor can provide more information about this condition. For example, your doctor may recommend further testing or surgery if your symptoms continue to get worse and are not improving within 4 weeks.11) You should contact your insurance company for specific information regarding your coverage.12) Your insurance will cover certain costs related to treating MS as long as the benefits exceed $50,000 per year.13) Medicare Part D covers both MS treatment and other treatments for people aged 55 years or older.14) The National Institutes of Health offers several different funds for funding research on MS.15) Many federal agencies offer support for medical research on multiple sclerosis, including the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP), Food and Drug Administration (FDA), and National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA).16) Some states also offer Medicaid programs for people with MS.17) All of these government funds pay for testing, procedures, medications, and services.18) Private insurers may reimburse you for treatment with MS drugs or devices when they're purchased through a private insurer under their reimbursement policies.19) Medication prices often vary greatly among insurance companies.20) Many patients find out about effective therapies only after trying them.21) Because your insurance company won't cover the cost of many MS treatments, some health care providers provide free or low-cost MS screening and testing for their own patients at no charge.22) The CDC recommends getting a second opinion before making major life changes like starting a new job or having children.23) People who develop a second disease after a first severe neurologic disease experience high rates of relapse.24) There is little evidence that taking medication
answer8: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a chronic neurological condition affecting the central nervous system. It affects about one in eight adults worldwide and about 400,000 Americans. The disease typically begins during childhood or adolescence and tends to strike younger individuals than those who have other diseases. It causes the death of nerve cells that control muscle movement, sensation, vision, and hearing. MS also affects women more often than men, and those with less severe symptoms tend not to seek treatment as aggressively. While many forms of MS affect similar areas on the brain, the most common form has affected around 50 million people worldwide over the past 30 years and is estimated to affect one-third of all U.S. patients between the ages of 40 and 60, according to the National Institutes of Health (NIH). In this disease, the immune system attacks and destroys myelin sheaths â€” protective fatty tissue covering axons in neurons (nerve fibers). Myelination helps enable nerves to send messages through their circuits; without myelination, signals cannot be transmitted properly. By removing damaged myelin, MS destroys communication channels and sends the message "we don't need you anymore." Without myelinated tracts, the part of the spinal cord where muscles, sensory nerves, and the brain are located can no longer transmit information to the rest of the body. Thus, there is loss of strength and mobility of vital organs. For example, muscle weakness may result from difficulty breathing because of a lack of oxygen to the brain. These symptoms can become debilitating and even life threatening. Some research suggests that MS could someday develop into a progressive disorder. However, for now, the best way to manage symptoms is by taking medication called an anticoagulant, which lowers the level of blood clots in the arteries that supply the heart. This reduces blood pressure and improves circulation. Other medications, including antihistamines (drugs to treat allergic reactions), anti-seizure drugs (drugs used to prevent seizures when they occur), and steroids, target inflammation. Together these medications help regulate cell function, reduce pain, and protect the body's own tissues from damage. Although some symptoms of MS can improve after treatment, others never go away. That means MS affects a person's daily ability to perform everyday tasks such as walking, climbing stairs, talking, eating, bathing, dressing, etc. Many people with MS suffer extreme fatigue, headaches, depression, confusion, memory problems, trouble concentrating, sleep disturbances, abnormal bowel movements, nausea, dizziness, tremors, tingling sensations
answer9: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic neurological disease characterized by the presence of signs and symptoms including weakness, loss of mobility, and numbness or tingling sensations. MS affects approximately 1 in 100 adults throughout their lives, with an average age at onset of 55 years old. The vast majority (90%) of people diagnosed with MS are women; however men can develop the condition as well, especially after 30 years of age. Most cases of MS are preceded by an abnormally slow brain growth that causes a buildup of scar tissue. This leads to progressive damage over time, eventually leading to the formation of a lesion known as an active lesions. After this lesion forms, nerve fibers start to deteriorate, resulting in loss of function and sensory input from the affected area. MS also leads to disability because of severe muscle spasms and other symptoms. There are three types of MS: relapsing-remitting, secondary, and primary (primary is when there is no clear cause for the initial attack). Relapsing-remitting MS is marked by recurring attacks of fatigue that last several days to weeks. These may be preceded by a period where activity levels are low but then increase gradually. During these periods of increased activity, nerve cells become damaged as they try to repair themselves. Typically, relapses occur every 2 to 8 months, although they can happen more frequently if the immune system starts attacking healthy nerve cells. Secondary MS occurs in patients who have had an early relapse and whose symptoms continue to worsen. Primary MS is characterized by recurrent, often disabling attacks that begin suddenly and persist even with treatment. People with primary MS do not experience debilitating bouts of fatigue and typically recover fully within 5 to 10 years of diagnosis. Some people will need to take medication for life to control symptoms (regimen), while others will live full lives without any disability. A person's risk for developing secondary MS increases significantly during adolescence and young adulthood, which explains why so many people with MS end up living with the disease into later life. In addition, some people are born with autoimmune diseases such as type 1 diabetes, celiac disease, lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, psoriasis, Hashimoto thyroiditis, and scleroderma, among others. For example, people with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) are twice as likely to get MS. While IBD itself does not directly contribute to MS, some studies suggest that certain foods may trigger MS
answer10:
Multiple sclerosis is a neurological disease in which the immune system attacks and destroys the brain, spinal cord, optic nerve (eye) and other parts of the central nervous system. It also affects many of your muscles, joints and skin. The damage caused by MS can be permanent if untreated. Treatment focuses on relieving pain and controlling symptoms. Some people are cured with drugs such as interferon-alpha and glatiramer acetate. Others live with their disability for years. A person may have multiple conditions at one time. These include: inflammation in the brain

spinal cord compression causing paralysis or even death

muscle spasms resulting from muscle degeneration

inflammation in the blood vessels that supply the brain and nerves

blood clots, which cause more problems when they break off and travel to the lungs or heart

damage to the nerves surrounding the eyes called retinitis pigmentosa, which causes vision loss The most important thing for you to know about multiple sclerosis is that you do not need to worry about having it any time soon. There's no cure available yet; however, advances in treatment make it less likely that you will develop MS. In some cases, treatments help slow down the progression of MS. If you have been diagnosed with multiple sclerosis, it's best to talk with your doctor about what kind of treatment works best for you. You'll find information about MS treatment options in Your Health Care Guide.

query: Q: How to manage multiple sclerosis?\nA:
answer1:
You can do it. The best way is through the use of medications and lifestyle changes. In my experience, the most effective method of managing MS is an annual physical exam, which helps you track down any conditions that might be contributing to symptoms or cause problems. It's also important to remember that there are many factors that go into how a person with MS feels â€” like whether or not they've been exposed to chemicals in their environment or their food, for example, which could make them more sensitive to nerve damage or lead to other neurological issues. And while some treatments work well for certain people who have MS, others don't. So talk to your doctor about which ones work best for you.

Brett McKay: That sounds great. I'll put this together and see if I'm on time today. Yeah, I want to ask one more question before we wrap up, too, and it comes from Dr. Thomas D. Smith, MD. He says, "I'm having trouble making sense of the word 'chronic.' Does chronic mean something like long term?" If so, then what does the definition of chronic mean here?

Dr. Daniel Lieberman: I think a lot of people have heard that phrase because they hear it used when talking about people who smoke cigarettes, but it means different things depending on the context. One context is that it refers to someone whose condition has lasted for at least a year, and that's very specific as far as the disease goes. We're talking about chronic pain and arthritis and neuropathic pain â€” all these kinds of chronic diseases. Chronic often means longer than a year, though, and I would consider that just another way of saying prolonged. That doesn't necessarily mean you had MS for years or decades. Someone who has been diagnosed with MS will typically have it for a lifetime, whereas someone without MS may only have had symptoms for years or even decades. This is why MS is called the second oldest known disease in humans.

You could say that chronic pain and arthritis have been around longer, but they have different causes. They're not caused by the same thing. For instance, back pain can get worse over time, which leads to inflammation; this causes pain. But chronic pain is usually a result of stress, and it is largely genetic. Some of us inherit the gene for chronic pain, and some of us just haven't been able to learn to cope with stress properly yet. There are various theories of why we carry some genes for chronic pain, and we know that people

answer3:
My experience with MS is that the more you use it, the better. There are ways of managing your symptoms and you will need them. A number of drugs can be used. They include drugs that target inflammation in the brain and spinal cord, such as riluzole or methotrexate; those that affect metabolism in the central nervous system (CNS), including carbamazepine, phenytoin and others; and those that treat glial cells that support the immune system, which includes cyclosporine, lamotrigine, cyclophosphamide, cycloserine and others.

What I have done for MS is to keep my body healthy by taking a variety of vitamins, minerals, herbs and other supplements. I also do some massage therapy at home. For example, if I feel pain on one side of the neck, I massage that area twice daily until I don't get any tenderness. The muscles relax then tighten up again over time. That helps reduce the swelling. But there are several different forms of massage that work best for me â€” manual, electrical and acupressure (a type of traction). You should talk to your physician about the kind that works best for you.

I am very diligent about eating right and exercising regularly. I avoid hot baths, saunas and steam rooms because they can worsen the symptoms and increase the risk of infection. However, people who suffer from multiple sclerosis often report benefits from deep-tissue massage. As long as we learn how to control our bodies properly through diet, exercise and vitamin supplementation, there is no reason why people cannot live life as normally as possible while still having their needs met.
answer4:
You can't control MS. But you can take steps that will help.

MS is a disease of the brain and spinal cord, and each person has his or her own individual risk factors for developing it. The most important way to prevent MS is to maintain a healthy weight by eating right, exercising regularly, taking medicines as prescribed and avoiding tobacco use.
answer5:
You'll have a good time, but it is not easy. For example, you need to be aware of your symptoms and make sure they are in balance with other things that can impact the condition; for instance, eating well and taking your medication regularly. If you're able to get by without all this, life will go on as normal.

Q: What about the future?\nA: Your diagnosis means there's nothing left to do but wait until people who know better start telling you what to do. The prognosis for MS varies considerably depending on when you were diagnosed, so the sooner you begin treatment, the better chances you will have. However, as long as you continue to take your medicine you should be fine.
answer6:
I have two questions for you about managing MS. First, what is the process of managing Multiple Sclerosis and how can it be improved? Second, if you were able to make a living from MS once, what would your business model or other options be now that you are no longer able to work? Thanks!

A: Hi Michelle. MS affects my right side so it's hard to keep up with all aspects of business; however, I am trying to focus on building my online store as well as working with some small companies. As far as jobs go, in order to get my job back I'm going to need a new application for every position. So, there will definitely be a big adjustment for me in terms of employment but things do look good. It really does depend on your industry though. Most positions available at most large firms require a degree in something that can't be easily replaced by software. In addition, many people with MS have a full time job at home or in another field where they aren't taking care of their health. When I was diagnosed (in 2009) I knew very little about MS and didn't know how to market myself or prepare for work. It took several years before I started talking with others about my situation (I had an MS support group back then). I think it's best if you talk to others who've been through similar situations because you may find that you're not alone in your struggles. Good luck!

Q: I have three questions for you about MS - first off, What is the history of MS and who is affected? How long has this disease existed? How does the illness progress from mild to severe symptoms? Lastly, why is it still such a mystery?

A: Thank you for taking the time to read our blog. MS is not an "old" disease like polio, or HIV. This condition was discovered over 100 years ago when Dr John Hunter discovered a protein that caused lesions to form around nerve cells in his patients' brains. Since then we've learned more and more about how the disease progresses over time. The reason the virus causes such devastating disease today is because of its ability to escape from immune system cells known as T-cells which are responsible for controlling infection. There is currently no cure for MS. Once a person develops symptoms, the entire body becomes infected. Treatment consists of medication to control the inflammation and prevent further damage to the brain and nervous system. The cause of MS is unknown so doctors treat everyone differently; there isn't one way
answer7:
My treatment plan includes immunotherapy. I get all the injections and follow-up visits at a clinic in Toronto that specializes in treating MS patients.\NI know how hard it is to find doctors who understand your condition, but with the help of my own neurologist, I have been able to gain independence as well as better control of symptoms.

Q: What's your approach when you're not feeling well? Do you take medication or herbal supplements?\ nA: No medications are necessary for me when I am not getting much sleep or eating very well. If I can't feel good right away, I ask myself, "Is this due to stress?" I try to be sure that I eat lots of fresh fruit and vegetables before bed. And if I'm unable to feel well later on during the day, then I make more time for exercise and rest. I also try to keep busy by working out regularly. It takes a lot of energy for me to move around so I make sure I stay active before going back to bed.


Q: You've said your life has changed significantly since you were diagnosed. What do you miss most about old days?\ nA: The flexibility to work whenever I want without having to worry about being locked into any job. I was never forced to choose between work and family commitments â€“ I could always choose both!

And when I don't feel like doing anything, I just lie on my back in the bathtub while listening to some relaxing music or playing a video game. There aren't many things I enjoy doing more than spending quality time with my family. I love making sure they have an amazing holiday season because that is something no one should ever experience alone. I spend Christmas dinner together every year with my parents, aunties, cousins and friends and it feels like we really share our lives together.

My husband and children also enjoy seeing their mommy taking care of us. We have a special bond that goes beyond physical relationships. It makes each day easier.


Q: What advice would you give someone living with MS?\ nA: As long as I remain healthy, I believe I will continue to progress in whatever area I decide to focus on. One thing I learned early on is that you cannot force yourself to live a certain lifestyle, but rather learn how to adjust your health and lifestyle habits according to what works best for you. With this knowledge in mind, I hope to lead a healthier lifestyle even though I am aware that this may affect my
answer8:
There are no specific "disease-management" protocols for MS; however, lifestyle changes and medication can help people live more fully with the disease. People who have MS should try to get at least 30 minutes of exercise most days, especially early in the day and after meals when the circulation is slowest. This will benefit their circulatory system and other organs as well. In addition, they should avoid heavy alcohol use and tobacco use, which increase the risk of developing MS.

A person may be diagnosed with MS only if there is a positive test result for an abnormal immune response called autoimmunity (see below). The initial screening tests used by doctors include:

The results of these tests come back quickly. It usually takes about 2 weeks from diagnosis to confirm that it's MS. If you have had symptoms or signs of MS before you were first tested and have recently been diagnosed, see your doctor again. Also call your doctor right away if you develop new problems such as weakness, pain or numbness in your arms or legs. These could mean you have another condition. You may need more tests.

How do I know if my body has the "autoimmune" reaction to my own proteins?

Doctors don't understand exactly what causes this reaction, but scientists believe they might involve a protein called interleukin 1 beta (IL1B) released by white blood cells in the body. IL1B has many different functions, including helping our bodies fight infection, fighting cancer, protecting against infections that can cause severe damage, and keeping inflammation under control. Scientists now think that some people with MS react to their own proteins because their immune systems attack them, creating inflammation. For example, scientists believe that IL1B plays a role in causing arthritis in some people with MS. However, some studies suggest that having high levels of IL1B doesn't necessarily lead to MS. Doctors aren't sure why some people don't react to their own proteins and others do. Some experts think that this type of autoimmune reaction occurs less often than people realize because most people with MS experience only short periods of severe illness during their lives.

Some research suggests that children and young adults with MS have a higher chance of developing MS as adolescents or young adulthood than children without MS. Scientists also think that older people who develop MS may have a greater risk of developing chronic illnesses later in life because their bodies are weakened, making them more vulnerable to infections and viruses. Other researchers suspect that the underlying cause of MS may change over
answer9:
In my opinion, if you have MS and are not actively using medications or other therapies for your disease, then you should consider switching from the traditional pharmaceutical treatment of TNF inhibitors. If you want to try something new that may be more effective than existing treatments, you might benefit from trying a natural alternative such as turmeric (Curcuma longa).\N

Q: What is the best way to protect oneself against MS/TENSI?\nA: Although there are no proven studies that show any specific ways to prevent MS, I think it's important to recognize that it is very difficult to avoid the risk factors associated with MS by simply avoiding certain foods and behaviors that can trigger an immune response in susceptible individuals. For those who choose to take medication, I would recommend taking a low-dose version of the TNF inhibitor called diclofenac sodium (Voltaren), which only requires one tablet per day in addition to your standard multivitamins. One of the first steps toward managing MS is learning what triggers the symptoms of MS and how these triggers differ depending on the person's race, gender, and age. Taking care of yourself through diet and lifestyle changes will play a large role in helping you feel better during this time. There also is some evidence suggesting that dietary supplements can help reduce the inflammatory process when taken together with regular exercise, but further research needs to be done before we know whether or not this holds true.

Q: Can MS be reversed or mitigated by dietary measures alone?\nA: Yes. There is some evidence showing that eating more fiber, fruits, vegetables, whole grains, healthy fats, omega-3 fatty acids, and probiotics has been shown to improve the quality of life in people with MS.[7] I would recommend doing everything possible to incorporate these into your diet as well as to increase your intake of beneficial bacteria, which could be found naturally in yogurt or fermented foods. This means consuming probiotic products in addition to following a balanced diet, since both provide you with essential nutrients such as live bacteria. Many patients report that taking probiotics along with their medication actually helps to minimize side effects and reduce inflammation, so this idea of combining probiotic products with drugs is definitely worth exploring!\r
