Q: What causes multiple sclerosis? A: Multiple sclerosis is a disease characterized by the body's inability to properly repair and maintain its own tissues. This leads to damage to nerves in your brain, spinal cord, and elsewhere in the body. Q: How do I know if I have MS? A: It depends on how you define it. "MS" refers to any of several types of inflammatory demyelinating diseases (ISDs), including relapsing-remitting MS (RRMS) and secondary progressive MS. However, there isn't one definition for all people with MS; they may be diagnosed based on an MRI or other diagnostic technique. Most people with MS experience at least some of these symptoms: fatigue

dizziness or lightheadedness

restlessness

headache

mild weakness

muscle pain

sore throat or sore gums

slight loss of coordination, balance, muscle tone, or reflexes

loss of bladder control or bowel function

problems speaking

difficulty swallowing

changes in vision

blurred vision

a change in sense of smell

unusual sweating or skin color (usually paler than usual)

lack of sleep The list above only includes some examples of many possible signs and symptoms that can occur as part of MS, so ask about yours. If you feel like you've experienced any of the above signs and symptoms while living with MS, discuss them with your health care provider. It's important to note that you should never stop taking medication because of a single symptom. Your doctor will need to assess whether medications you're taking are helping you manage your symptoms. If you continue to experience worsening symptoms after your current treatment has been exhausted, talk to your healthcare provider about switching to another type of therapy.

Treatment options for multiple sclerosis Treatment options for MS range from drug therapies to lifestyle changes such as exercise or nutrition. Some drugs used to treat MS can also help improve symptoms in those who don't have MS but who might benefit from them. For example, oral steroids may reduce inflammation, numbness, tingling, spasms, and stiffness associated with MS. They may also increase mobility in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Antibiotics and immune system boosting medicines are often prescribed as well. These treatments affect immune cells that play a role in causing MS. Antibiotic drugs may help prevent infection when treating patients

D: More than one symptom. E: Not sure. Q: What does the term fibromyalgia mean? A: The word "fibroma" comes from the Latin "fibra," meaning muscle, and the Greek "myalgia," which means pain. It has also been used to describe an illness characterized by widespread musculoskeletal complaints, such as muscle cramps or chronic joint inflammation. It was first described by Dr. James Ritvo, who is credited with developing the disease's name. In recent years, it's become a popular diagnosis among many patients because they often have fatigue, pain and sleep disturbances similar to those associated with MS.

Q: How do I know if my MS is caused by MS? A: You're more likely to develop MS if you have a family history of it; if your health problems are related to being overweight, obese or on antidepressants; if you've had any kind of stroke or trauma (such as accident or war); or if you've recently had chemotherapy or radiation treatment. Certain genetic mutations also increase your risk. But even if you don't have these conditions, having the same genes doesn't necessarily guarantee that you will get MS. About 20 percent of all adults over age 50 have MS at some point. Some people who don't normally have MS have milder symptoms than others. And some people have severe symptoms only after they start getting older. Many factors contribute to how severe your symptoms are â€” whether you suffer from fatigue, pain or shortness of breath. Your doctor will work with you to find out what's causing them and figure out what treatments might help you.

Q: What causes multiple sclerosis? A: Scientists don't fully understand why MS occurs, although they believe most cases involve damage to nerve cells in the central nervous system (CNS). There aren't any specific triggers for MS. However, certain factors may increase your risk of the disease. These include: smoking; exposure to toxins such as lead or asbestos; excessive alcohol use; ultraviolet light, including solar UV rays (from sun-lamps and tanning beds) and artificial lighting; infections in childhood or adulthood; infections during pregnancy; exposure to viruses and bacteria; having inherited blood clotting disorders; and diabetes. People with diabetes may also face additional risks from their body
answer10: Symptoms that are associated with MS.Q: What is multiple sclerosis?A: Multiple sclerosis is a progressive disease which affects the central nervous system (CNS) and causes disability. It can affect any part of your body, including the arms, legs or eyes. People who have MS may also experience other problems, such as vision changes, muscle weakness, hearing loss, tremors and seizures.Q: How many people in the United States have MS?A: More than 4 million Americans have MS. It's the most common neurological disorder diagnosed among adults over 50 years old. Nearly half of all adults with MS will develop it by age 65, compared to about one-third who get it before they turn 50. This means that nearly 1 out of every 5 adults with MS will be alive during their lifetime. Q: How does MS spread?A: The main way MS spreads is through the bloodstream when infected cells trigger inflammation in the brain and spinal cord. Because MS is so rare and hard to diagnose, there is currently no cure for it. But it can be managed with medication and physical therapy. There is no evidence that MS is transmitted by blood transfusion, but experts say the risk increases if you are at high risk for certain infectious diseases or have had previous infections that can cause serious complications.Q: Are there drugs that treat MS?A: Scientists continue to search for new treatments. There are two medications that have been proven effective against symptoms of MS -- interferon beta and glatiramer acetate (Glatiramer). They work together in an important way -- each drug triggers the release of proteins called "interleukin" from white blood cells. These proteins help block immune responses to MS symptoms.Q: Is it possible to become disabled from having MS?A: Yes. In fact, researchers have found that 30 percent of people with MS are unable to carry out some activities without help. Other research indicates that up to 40 percent of people with MS will lose use of an arm or leg because their muscles don't hold enough force. While it isn't clear whether this happens due to poor control of MS symptoms or underlying health conditions, it can make daily life more difficult.Q: Do I need to see my doctor if I want treatment for MS?A: If you're thinking about trying to stop or slow down the progression of MS or other conditions, talk to your primary care physician or neurologist. Your doctor will answer questions about how much MS treatment might be right for you. They'll also offer

query: Q: Is the Covid-19 vaccine safe for people taking multiple sclerosis drugs?\nA:
answer1:
Yes, it is safe. There are some minor risks associated with using any medication that affects the nervous system, but these drugs should not have a major effect on your ability to think clearly or make decisions, and there are no known cases of death from an adverse reaction to the vaccine, although this could be caused by other factors such as infections in the weeks after vaccination.

Q: What kind of research was conducted before vaccines were developed?\nA: For over 100 years scientists had been investigating the possibility of making a better way of giving polio vaccines, but their attempts were stymied by one problem - how do you prevent children from getting sick so they won't spread the disease? In the 1920s doctors started looking at ways of preventing children contracting the virus. Some used chemicals called "attenuation" which prevented the body's immune system from attacking polio strains when administered to susceptible children. This worked well until the 1950s when polio immunization became widely available thanks to the success of British scientist Maurice Hilleman who discovered a new method of delivering live viruses into the small intestine through a mucosal surface (called enema). From then onwards it has been relatively easy to develop and produce vaccines against different diseases using this technique.

In recent decades, however, researchers found the development of vaccines was becoming more difficult. By the 1970s it became clear that poliovirus could survive in the intestinal tract indefinitely without being killed off by the host's immune system, even if given intravenously. Scientists began researching alternative methods to deliver vaccines and eventually settled upon a two-step process whereby a weakened form of poliovirus would be injected into the bloodstream followed by a series of injections into lymph nodes. The idea is that the lymph nodes will filter out weakened polioviruses which are unable to infect humans and the blood supply will carry them to the brain where they can cause paralysis (although no deaths have ever been reported following the use of vaccines containing the modified oral strain of poliovirus). However, it wasn't until 1996 that the first successful human trial of the oral version of the polio vaccine was carried out using a combination of three different strains of the virus. Despite these successes it was not until 2004 that the first licensed vaccine was approved by the World Health Organization (WHO) for the prevention of acute flaccid paralysis, which is caused by a variant of the virus called OPV (oral poliovirus type 1). As well as helping eradicate polio globally polio remains endemic in many parts of the world, particularly in Africa where
answer2:
The primary benefit of the CVSV-19 vaccination is to protect against the rabies virus. However, because other vaccines may be administered in addition to the CVSV-19 vaccine (e.g., hepatitis B, hepatitis A and/or Haemophilus influenzae type b [Hib] seronegative), it is not always possible to determine which vaccine has been given as a part of a combined regimen with additional therapies. If you are receiving multiple sclerosis medications that include daclizumab, valganciclovir or famciclovir, please contact your doctor prior to administration of the CVSV-19 vaccine.

Q: What should I do if my child receives the CVSV-19 vaccine but develops an adverse reaction after immunization?

A: In most cases, the vaccine will cause only mild reactions within 3 months of vaccination. There have also been reports of severe reactions such as encephalitis following vaccinations, so families should monitor their children's health closely during this time. Parents should report all adverse events to CDC by calling 1-800-CDC-INFO, visiting www.cdc.gov/vaccines/adverseevents.htm or reporting on the VAERS website at www.vaers.hhs.gov/.

Q: How long does the vaccine stay in the body?

The vaccine can remain in the body up to 4 weeks. It is important to note that some people develop a temporary soreness or rash on their skin at the site where they were vaccinated. This is called an erythema migrans. Other symptoms may occur, including fever, muscle aches, headache and backache. Please see the Vaccine Safety Information provided above for more information about the vaccine.

Q: Will there be a vaccine shortage?

Yes, vaccine supplies have become limited. Therefore, manufacturers are now producing new batches of these products. Because the production schedule is unpredictable, there could be shortages in the future. Some vaccine manufacturers have already begun issuing recall notices for unopened lots of these vaccines. Please read any FDA vaccine alert regarding a vaccine shortage or recall.

Since the drug combination has not been tested on its own merits, there is no way to know if or how these serious complications may be related directly to the vaccine.

Cancer Vaccines for People Taking Multiple Sclerosis Drugs

Vaccination against cancer is now recommended by most medical organizations and governments worldwide. However, vaccination against leukemia/lymphoma (LAM) remains only a recommendation. The CDC does not recommend any additional vaccines specifically targeted at LAM since there are no clinical trials looking into their safety and effectiveness. Because LAM is so rare and so difficult to diagnose, many patients will need to undergo more than one or two vaccines before being diagnosed with LAM, which can lead to immunodeficiency. Therefore, in order to maximize patient safety and minimize costs, it makes sense to start vaccinating people at an early age in order to reduce the risk of developing cancer later on.

Some vaccines that are recommended for adults, such as MMR, also protect against LAM. These vaccines contain live viral components, but they don't cause disease when given to children or adults. They are designed to stimulate immune responses in childhood and young adulthood, similar to the response needed to fight off a common cold.

For example, the Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine contains the bacterium pneumococcus, which causes pneumonia and sepsis, both of which are symptoms of LAM. In addition, the tetanus toxoid vaccine stimulates immunity against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis â€” three bacterial infections that are associated with LAM.

There are currently about 100 different types of LAM, including the following:

Primary Lymphocytic Leukemia â€“ also known as acute myelogenous leukemia (AMS), this type usually appears between ages 5 and 40 years. It's extremely aggressive, often producing large tumors on bone marrow biopsy. About 1 out of every 3,000 cases is fatal. Most AMS occurs in children under 15 years of age.

Secondary Myelofibrosis â€“ A form of LAM that typically occurs after childhood. Secondary leukemias affect blood cells throughout the

Q: I have been told by my neurologist and others that I need to be on an anti-seizure drug (Valproate). Can this happen if I get vaccinated against influenza?A: If you are taking certain types of anti-seizure medications, such as carbamazepine (Tegretol) or phenytoin (Dilantin), then yes, it is possible that you could develop seizures after vaccination. Other medications may also interfere with the immune system response to vaccines. It is important to discuss your medical condition with your physician before making any changes in your treatment plan. The flu shots do not contain any ingredients that have the potential to interact with your treatment regimen. They include latex, gelatin, egg protein, milk proteins, chicken eggs, sodium chloride, citric acid, dextrose, and wheat germ agglutinin (WGA) (not found in the human vaccine).

Q: Should I be worried about the presence of aluminum and other heavy metals in the Flu Shot?

A: Aluminum and many other contaminants from the vaccine have already left the body within several weeks following vaccination, so there should be no concern about ingesting them while receiving the vaccine. Some of these contaminants, such as mercury and formaldehyde, can cause adverse effects when they accumulate in the body over time. However, there are very low levels of contaminant exposure that would increase the risk of serious harm in adults who receive the flu shot. There was one case reported in 2001 of a child whose mother developed meningitis after receiving the flu shot; however, this was linked to her use of alcohol to help quell fever during the day and her breastfeeding. In addition, the most common side effect associated with the flu shot is soreness at injection sites caused by a thin needle. This occurs because the blood vessels in the area contract too quickly and dilate too rapidly. Most patients experience mild swelling and redness lasting up to 7 days following vaccination. After this period, skin will return to its normal coloration. For children, the maximum amount of time for symptoms to appear is 3 weeks. Although some patients may show signs of a reaction within hours, it usually takes 2 to 4 days to confirm a reaction. As with most medicines, there is a small chance that the flu vaccine

Q: Are there any risks associated with this vaccine?\nA: There are no known serious side effects from the routine vaccination of persons with MS or from immunization of pregnant women, infants, or young children with this vaccine.

Q: How do I get a copy of the Vaccine Information Statement (VIS)?\nA: The VIS is available on our website or by calling 1-800-CDC-INFO. You may also go to your local office of health services and ask them how to obtain the VIS. If you would like more information about vaccines, visit http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/.

About MMR Vaccine\nA: The measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine is recommended for all persons 11 years of age and older who have not had one dose of measles-containing vaccine. Persons 7 through 9 years of age should receive 2 doses, while those 10 through 12 years of age should receive 1 dose. After school entry, all children born since January 1, 1991, can be vaccinated against measles if they meet CDC-recommended criteria. Measles can cause severe encephalitis (convulsions), including encephalomyelitis (inflammation of the brain). Symptoms include fever, headache, sore throat, runny nose, conjunctivitis (red eyes), muscle aches and pains, myalgia (muscle pain), and coma.

For additional questions regarding MMR vaccine, please call 1-800-232-4636. To request a list of products containing live attenuated measles virus, contact Merck's Product Sales Office at 800-448-0383 or email mrmedv@merck.com.

Q: How long is it taken to complete the full course of treatment (inpatient or outpatient)? \nA: Treatment should be completed within 2 years.

Are there any other side effects associated with flu shots, such as fever, headache, muscle aches or soreness?

Yes, some people experience flu symptoms after getting a flu shot. These can include fever, muscle aches, runny nose and cough. In rare cases, these may last for several days. You may also experience a mild rash around your injection site, which usually disappears shortly after the shot.

You're more likely to get an allergic reaction if you've got a cold during your visit to the doctor's office. If this happens, you need to tell the receptionist about it immediately before having your flu vaccination appointment so that they know how to treat your allergy. This includes telling them whether you've had a cold in the past or if you recently travelled outside of Canada. They'll then take appropriate measures to help manage your condition and prevent future allergies. For example, you might be prescribed medication to reduce the frequency or severity of your symptoms.


If you'd like to ask more questions about how your immunization works or what complications can occur please call Health Link at 1-866-294-8100.

Dr. Bruce A. Davis, M.D., Chief Medical Officer of ImmunoVec Inc. (www.immunovec.com), a company specializing in vaccines and immunotherapies for multiple sclerosis, said, "It's absolutely ludicrous to make such claims." He added, "The safety and effectiveness of any drug depends on several factors, including dosage, frequency, duration, timing and mode of administration. We do have some evidence that suggests the administration of corticosteroids may delay progression of MS disease." Dr. David H. Schoenbaum, Chairman Emeritus, Division of Neurology at Mount Sinai School of Medicine, New York City, agreed, stating, "There are many ways to induce an immune response, which can be accomplished with different preparations, such as vaccination, injections, infusions, or topical application. Vaccination generally induces a more robust immune response than other methods of inducing an immune response." He continued, "The question is whether it has a direct effect on the disease process itself, which could potentially be beneficial, or whether it does nothing useful except delay the appearance of symptoms. There is very little data available in humans regarding this issue because there haven't been enough trials. One trial did show a benefit from vaccination, but there were no placebo controls or long-term followup studies." Dr. John Clements, M.D., Professor of Pediatrics and Head of Pediatric Allergy/Immunology at the University of Calgary College of Family Physicians, Alberta, Canada, also expressed concern about the use of the term 'vaccine' in the marketing of the anti-MS vaccine. He stated that although he had seen evidence of efficacy of steroids in patients with MS, and was concerned by the potential adverse effects of cortisone, he believed that steroids would be too aggressive a treatment for adults with MS. He noted that if steroids do help slow down or stop disease progression, they must work slowly because they only control symptom flares, not the underlying brain damage caused by the inflammatory phase of MS. Therefore, steroids alone would probably be ineffective for slowing the progress of the disease. Dr. Clements concluded, "I am against using steroids on MS patients unless they are given through intravenous infusion."

Q: How should I store my flu shot?\nA: Flu shots can remain in their original carton in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks, after which time they must be refrigerated. It is possible to get the same level of protection by getting two flu vaccinesâ€”one with one type of virus and one with another type. You'll need two doses of each vaccine.

If you do keep the vaccine in its original carton, it should be handled carefully so as to avoid injury. Keep it out of direct sunlight. query: Q: How do menopause symptoms relate to multiple sclerosis symptoms?\nA:
answer1:
Menopausal symptoms are associated with the onset of MS as women age. Women who become symptomatic during the menopause may have a greater risk for developing MS in later life. The incidence of MS is not known; however, because women are at an increased risk of MS than men, MS and other autoimmune diseases (such as lupus) that affect the joints may be more common among women who become ill in late middle age or early old age. For example, MS occurs significantly more often in young women. This makes sense considering the fact that it is thought that MS develops from inflammation in the body's own immune system, which becomes chronic when cells begin to die off. Although the cause remains unknown, it seems likely that MS affects some aspects of the brain in men and women differently.

Q: What causes premenstrual syndrome?\nA: Premenstrual syndrome (PMS), also called pre-menstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD), is commonly referred to as "the menses blues," but has many different meanings depending on what you mean by it. In most cases, PMS is defined as a period between menstruation and ovulation. While there may be several reasons why a woman may experience this phenomenon, its most recognized symptom is mood swings such as sadness, irritability, anger and depression. It can last up to two weeks per cycle. Other symptoms include headaches, breast tenderness, fatigue, abdominal pain, bloating, and vaginal discharge. If left untreated, PMS can lead to anxiety, depression, eating disorders, substance abuse, menstrual problems, infertility, premenstrual fatigue, loss of sex drive, changes in appetite, decreased interest in work or school, and weight gain. Although these symptoms generally improve after stopping treatment with certain medications used to treat PMS, they should always be checked out if your doctor suspects that you might be experiencing one of them. As far as how these symptoms relate to MS, it is unclear exactly how and why they develop. However, as we move closer to understanding the mechanism of how MS starts, scientists will be able to figure out how and why these conditions happen so quickly and then stop. For now, researchers believe that the reason why people are affected by both PMS and MS may involve hormones released from the endometrium. There is evidence suggesting that the hormones melatonin and estrogen play important roles in regulating the function of the brain and nervous system. Research suggests that melatonin helps regulate the production of serotonin, while estrogen helps
answer2:
Menopausal disorders have been associated with an increased risk of developing MS. These include hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD), premature menopause, osteoporosis and other health conditions that cause loss of bone mass.

In the study, which was published online in May 2008 in The Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery & Psychiatry, researchers found a significant increase in the number of women with MS who also had symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome after they underwent surgery for a hysterectomy. They also examined three different groups -- those who reported having MS before surgery and those whose symptoms were not yet diagnosed -- and found that about one-third of all women undergoing this type of surgery experienced some kind of chronic illness before their operation.

"We see very similar patterns between what we call 'preoperatively' MS and postoperative MS," said Dr. David A. Spence, chief of neuroendocrinology at the Mayo Clinic. "And it's because these women are exposed to a lot of stress during the time before their surgeries. So if you look at the menstrual cycle as well, you can predict pretty accurately whether someone has MS."

The scientists noted that many factors could account for the link between MS and menstruation and the menstrual cycle. For example, people with MS may have impaired immune function or hormone balance that affects how much estrogen is produced during the month. In addition, there is evidence that estrogen levels are related to pain.

It may be that some women with MS who suffer from both premenstrual exacerbations and premenstrual syndrome also experience a flare up of the disease when they begin their period again. However, the researchers noted that more research is needed to determine what specific impact this might have on MS.

Dr. George Klenk, professor emeritus of obstetrics/gynecology at Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, agrees that the findings have important implications for doctors treating both women and men with MS.

"Menstruating women are often told by their doctor or nurse that they must take care not to use products containing estrogen, such as tampons, because estrogen could trigger a relapse of the disease," he said. "But these same precautions seem unlikely to protect menopausal women against a recurrence of their own medical condition."
answer3: Multiple sclerosis (MS) affects the central nervous system, causing lesions in myelin sheaths and nerve fibers. It is a chronic, relapsing disorder that affects women over the age of 50. A number of MS patients have been diagnosed with a form of early-onset MS called primary progressive MS. Menopause occurs around age 45, which means that most women with MS who are postmenopausal at diagnosis will be diagnosed as having pre-MS. The main symptom of both MS and PCS is pain. Pain caused by other conditions or medications can cause similar symptoms. Some people experience only one type of migraine headache during their lifetime. Other people may experience two different types of headaches, each lasting for less than three months, or migraines that start in adolescence but stop by adulthood. Migraine attacks may also affect a person's sleep, mood, energy level, concentration, strength and ability to drive, work and perform everyday activities such as eating, walking and dressing. In addition, MS patients often notice that they feel tired more frequently and lose their appetite. Symptoms can range from mild to severe, depending on the severity of the underlying condition. Sometimes people report not feeling well enough to go out without help. People who are unable to work or participate fully in social activities might find it difficult to manage finances, make new friends, get married, or raise children. They might even decide to stop working altogether. Many factors contribute to these symptoms, including fatigue caused by physical work or emotional stress, changes in hormone levels due to changes in pregnancy or menopause, infection, anemia, inflammation, injury or surgery, or depression. Menopause usually causes the menstrual cycle to slow down, leading to heavier flow and cramping that may last up to six weeks before menstruation resumes. During this time, a woman should continue to take her medication regularly because some medicines may prevent the body from properly making estrogen. If there has been a recent change in diet or lifestyle, it can disrupt the balance between hormones, causing problems with estrogen production. However, any changes in diet or lifestyle should be carefully monitored. As a result of a change in diet or lifestyle, it may be necessary to adjust your treatment regimen if you already have PCS or MS. Some health care providers prescribe a combination of estrogen plus progestin to treat both MS and PCS symptoms. This method of using estrogen together with oral contraceptives (birth control pills) has been shown to be safe when used safely. For more information about hormonal contraception and PCS, see
answer4:
Menopause symptoms are common in MS. They include changes in mood, memory and sleep. Some women also have menstrual irregularities as a result of the menstrual cycle change that occurs in MS. MS is not an equal opportunity disease; some women experience more symptoms than others.\r

"Some studies have suggested that women with MS experience less fatigue and fewer psychosomatic complaints during their first trimester of pregnancy compared to women without MS. \r

\r

Women who undergo treatment for MS may be prescribed oral contraceptives (OCs) or hormones such as progesterone or estrogen, which can affect how well a woman's ovaries function." https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6395871 "In addition, a recent report indicated that women with MS had significantly higher prevalence rates of depression and anxiety disorders than did controls. It has been reported that patients with MS may be more likely to take antidepressant medications, but there remains debate about whether this is related to diagnosis or treatment response. A number of researchers have reported that female patients have higher levels of depressive symptoms when treated with antidepressants. In one study, depressed patients were found to have greater severity of depressive symptoms on both the Montgomery-Ã…sberg Depression Rating Scale and Beck Depression Inventory than non-depressed females (Nguyen et al., 2005). Similarly, in another study, female patients with MS showed increased prevalence of major depression symptomatology compared to their male counterparts (Lopez et al., 2007)." http://ajpregu.physiology.org/cgi/content/abstract/286/2/E101 "The role of oestrogen in central nervous system (CNS)-mediated pathogenesis in AD was first hypothesized by Wacholder & Schuhmacher (1943), based upon data from the German perinatal cohort of 1932â€“1945. These investigators observed elevated levels of serum oestradiol at 10 weeks postpartum in mothers with breast cancer after they became pregnant. Subsequently, it was shown that high plasma levels of oestrogen induce CNS-induced apoptosis and dysfunction of neuronal excitability. Several lines of evidence support a model whereby ovarian steroid action contributes to neurodegeneration via modulation of excitatory and inhibitory amino acid receptors through activation of G protein-coupled receptor-gamma interferon gamma (GRGs), i.e., AMPK and AMPA/kainate receptors. Moreover, several mechanisms have been proposed
answer5:
Multiple sclerosis is a progressive disease of the central nervous system that results in loss or impairment of motor and sensory functions, as well as cognitive function. Menopausal symptoms may be related to MS by causing low estrogen levels (hypoestrogenism). Several studies have shown that women who experience hypoestrogenism with postmenopausal women are at increased risk for developing MS. In addition, multiple sclerosis is more prevalent among women who live longer than 30 years. Therefore, it is possible that women who take oral contraceptives will be at increased risk for MS-related symptoms if they have a history of MS.

Q: I am on oral contraceptives. Do they affect my risk for MS?A: Many factors can affect your chance of getting MS, including genetics, environmental exposures such as smoking, being overweight, and having inherited genes that predispose you to MS or other autoimmune diseases. Some of these factors include: age, gender, race, family history, education level, socioeconomic status, and how much weight you carry around. If any of these factors increase your chances of getting MS or other autoimmune disorders, then taking a contraceptive pill could reduce the likelihood of getting them.

The bottom line is that this study shows some benefit from taking birth control pills for MS symptoms, but there's no evidence to suggest that they work better than placebo. This doesn't mean that birth control pills don't help people with MS â€” just that it's not clear whether they offer any additional benefit over placebo treatment.
answer6:
Menopause is the transition from reproductive to post-reproductive health. It affects all women, but it is most common in older women (35â€“55 years of age) with a history of autoimmune disease or cancer, and in those who have had an intact uterus for at least 20 years. Symptoms are similar to those seen during early stages of MS, including fatigue, loss of appetite, vaginal dryness, headaches and sleep disturbances.

In addition, menopause can exacerbate MS symptoms by causing changes in blood clotting, which are also known as vasoconstrictor responses. Vasoactive substances in circulation cause constriction of blood vessels and this triggers inflammation, usually in the legs and feet. The increased risk of stroke that occurs in menopausal women may be related to the high levels of inflammatory molecules that circulate in their bloodstreams (37).

Eating disorders are one of several coexisting conditions that are thought to increase the risk of developing MS (38). In fact, eating disorder symptomatology has been associated with a higher frequency of MS among people with a family history of MS (39). Many individuals diagnosed with MS have problems with food intake (40), and some studies suggest that diets rich in omega-3 fatty acids may reduce the risk of MS (41). Omega-3 fatty acid deficiency and malnutrition can occur in both sexes during menopause (42), and vitamin D deficiency is reported to be more common in premenopausal women than in postmenopausal women (43). Both low levels of testosterone and reduced levels of estrogen in women with MS increase their risk of depression and other mood disorders (44).

References
answer7:
A case report (N=6) demonstrates that a woman with MS who had no apparent risk factors for MS was diagnosed with late onset perimenopausal MS and was found to have an unusual number of MS-related symptoms including fatigue, mood changes, decreased sex drive, increased sexual activity, and pain. This is the first reported case of perimenopausal MS in a MS patient.

Q: What are some possible mechanisms by which perimenopausal women may be at risk for developing MS?\nA: Some evidence suggests that estrogen deprivation from ovaries during the perimenopausal period may increase the likelihood of relapsing, or worsening of the disease. These findings support the notion that the menstrual cycle plays a role in determining susceptibility to MS. In addition, the presence of MS in the absence of any other identifiable cause warrants investigation as a potential cause. If a female with MS also has perimenopausal symptoms, it may well indicate a link between her MS and the hormone system. However, there is currently insufficient evidence to determine whether this is likely to occur and if so, how frequently such a relationship occurs.

Q: Does the use of oral contraceptives (OCs), particularly ethinyl estradiol (EE), alter the risk for developing MS?\nA: Although OC use is associated with an increased risk for MS, the mechanism through which OC exposure increases the risk remains unclear. It could result from the development of a proinflammatory cytokine response following exposure to OC hormones. Alternatively, OCs could induce damage to myelin sheath around nerve axons, leading to neurodegeneration and inflammation that may eventually lead to MS. Studies examining whether hormonal contraception affects MS outcome remain limited and inconsistent.
answer8:
Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a progressive autoimmune disease of the central nervous system, with signs and symptoms including headache, numbness and weakness on one or both sides of the body, difficulty walking, fatigue, sleep disturbance, cognitive impairment, vision problems, bladder dysfunction, chronic pain and a range of other neurological complaints. The first few years after diagnosis may be very difficult for women as they struggle to cope with these symptoms and the emotional turmoil that can accompany them. During this time, most women's symptoms are subtle and may not present themselves until later in life. As MS progresses, it causes damage to areas around neurons called axons which transmit nerve impulses from neuron to neuron and cause many of the symptoms associated with MS. This is known as neurodegeneration and occurs throughout the brain and spinal cord. Menopause affects the menstrual cycle more than any other aspect of a woman's health. It also leads to changes in blood flow and hormone levels, which can affect the functioning of nerves. Although the exact cause is unknown, there are several theories regarding the link between MS and menopause. One theory is that MS is triggered by an inflammatory response within the immune system against a cell type known as microglia. Microglia contain a protein called CD47, which binds directly to the surface of macrophages â€” white blood cells. When CD47 is bound to the surface of a lymphocyte, the cell produces chemicals called cytokines, which help destroy invading pathogens. Studies have shown that when the number of CD47-bound microglia increases during MS, inflammation becomes more severe. Many researchers believe this could explain why MS attacks nerve cells. In addition, another hypothesis suggests that inflammation might play a role in causing menopause because the immune system responds less strongly to estrogen and progesterone. Another possible explanation is that MS has something to do with the release of an enzyme called cyclooxygenase 2 (COX2), which allows your body to break down endocannabinoids, an active ingredient in marijuana that makes you feel high. COX2 appears to be activated in MS patients at lower doses of THC compared to healthy individuals. However, some studies suggest that smoking cannabis is linked to lower rates of MS. Although these hypotheses have yet to be proven through controlled clinical trials, they are worth investigating further because the findings could potentially lead to new treatments and even new ways to prevent MS.

What are menopausal symptoms? A symptom of menopause is hot flashes, which usually occur about once every two weeks
answer9:
Menopausal symptoms are an important marker of the progression and severity of MS.

Q: What is the difference between menopause in women and menopause in men?

A: The menopause process starts at a much earlier age for most females than it does for males; in many cases, it's even happening before puberty. For this reason, the average age of onset for female MS is significantly lower (12 years) compared with male MS (25-30). There is no one single cause for female MS and as a result, there are also no simple treatments that will work for everyone. However, there are several things you can do to help reduce your risk.


For more information about how to manage menopausal symptoms during your MS course, please visit our Women's Health page. If you have any questions or concerns regarding what may be causing your menopause symptoms, contact our Patient Care team today!
answer10:
Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a degenerative disorder of the central nervous system. A person with MS has reduced ability to move his or her body, and can experience pain and numbness in their hands, feet, face, legs, mouth, throat, eyes, and extremities.

If you have MS and don't know if your condition will worsen, talk to your doctor about how to reduce your risk for developing early onset MS. You may be able to take certain medications before getting pregnant. In addition, many women with MS are diagnosed during their pregnancy, so it's important that you continue to take your medicine as prescribed during those months. If you're a woman who is trying to become pregnant, check with your health care provider about whether MS medication could harm your baby, or what other treatments might help prevent MS-related problems during pregnancy.

You should not stop taking your MS medicines unless your doctor tells you otherwise.

Cannabis Use During Pregnancy

There is no known evidence that cannabis use affects birth outcomes, including miscarriage or premature delivery. However, it's possible that marijuana use in late pregnancy may increase a woman's chance of having low Apgar scores, which indicates that your baby was born alive but less than full term. Therefore, ask your health care provider about ways to limit your exposure to THC while you're pregnant.

Women who smoke cannabis throughout pregnancy have been found to have higher rates of preterm birth. Research on marijuana smoking during pregnancy remains inconclusive because little research has been done on this subject. Because there isn't enough information to draw strong conclusions regarding its effect on fetal growth, women shouldn't start using cannabis until they're sure that it won't affect their unborn child. To learn more, read our article on Marijuana Use During Pregnancy.

query: Q: Can I pass multiple sclerosis to other family members?\nA:
answer1:
Yes. The disease is not inherited, and there are no known genetic mutations in the MS gene(s). However, it is important for you to know that a diagnosis of MS requires three or more of the following: (1) a history of MS symptoms; (2) an MS-specific test showing abnormal CSF proteins on both peripheral blood smears and MRI scans; and (3) laboratory confirmation of CD4+ T-cell counts below 100 cells/mm 3. In some cases, these conditions can be found without having had any previous diagnosed MS symptoms.

Q: What medications should I use with my medications?\nA: There have been several clinical trials (a type of study where participants take different medication for varying periods over several months or years) that look at combining various types of anti-MS medicines in an attempt to improve their side effects. Unfortunately, all of this research has so far failed to yield any improvements in symptom relief. For those who do want to try combination therapy, we recommend that you consult your physician about which anti-MS drug combinations may work best for you. If you're interested in taking these kinds of medications, please visit our Medication page.

Other Questions About MS
answer2:
Yes, MS is hereditary and passes from parent to child. It can also be passed on through the blood system. There are several ways to pass it on, such as being exposed to certain drugs or having a close relative with a genetic mutation that makes them more likely to develop MS. People who have been diagnosed with MS should talk with their doctors about any possible risks of passing MS on to children.

Q: Will my doctor know if I had a brain tumor? A: Your doctor will ask you questions about your medical history. If he/she knows something about your personal history and finds the diagnosis suspicious, they may refer you for testing at an accredited neurology center. Some centers have protocols in place to screen people before allowing them to get a CT scan (electroencephalogram) or MRI (magnetic resonance imaging), which reveal lesions that might be present in the brain. However, many patients with suspected or confirmed brain tumors are not referred for these tests until after the first treatment course. The same is true when trying to find out whether MS is causing the brain tumors; you do not need to undergo additional scans or treatments until the first course of therapy is complete. In some cases, symptoms occur in conjunction with the onset of tumors that may not be detected until months later, even years after the initial diagnosis. Also, because there is no standard way to diagnose these conditions, physicians often perform different types of diagnostic procedures on each person, sometimes leading to confusion and potentially inaccurate results. For example, some doctors use magnetic resonance images to look for MRIs in the brain but use computed tomography (CTs) for neurological exams or blood work. Other doctors use PET scans to view the metabolism of red blood cells. These differences may lead to misdiagnosis and incorrect treatment recommendations.

Q: What happens if someone has MS and then develops a brain tumor? Do I really have brain cancer? A: Yes. Brain cancers usually grow slowly over time; however, the rate varies widely depending on the type and location of the tumor. Early-stage noncancerous brain tumors can become malignant and spread throughout the body. This can cause death by respiratory failure. Later stages of cancer, such as gliomas and meningiomas, have much slower growth rates and generally don't require surgery to remove them. Although most people recover fully from this condition, some people develop long-term problems, including speech loss, depression, impaired memory, Parkinson's disease symptoms, or dementia.
answer3: Yes. If you have multiple sclerosis, your parents or siblings may inherit the condition from either of you. You will need a statement from each of you stating that you understand and consent to being included in any future distribution. The Statement should be signed by both of you. It is important that the letter states which parent has multiple sclerosis and what symptoms that parent may experience.\nB\ --------------------------------------------------------------------------- \3\ As explained more fully in chapter 3 of this report, it is likely that a patient's disease status and its medical treatment may affect his or her ability to express assent or withhold assent as required under IRC Sections 401(m) and 408(d). However, because you did not file an accurate Parental Consent Form for SRA coverage when you applied, a parent cannot assert that he or she was unable to sign a statement to indicate that he or she consented to receiving benefits on behalf of his or her children. Instead, if an individual with a disability who received SRA coverage before February 1, 2000, but who does not qualify now for SRA health insurance benefits (i.e., all individuals are enrolled in Medicare), he or she may submit a valid Affidavit of Waiver or Authorization to Receive Benefits. If a person receives only limited-purpose Medicare coverage, he or she must fill out a Supplemental Affidavit of Eligibility, in addition to affirming that he or she meets the requirements for Medicare coverage. See 44 CFR Part 164.50 for more information about submitting such forms. Note also that if a noncustodial parent fails to provide documentation establishing eligibility for Medicare coverage or any other benefit under Medicare, then he or she could face penalties under Section 501 of the Social Security Act.\4\ --------------------------------------------------------------------------- \4\ 42 U.S.C. Sec. 651 et seq.; 45 C.F.R. Secs. 1308.5(a)(1)-1308.5(b)(2). In many cases, however, the inability to complete the form can be attributed to the fact that a custodial parent did not know about his or her child's condition until after he or she had been given notice that coverage would begin. For example, a father whose child with spina bifida was born prematurely may have had no knowledge that his son would require lifelong care; instead, he may have thought he would receive the $1,000 per month SSI benefits paid by his employer. Under these circumstances, a parent may still claim
answer4: Yes. MS is an autoimmune disease that can be passed from parent to child. It may be possible for some families to develop the condition and others not. However, in most cases it's impossible to determine which of a person's parents or siblings have MS. Therefore, if you are concerned about your sibling's ability to maintain their independence, please talk with your doctor.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cp\u003eFor more information on this topic contact our \u003ci\u003eMS Knowledge Team\u003c\/i\u003e.\u003cbr\u003e\u003ch3\u003eCan my cat or dog get MS?\u003cspan style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"\u003eWhen cats and dogs cohabit, they share many health concerns. This includes exposure to toxins and viruses that cause diseases such as mites. They also face different health risks because they carry bacteria that can trigger asthma attacks. So why not consider getting one pet, especially a healthy, housebroken animal? A friend recently shared her experience with her three cats who all got sick within a two year period. Her cats were on medication to treat allergies at the time so she was unaware of any underlying problems. She has since found out that her cats had been exposed to toxoplasmosis (Toxo), a common parasite associated with diabetes mellitus. Both cats are on medication to control diabetes but do not respond well to these drugs. The Toxo infection came back to haunt them as symptoms of asthma and heart failure returned. Some cat owners will decide to put down their pets because of this, while others keep them for fear that they will suffer the same fate as their beloved felines. You should only take steps necessary to protect yourself and those close to you. If there are no underlying issues, and your pet has never had an allergy, then consider keeping them together.\u003c\/span\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003ch3\u003eWhat are the symptoms of MS?\u003cspan style=\"line-height: 1.5;\"\u003eThe early signs of MS include:\"\u003c\/span\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003ch3\u003eHow often does MS run in my family?\u003cspan style=\"line
answer5: Yes, but it can be difficult for one or both of you. You will need support from a doctor in making the decision about whether you should move forward with this new family member (if any). There may also be issues about insurance coverage. This is something that should be discussed by your doctor and/or neurologist. Some people are not able to have more than one child, so if you do decide to adopt another person who has MS, there may still be additional costs involved. You should speak directly with those individuals before deciding on additional adoption. Q: Is there anything else I should know about adoption?\nA: The process of adopting an individual living with MS must be approached carefully. If possible, it is best to work closely with your doctor and other medical professionals before starting the adoption process. Most people who are considering adopting have been through at least one MS diagnosis, and most of them have experienced MS symptoms for longer periods of time than we would like, especially as adults. They may be afraid of losing control of their body. And they may be uncertain about what they will feel and think when the time comes to make such a significant life change. In addition, many people with MS become re-diagnosed periodically. We encourage anyone contemplating an adoption to seek out information about the risks associated with MS and the risks associated with pregnancy and childbirth. It is important to note that the risk factors for MS are different for each patient. For example, some people with MS experience exacerbations of the disease after being diagnosed with MS during adolescence, while others do not. All these factors play into decisions about what kind of care someone needs prior to, or during, an adoption. A complete discussion between you and the adoption agency about your individual situation and its specific risks and benefits is very important.
answer6:
The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has approved a vaccine for MS called Rituxan that contains both the gene from MS and another gene from someone who is not positive for the gene. However, this type of vaccination cannot be passed on unless it's used in conjunction with a blood test done before birth.

Q: Is there any treatment for MS? \nA: There are many different ways to treat or manage MS, but we do have some treatments available that can help reduce symptoms. You may choose to participate in one of these research studies if you'd like to learn more about them or you're interested in learning more about your options when trying to live with MS.

Q: Will I continue to develop my disability after I die? \nA: It depends upon how long you lived with MS; some people will still experience ongoing symptoms such as muscle weakness or fatigue at least until age 65 years old. We don't know for sure how long MS remains active in your body once you stop living with it. But even though it might take several months or longer for symptoms to go away completely, the most common symptom of MS is an inability to walk without assistance. In addition, MS patients often find it difficult to get around, especially when they lose their hands or feet while working or caring for others.

Q: How can I help MS researchers understand MS better?\nA: If you would like to support our work, please consider donating to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society Research Program. Your gift allows us to recruit new scientists, improve our understanding of the disease, and fund basic and clinical research into all aspects of the disease, including its causes.
answer7:
Yes, if the individual has a history of MS and is living with you. You may not be able to pass both diseases simultaneously to your spouse or children. However, if you have a good relationship with them and they understand what you are going through, there may be some chance that the disease can progress in either direction. If it does, please call us back so we can help you make sure you don't run into a situation where you are unable to care for yourself.

Q: I am an older adult who has multiple sclerosis, but my husband has lived full time as a volunteer at our local homeless shelter for over ten years. He has never worked, he doesn't know how to manage his finances, etc.. Is this legal?A: This may violate federal and/or state laws (if the individual lives on their own). In addition, if a person is living in a home alone then this violates state law as well. We do not recommend this arrangement because of the risk of abuse of power and neglect by someone whose primary job was caring for another person.

Q: Do you offer financial assistance to people with disabilities?A: The main purpose of MS support groups is to empower individuals with MS to lead healthier and happier lives. Our groups provide information about medications, treatments, health insurance options, and other resources available to those who need help. There are no restrictions on eligibility for group membership, however many of our activities depend on the generosity of the people attending. Some participants will also receive disability income from Medicare. For more information contact the National Multiple Sclerosis Society at (800) 933-2396.
answer8:
Yes, you can. There is a 1-in-2 chance that if you have MS and an affected child, the parent of the child has MS as well. However, there are some complications for this, such as when the siblings have different patterns or types of MS (for example, if one sibling has relapsing forms of MS while the other sibling does not). Also, it may be difficult to establish who has which form of MS so it would be best to consult with your doctor to determine whether passing the disease on to another relative would be wise.

Q: What should I do if my relative refuses therapy?


A: If treatment is being refused, contact the physician directly. Do not ask others in your family to refuse treatment. Many people will try to convince their relatives to accept the diagnosis and treatments offered by the doctors at the clinic. This rarely works. The only way to end the confusion over what is happening is through honest communication between the patient and physicians, which is often difficult to achieve because of differences of opinion about what is going on.

In addition, please remember that when discussing treatment options, even with close friends, the doctor has his/her own opinions about what is best for your loved one. Please keep those opinions confidential unless you want your friend to know them.

Q: Why do some women develop symptoms after having children?


A: It is possible that some women, particularly older mothers, have low levels of sex hormones in their body from having had babies earlier in life, causing changes in the lining of their uterus. This may cause problems during pregnancy and possibly even after childbirth. These include inflammation and damage to the walls of the uterus, which can lead to pain and bleeding. Some experts believe that it is also possible that there is more than one hormone involved in these conditions.


If your doctor suspects that you might be pregnant, she will check your blood pressure every 6 months and monitor your progress toward delivery. She may need to perform ultrasound scans before and during the birth process to identify any abnormalities in the baby's development. During labor, the doctor will also examine the mother's abdomen and cervix periodically, including at the time of vaginal exams. You will probably notice a change in your pelvic floor muscles as your water breaks -- this will help her understand how much force she needs to apply during labor.


Your doctor also recommends that you avoid strenuous exercise for several weeks after giving birth, and take antacids for up to three days after labor
answer9:
No, there is a limit of five. (However, if you have more than one relative with MS, your application may be denied.)\nA: Yes, but only up to the age of 21.

If you are applying for an exemption from the age requirement or disability exemption (because you're over 18), please indicate in the notes box what percentage of your income will be exempt based on the number and ages of people with whom you live and work.

Q: What if my child is living with me? How much does it matter? A: You must still meet both age requirements if you apply to join the DLA. If this applies to you, we recommend that you check out our article on how to apply in full time employment.

What happens to older siblings (over the age of 20) who don't qualify for a DLA?

We will let them stay on the family home allowance until they turn 22 years old, after which point they become eligible for their own personal allowance. If this applies to you, contact us before the end of the year to see whether we can make arrangements for you to continue to receive support through these payments even though you are moving house.

Do I need to prove my household income?

You do not need to provide proof of your household income when you apply to join the DLA. However, some people might choose to do so because it helps them get around the rules. For example, you could show your council tax bill and ask us to reduce your housing costs as part of your application if the total amount you pay in council tax each week isn't enough to cover your rent or mortgage.

The DLA also has special rules for those who earn less than Â£11,500 per year. If you fit into this category, you can't use the new income-related test. Instead, you'll have to have been on a low paid job for at least three months prior to joining the DLA, or you won't qualify for a DLA at all. The same goes for earnings above Â£18,200 per year - although those earning between Â£17,800 and Â£23,400 should already have had experience with the Income Support system. This means your claim for a reduction in benefits will probably fail if you haven't worked for at least 3 months by the date you've finished your course.
answer10:
Yes. In fact, you can provide your children with a copy of your disability report and their parents' disability reports if they are over the age of 18. If there is any overlap in coverage between your children's and parent's plans, that will be considered a qualifying event for you. However, if you have more than one child and more than one of them has a qualifying event under your plan, only one of your children will qualify as having received an exemption from group health insurance. The coverage must be medically necessary and in the form of a qualified long-term care or retirement benefit plan. It cannot be part of a group health insurance plan that provides medical coverage without a financial requirement (for example, health maintenance organization). This rule applies even though these types of plans do not include requirements for preventive services.\u00a0You may also wish to review our policy on providing extra help for relatives who need it. For more information about this process, please visit our Family Member Help page.

Q: What happens if my spouse's income exceeds my income by $2,000 and we file jointly?\nA: Under the Internal Revenue Code and regulations, joint returns are treated as married filing separately for tax purposes. If you and your spouse file jointly, then you are both subject to the same taxes. Your combined taxable income after all deductions and exemptions would be $9,250 ($7,500 + $3,750).\r

If either of you make too much money ($6,350 or less) to meet this threshold, you'll pay higher income tax rates -- up to 39.6% percent on joint filers earning more than $150,000 ($75,800 per person/$225,100 per couple). If either of you makes too little to satisfy this threshold, you won't owe additional federal income taxes at all. So, whether or not you have joint tax liability, you're still responsible for paying at least some of your share of both state and federal taxes if each spouse contributes to his or her own retirement account. This includes Social Security payments and unemployment benefits. If you don't want to contribute to a retirement account directly, you could elect to defer those contributions until retirement. You could also transfer assets from your regular retirement accounts into a Roth IRA, but doing so requires a lengthy and complicated process. Once you've done these things, you won't have any federal tax consequences for years to come unless you choose to file a return claiming a break for marital status (see question #

A: You must have insurance as part of your health plan. All eligible MSFS employees will receive a benefit package from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). You can view the current benefit packages available at www.mssf.gov/benefits. If you would like more detailed information about your coverage, please contact us directly via email at msfs@msfs.org. Please note that these benefit packages do not cover treatment for conditions that arise after you become disabled.

CAREER TRAVEL

Yes, there are many options available. Many foreign graduate students are employed by corporations or government agencies throughout North America. There are numerous international organizations, such as the Canadian Council on Learning (CCL), and international associations such as the International Association of Medical Humanities (IAMH). These groups provide services to international medical graduates studying within their countries' healthcare systems. The CCL and the IAMH have offices in most major cities worldwide and offer many programs designed to help doctors and medical professionals gain experience abroad. Q: What are my obligations as an individual employee? Are there specific procedures to follow if someone needs time off for medical reasons?

MS is often diagnosed during adolescence or early adulthood, so it may not appear until later that people may have other conditions that interfere with their ability to carry out normal tasks, such as learning disabilities or ADHD symptoms. When you begin your job, it would generally be appropriate for your employer to provide you with notice of any reasonable medical restrictions or limitations. If you experience any difficulty because of these medical restrictions, or you need time off to receive treatment for them, please discuss this issue directly with your supervisor (or a person authorized by the supervisor) to ensure that your role is being properly managed. You will probably be required to take leave when you need the time off; your doctor may order additional time off without prior notice, but you should communicate with your boss before taking extra time off.

Q: Do I have to report medical problems to my employer?

Yes. Your employer must notify its employees who are covered under any applicable federal, state or local laws regarding the use of drugs or medical devices that they are not allowed to carry a firearm while performing their duties unless they obtain written permission from their employer or their physician.

When it comes to employment benefits, including health insurance, your employer must make certain coverage available to all employees equally. This means that your employer must cover your medications at no cost, even if your medication is prescribed for a "disability." It also requires that employees receiving disability payments continue receiving those payments until the date on which the payments cease.

In addition, your employer must allow you to transfer between groups of employees on the same basis and regardless of where you live.

Some states have passed laws allowing employers to require employees who are using drug therapy to get prior approval prior to using their medications and/or participate in group therapy. However, these laws only protect against discrimination based on disability and do not affect non-drug therapy or the right of employees to share their personal thoughts or opinions with others.

The MS Society can help you find financial assistance through several grants and loans as well as loan programs.

To apply for any of these services, please email us at info@mssoc.ca and let us know which one(s).

Citizen Education Bursaries

For many Canadians living abroad, going back to school for free is not a viable option due to costs and the limited number of approved bursaries available. The Citizen Education Program provides low cost financing to eligible Canadian citizens studying overseas who intend to return to their home country. In addition to qualifying for this funding, the citizen student must demonstrate their intention to remain in Canada long term.

To be considered, applicants should complete an online application form. Eligible students may include international graduate students, Canadian citizens studying in another country and those enrolled in a program offered by one of the recognized faculties or schools of education located within Canada or outside of Canada.

How do I apply for a disability? How long does it take?

To apply for disability benefits from Medicare, you must apply at least 60 days prior to your expected retirement date, or within 30 days after your expected retirement date if you have already retired. If you have not yet applied for Social Security Disability Insurance, then a new application process begins once you have reached age 65. It can take several months, depending on what kind of evidence you provide in support of your claim, before we evaluate your case. You should always call us as soon as possible when you know you might need help in applying for disability benefit payments, so we can make sure we can handle your request quickly. We also require documentation from your doctor regarding all previous illnesses, injuries, and diagnoses that could affect your ability to perform your job duties, as well as any medical reports that document your ability to work safely and effectively. You may need more information than we ask for when you file your application. Please see our web pages (www.medicare.gov and www.socialsecurity.gov) for further information on how to prepare for your claim.
