query: Q: Why get episode diagnosed by a doctor as a relapse of multiple sclerosis?\nA:
answer1:
To help others with MS, to make a difference in the lives of people who have it and to be able to continue living life after my time here. I think that's what everyone wants from their doctors.

Q: When you were first diagnosed with MS, did you know exactly how severe your illness was or was it more like a vague sense?\nA: No. It wasn't until about six months ago when I got this diagnosis that I started having symptoms of it again. The only symptoms that came back are just fatigue and general aches and pains that I don't really have much control over but if they're severe enough then it does take away your ability to do things. So for me it's not so much about knowing what's going on, I'm pretty sure I didn't know at all. As far as the severity of the disease I can say that it is very slow progressing, it doesn't feel like someone has been beating up on your body and breaking down every single one of your bones right now, but I've been saying for quite awhile now that I'll probably never walk normally again, I haven't even walked without pain since January. And it sucks because once I had to go through three surgeries and an MRI and all of that crap before getting better. But it feels good to finally be getting some relief, I mean there are still days where it makes me cry to wake up because I feel so weak and helpless and there isn't anything that I can do about it.

Q: What kind of medication is being prescribed you? A: Antibiotics or steroids or both, depending on what my health insurance covers. They also gave me a big speech about how not taking them would cause problems later on and all of these other horrible possibilities. That's not something I want to believe, it will most likely lead to another hospital stay and that doesn't seem very healthy to me. So I guess at least I know that I'm getting the best possible care out of whatever resources they provide for me. Q: How many times have you gone back to school since the diagnosis? A: Three times actually. One time I went back for two weeks to finish high school while also working a few hours a week during that period. Then I went back to work at the same job I worked at before the diagnosis, which I quit because it was such a stressful situation to deal with. This time around it was only a couple weeks before coming home. So I got a little bit older, got
answer2:
I'm not sure. The idea was to treat her symptoms, but also be able to look at the cause of these things.

Q: How is she doing now and what are you going to do with your life? \nA: She's doing good. She's in good hands. It's hard when you can't work -- like I couldn't work for my own money, but I had a full time job helping other people. She wasn't having that. She had a real difficult time making ends meet. But we're going to continue working together. We have to make money. That's why we went into business. And we were able to get insurance.
answer3:
The disease has progressed to the point where I am not able to function as an active participant in my life. It is a matter of survival, which means that I must find something else to do and work out my weaknesses. That's why I have chosen this path, because I want to contribute in some way to help people with MS who are in similar situations.

Dr. S.: What kind of treatments can you offer patients?

Patient 1: Most often they just need some physical therapy, but there is also medication that might be needed for their conditions such as nerve damage, muscle paralysis or loss of vision. They usually start off on a low dose of medications before slowly increasing it over time. In addition, we talk about nutrition and supplementation.

Dr. S.: How much does an average patient spend per month on MS drugs?

Patient 2: Some spend up to $2,000 a month while others only spend half that amount. However, if they go down the "low-dose" route, one third will spend less than $100 a month, two thirds may spend no more than $200 a month, and five percent will pay nothing at all.

Dr. S.: What kinds of tests do you use?

Patient 2: We screen every new patient through MRIs and EEGs (electroencephalograms) since the disease progresses rapidly.

Dr. S.: Who are your biggest clients and how long did you work with them?

Patients 3 and 4: Both suffered from progressive degenerative disc problems. They were initially prescribed antibiotics and steroids but found that they had very serious side effects, such as constipation, hair loss, fatigue, dizziness, depression, insomnia, diarrhea, skin rashes and weight gain. Because these symptoms occurred so frequently, they decided to stop using these medications and went back to their traditional treatment plan consisting mainly of acupuncture, diet modification and walking. Each patient was followed for 12 months, which showed remarkable improvement, even though many side effects returned. Their doctors suggested a small dose of oral statin drugs that could keep the benefits without the side effects. Patients 5 and 6 both suffer from severe neuropathy caused by multiple sclerosis. After the first few sessions, they experienced significant improvements and after eight sessions, they said they felt completely normal again, despite having to walk with a cane for three years. These cases proved to us that the medications used to treat MS and other diseases should be adjusted according to individual needs
answer4:
Because you are telling me that I am not getting better because there is some physical cause for my symptoms. If your symptoms were caused by a virus or bacteria, then you would just be on antibiotics and have no more symptoms. You don't do this to people who don't have MS. And if it was a viral infection (as some other people say), the only way you could know that was from blood tests. No one wants their health tested every time they cough or sneeze. A simple cold has nothing to with MS.


Q: What is an MS-related symptom that can last years? Can anyone else tell me what those things are?\nA: There are many kinds of MS symptoms. The most common ones are muscle weakness, difficulty speaking, trouble understanding speech, loss of bladder control, and problems walking or balancing on one foot. They affect about 20 percent of patients. Other common problems include vision changes, headaches, dizziness, numbness in hands and feet, fatigue, depression, anxiety, concentration difficulties, memory problems, tingling sensation when moving parts of body, and tingling in joints like the knees and elbows. These often start while patients are still young children and continue into adulthood. It's important to remember that not all of these problems will show up right away. The brain isn't made fully until age 30 or so, after which it becomes less able to repair itself as it ages. Also, the symptoms that occur earlier in life are usually easier to treat than later ones because the damage occurs at an early stage of disease development and treatment options aren't limited as much. In fact, sometimes treating symptoms too late can actually make them worse. But even if they go away, there may come a day when they return.
answer5:
MS can cause progressive neurological symptoms. In most cases, these are manageable without medication and rest in the treatment phase. However, some patients may have ongoing problems due to their neurological changes or even an exacerbation of previous symptoms (such as worsening fatigue or memory loss). In such cases, we will refer the patient for diagnostic evaluation through physical examination and tests that help us diagnose MS and its associated illnesses. If there is evidence of a relapse, we recommend that you consult your primary care physician and/or neurologist who can discuss ways in which you can improve your functioning and manage this disease.

Q: Can I take my medications while on PEGIFY?

A: Yes. You should not discontinue your current treatment unless directed by your health care provider. However, if you experience withdrawal symptoms from any medication or dietary supplement, please contact your health care professional for advice regarding appropriate consumption. The following medications should be taken with caution when taking PEGIFY:

Antibiotics (such as penicillin and cephalosporin)

Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone and hydrocortisone)

Drugs that affect calcium absorption (e.g., calcitonin, bisphosphonates and other oral anticoagulants)

Medicines used to treat hypothyroidism (e.g., levothyroxine and thyroid hormone replacement products like Synthroid)

If you experience severe constipation (diarrhea), diarrhea within 3-4 days of stopping one or more of these medicines, call your health care provider immediately for further guidance.

Q: Is it safe to use PEGIFY with other drugs?

A: No known interactions between PEGIFY and other substances have been reported. Some medications may interact with PEGIFY in unpredictable ways. This includes drugs taken together with food, including many over-the-counter medicines that you swallow, as well as prescription and nonprescription drugs. These include over-the-counter pain relievers (including acetaminophen, ibuprofen, aspirin, tylenol, naproxen, and others), sleeping pills, antihistamines (phenylephrine and albuterol), corticosteroids, diuretics, blood thinners (like warfarin, CoumadinÂ®, PlavixÂ® [lansoprazole], AdvairÂ® [diltiazem], and others)
answer6:
When we first started seeing patients with MS, it was not known that MS could cause other medical problems such as stroke and heart attack. It wasn't until the mid-1970's when we began to see these new symptoms in our patients that we realized that this is indeed an autoimmune disease. The early treatment for this type of illness was largely based on immunosuppressive medications that were supposed to prevent or reverse the disease. However, in many cases they did no good at all.

Q: What is the most common reason why people experience MS symptoms?\nA: We now know that MS can be triggered by over exposure to a variety of environmental triggers including stress, colds, flu, viruses, toxic chemicals, air pollution, toxins from household cleaners, pesticides, food additives, etc. This list continues to grow as more research into MS is being conducted. In addition to that, there are still unknown factors involved in triggering MS including genetic differences in how the immune system works which could also increase susceptibility to MS.

Q: I've heard about certain foods causing MS, do they really cause that?\nA: Research has shown that some foods can trigger MS but you should always check your doctor if any of those specific foods have caused any signs of trouble before adding them back into your diet.


Q: How often should I check my body for signs of MS?\nA: You should look out for any symptoms like fatigue or weakness after a long period of time, especially if you haven't been active recently. If you notice any unexplained soreness, redness, or swelling anywhere on your body, please consult your doctor.


Q: How do I know when I am getting better?\nA: Your doctor will monitor your progress closely while you take the right medication and continue to keep a close eye on your health throughout your life. With proper care, even the earliest signs of MS may not become apparent and you might never know that MS had even begun!

Sources & Further Reading:
answer7:
If I had an easy answer, I would say "because the MS diagnosis is so common and so good that people assume it's pretty well established," but it isn't. There are lots of false positives for MS in people who aren't actually sick. For instance, I've been told that a patient with chronic fatigue syndrome who has some other symptoms is probably just depressed. And there may be a lot more to these things than a simple disease misdiagnosis. When someone gets a new neurologist at the beginning of each year, they have to prove their neurology (and sometimes medical history) on what they call "the MR" or "medical records." They're required to send back documentation about how much they slept over the past few months, how much exercise they did, whether they took pain relievers, etc. All of this is intended to tell doctors that you're not doing anything wrong with your neurological system, even if all those symptoms look like something else. Sometimes the tests are done after an MRI scan of the brain; other times it can be done right before the MRI scan. But what really matters is that they do a neuro exam, which will give them information about the way your brain processes information, especially when there's a problem. This examination is usually done with two doctors working together â€” one for diagnosing MS, the other for making sure everything looks fine. There aren't enough of these specialists around to test everyone every time. So many people get a new neurologist in the first year after MS diagnosis because they feel better, or they think they should be getting the same treatment they were already taking. The most important thing here is that they only diagnose you once, regardless of whether you're showing up again within the next month or year. They don't need to worry about recurrence. It's possible to learn the signs and symptoms of MS very early on, but sometimes this information doesn't come out until years later â€” after you've developed serious health problems unrelated to MS, like heart disease, stroke, arthritis, or cancer. There may still be a small chance that you'll develop symptoms or problems again after you recover from the initial attack. However, it's extremely unlikely, since the treatments used against the primary autoimmune process have gotten so far along that no return is anticipated.

Q: How long does it take for the body to produce antibodies against another person's immune cells? A: That depends upon the type of antibody. Antibodies make it difficult to transmit the infection to a second person (
answer8:
It's so that I don't have to go back to the hospital. __________________

"Life is like riding in an elevator, you need the right keys to open every door."
answer9:
Because MS is an autoimmune disorder, the immune system attacks the myelin sheath that insulates nerve fibers from injury. That's why relapses are so common in MS patients. It's the same reason doctors diagnose diabetes and heart disease â€” because they attack the body's own cells that produce its energy source. This kind of damage to the brain or spinal cord leads to symptoms such as pain or numbness (migraine) during certain activities, like walking up stairs or driving.

MS is classified into five different types based on the number and severity of the neurological deficits that result from the auto-immune process. These disorders can be managed with medication but often require ongoing treatment. The main goal of this study was to look at how the drug cyclosporine could help reduce or eliminate the relapses. Previous studies have found some MS drugs work effectively in treating most cases. But few treatments are effective for all cases. If one drug were more than 98 percent effective in relieving symptoms compared to placebo, it would likely be recommended as the first course of treatment for patients. In the trial, which ran from September 2011 through April 2013, the researchers randomly assigned 15 men and women to either cyclosporine or a placebo pill. They then monitored the participants' brains and spinal cords over the next nine months using Magnetic Resonance Imaging, or MRI, scans. After nine months, the patients who took cyclosporine had almost twice as many fewer relapses â€” 19 versus 13 â€” compared to those taking a placebo. Cyclosporine was also associated with improvements in four other patient measures: pain, fatigue, sleep problems and depression. "The results suggest that cyclosporine may be especially beneficial when used in conjunction with other medications," says Dr. William H. Pazdernik, lead author of the paper and professor of neurology at Stanford University School of Medicine. The research team plans followup studies at Stanford Medical Center, Kaiser Permanente Northern California Health Care System and at other health care facilities nationwide to see whether the benefits of cyclosporine continue to improve over time. The research team will present the findings Thursday, March 27, 2016, at the American Academy of Neurology annual meeting in Chicago. About the Author: Alyssa Shumaker, a freelance writer living in Seattle, Washington, contributed to this story
answer10:
MS is an autoimmune disease. When the immune system attacks your own body, it can cause symptoms like pain and numbness in your legs (called peripheral neuropathy), or damage to nerves that control movement (called central nervous system disorders). The most common form of MS is called relapsing-remitting MS. In this type of MS, the immune system attack your brain, spinal cord, and other parts of your body; then these areas react again with inflammation. Relapse occurs when the inflammation starts over again within several weeks. Since MS is a lifelong condition, relapses are common, and even more so during pregnancy. This is why getting diagnosed with MS as a relapse is important for you to know about before trying for a baby.

Q: What does being pregnant do to my body?\nA: Pregnancy increases your risk of developing MS. Although there has been some research on the effects of pregnancy on women who have had MS, many researchers still don't know if pregnancy is associated with increased risk for MS. However, one study found that women whose MS was treated early in pregnancy had lower levels of inflammatory biomarkers than those who were given treatment later in pregnancy, suggesting they may be at less risk from having MS than other women. As always, see with your healthcare provider before taking any medication.

We know that this is a very serious problem. So you need to consider the issue of whether or not there are treatments which can be offered in these cases. If we were able to find an effective treatment, would it change the direction of research?

Dr. Wainwright: Well, I don't think so. That's why we want to make sure that whatever we do, whether it's using a genetic approach or an immunotherapy approach, that we look at it in as many people as possible, and that we have follow-up studies. But if we're finding one person who shows benefit, then we'll continue on with that drug. And we're also looking for another drug that might work in this setting.

It's important to note that there may be drugs that have some activity against MS lesions but not relapses. And you may also have some drugs that are more likely to trigger relapses because they've been used before to treat other autoimmune diseases, like lupus. So how you choose between those approaches depends entirely upon your needs and your outlook on the disease. In terms of developing new drugs for MS, this isn't going to happen any time soon, certainly not within 10 years. But it's important to remember that new therapies will keep coming, and we should try to understand them better and what are the best ways to deliver them.

Q: I have an older child who has relapsed after 1 year of treatment with cyclophosphamide (Cytoxan). Is this a serious condition? A: It can be. This disease is very similar to MS and should not be confused with the relapse associated with MS. In fact, people with the same symptoms as those seen in MS are often diagnosed with relapses of their own. So you need to get your child evaluated by a neurologist or other specialists when he/she becomes more symptomatic than usual, particularly if they have had an increase in their symptoms over time. Also check out the FAQs section on Relapse to learn about some common signs of relapses.

In general, many people with MS also experience other forms of MS (also called secondary progressive MS) which may take years or decades to develop and do not respond to therapy. You should consult with your physician for any additional information regarding any new onset of symptoms, including changes that occur while taking treatment or after discontinuing treatment.

Q: How long does it usually take for MS to go away? A: MS is a chronic disabling disease that typically progresses slowly and steadily throughout the course of life, but sometimes the progression is faster or slower. If you have been treated for MS for several months, you may want to continue your treatment. If you've been getting well during the past few years, you may no longer need treatment. When it's just started, there is a lot that goes wrong. So talk with your doctor and ask how much you should stick around for.

Q: Can my family member who has MS work? A: Yes, but it will depend on your individual circumstances. Some people with MS have problems lifting heavy objects, so they might want to avoid such jobs until the disease has gone into remission. Other workers might be able to work safely. And others may find working harder rather than less difficult since most tasks are now easier for them because of the loss of muscle strength.

Q: What do I tell my spouse or partner who has MS? A: Talk to your physician about any concerns that might arise related to MS at home. Sometimes spouses or partners of people with MS find it helpful to keep track of what medications are being taken. They can then discuss these medications with their husbands or wives before they start or stop taking them. The medication regimen will be different for each person depending upon their specific needs, but there may be some overlap.

At that time I had a couple of flare-ups and then for awhile I wasn't able to get out of bed. It's been a long process, but I think we're finally getting there now." Q: How has MS affected your relationships with family and friends? Do they understand the disease? A: "My parents have always understood my condition, so that helps. I've never lied about being diagnosed. They still know what it is, which makes them very supportive. My wife doesn't understand why she can't walk; she goes through the motions, but I guess she understands the difference between a physical injury and an emotional one. We also have our kids who are older than us, and sometimes those things bring up questions about their understanding and how they want to be involved." Q: What would you like people to know about relapses? A: "You only have one life. If something good happens after the initial relapse, great! You just have to work on the next thing. There isn't anything you should do because of a relapse. Life is too short. People should respect that. When you've got cancer, you want people to see you as strong as possible and try and give you a chance to live your best life. But you don't necessarily have to recover all at once; this way you can focus on learning new skills and becoming stronger and healthier for longer periods of time." A: "There were times over the years where I did take anti-seizure medications -- especially during my second or third relapse. Sometimes I'd feel like giving up and just letting everything go back to normal again, but that didn't happen often. Instead, I took a break from anti-seizure medication and started eating better and exercising more. That helped me quite a bit, actually. And I found some really good natural treatments. So I'm working on trying to find ways that might help control these relapses without having to use a drug or have other problems. It

What is this?

A: It's a condition where there are repeated relapses of the disease, often within just days. The person might have had an early relapse that was so severe it caused them to lose all function in their legs and arms or even kill them from damage or infection. Or they might be able to get through one relapse but then find themselves unable to walk for weeks or months after. Often they can't move at all without help. Then, with another relapse, they may fall down. And the cycle continues until either the person dies or gets better again.


The more serious type of relapsing remitting MS (RMS) has symptoms such as weakness on one side of your body, numbness on your feet, loss of muscle tone on one side of your face or hands, and problems with speech, balance and vision. People usually develop some degree of disability after relapsing for a short time, sometimes only days or weeks. But as the disease progresses, you'll experience worse symptoms until eventually your whole body is affected and you can no longer see anything clearly. A few years ago, people who were treated with steroids called glucocorticoids were found to get better rapidly when they first began treatment because they could control the inflammation associated with the disease by taking drugs. However, after about six months or so, when they stopped using these drugs, many of those patients got worse again. They were left vulnerable to other types of infections, which could cause further relapses.


Because so much research has been done on drug therapies, we know what causes relapsing remitting MS. We also understand how the disease affects different parts of the brain and spinal cord. This knowledge helps us understand how to treat RMS. There are several things that are known about this disease, including:


* When an immune system attack occurs, cells inside your nervous system become damaged. These changes can lead to nerve cell death, which leads to paralysis or a loss of mobility. In recent years, researchers have begun studying ways to stop the immune response before the damage to the nerves takes place, and thus prevent a cascade of events that ultimately kills nerve cells. Drugs are currently used to suppress the immune system. Some of these medications work well and others do not. Scientists are working hard to improve the effectiveness of treatments and discover new ones. If we succeed, we will likely have treatments that give people back their independence and ability to move around completely independent of any external support.


* Because R

But if people were doing a lot of research on this topic, they would have already been able to tell us that. They'd be seeing results in many different studies. You can't just make something up. It isn't possible. Q: What else is there to the story? A: If someone was talking about an unproven theory and then someone came along and proved them wrong, then that person could be called a liar, or a charlatan, or whatever. And yet, when scientists talk about a scientific principle they don't like, such as HIV causing AIDS, we are expected to accept that the theory has not been proven. Why should the public believe a statement that hasn't been proven? As a matter of fact, we wouldn't want to accept something without proof either. We need to go on believing what our senses tell us, whether it's true or false. This may sound absurd, but it's a pretty simple concept; we need to trust our senses, especially since many of these same scientists who say HIV causes AIDS are also members of the medical establishment which says HIV does cause AIDS. But again, why shouldn't we believe their sense? If science teaches us anything, it teaches us how to think critically. Q: Do doctors actually believe that HIV causes AIDS? A: Well, no one is going to take your word for it. The doctors we spoke with said yes, they definitely believe that HIV causes AIDS. Dr. Andrew Wakefield is probably the most well-known. He wrote a very famous paper back in 1998 claiming that this virus caused AIDS in some people (as he termed it) and the Lancet newspaper published his report. The report had to be retracted by the Lancet after extensive criticism from numerous medical authorities, including the chief editor himself. In 1999, the British government appointed him to head a panel of experts looking into the safety of the MMR vaccine. In 2002, the British Medical Journal investigated Dr. Wakefield's work and found that not only did he misrepresent the data he presented, but his study methodology was "fundamentally flawed." The journal further concluded that it was "virtually impossible" to conduct a randomized controlled trial comparing the MMR vaccine to the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine because those vaccines contain both live viruses and dead ones. Q: What are the other benefits of the drug?

A: The most notable benefit is that there appears to be a reduction in nerve cell loss with the use of CSL-2. There was also some improvement in clinical progression. For people who have relapsed after treatment with corticosteroids or other disease modifying therapies, this may help them avoid a relapse and allow for more time for recovery. This kind of therapy can often provide a better outcome than what would otherwise occur if an individual took these drugs on their own. However, because it has not been studied as well as other treatments for MS, we do not know how long they will last in the body.

This study only looked at one drug used to treat MS and many questions remain about its efficacy, safety and long term effects on patients. So far, we believe that our results add to the body of knowledge about the effectiveness of anti-inflammatory medications in treating MS.

Anecdotal reports that a patient who is relapsing remitted MS had a positive biopsy result for antibodies to TNF, which was the same as one of your patients. Is this an example of a drug-induced remission?

MRS: Biopsies are not diagnostic and cannot be used to diagnose MS. They can only be used as indicators in the case of suspected disease. In other words, they do not exclude or confirm disease. The fact that a patient with relapsing remitting MS has received a positive biopsy for IgG anti-TNF does NOT mean that he/she will get better from treatment. If a patient is considered at risk for relapse, then he/she should have another MRI (or another imaging test) performed.

Q: Do you recommend that every patient undergo a double-blind placebo controlled trial of an agent such as SOD1? And if so what kind of results would be expected?

MRS: Most important, we need to know why a patient gets better after being treated with an antibody. To answer these questions, one needs to evaluate an individual's response to treatment. This requires having an accurate biopsy. That means that a patient must first agree to an appropriate biopsy protocol before the doctor or laboratory begins doing it.

This means that there is no way to tell whether the patient has any potential benefit from treatment until she decides to take part in a clinical trial. It also means that there is no control group of healthy individuals. In order for an investigator to determine whether it's worthwhile taking a medication, he must assess both how much improvement a patient receives from his medication versus how well he responds to a placebo or sham treatment. Without good baseline data from a single person, we cannot make reliable conclusions about the efficacy of treatments like this. It's very possible that it could be true that something else happens, such as inflammation and immune system overreaction, that accounts for the patients' improved symptoms. However, because there isn't any evidence to suggest that this happens, I would not recommend that we try this approach.

Q: How do you diagnose multiple sclerosis? A: That's a good question. We usually use several different tests to try and diagnose MS. The most reliable one is called the double-blind study [a study in which neither patient nor physician knows who has been given an experimental drug or placebo]. It allows us to compare patients with those on other treatment regimens without bias.

Q: Why did you decide against trying to treat people with multiple sclerosis by using steroids? A: With our previous research, we looked at whether there might be any beneficial effect of steroid injections for some patients with relapsing MS; however, this was not a study designed to specifically assess whether such therapy could alleviate symptoms. More recently, researchers from the National Multiple Sclerosis Society have done a very rigorous randomized controlled trial examining the potential benefits of a number of treatments (including drugs) to reduce disability in those with relapsing forms of MS. However, due to their small sample size, it is difficult to draw definitive conclusions about possible efficacy based upon these results alone. In addition, because many medications are available over the counter, many patients may already be taking them as well. Therefore, further studies should look into more extensive use of steroid medication in people with relapsing multiple sclerosis. Q: What is a relapse? A: At least 5 months after stopping a long-term steroid regimen, relapse can occur if the person has had a major flare up of illness. This may result from either an allergic reaction caused by the anti-inflammatory properties of steroids or increased sensitivity to a secondary infection. These flares could also represent immune system attack on the bone marrow cells responsible for producing new white blood cells in the body. During these flares, pain is severe and fluctuating. Sometimes the disease progresses rapidly into acute exacerbations of symptoms such as numbness, weakness and fatigue. Other symptoms include fever, facial edema, night sweats, weight loss, eye irritation, and malaise. This acute phase typically lasts 3 weeks and can last 1 month or longer depending on the severity of the episode. For many years, doctors didn't think it would ever happen to someone else after they stopped taking their steroid pills. But now they're seeing more and more people relapsing after stopping these pills. Q: What kind of side effects are associated with steroid withdrawal? A: Steroid withdrawal produces physical changes and possibly serious infections. Some of these side effects involve fever, headaches, skin rash, muscle ac

Questionnaire for disability rating of the major and peripheral nerves and brainstem syndrome (MDDS)\r


The MDDS is a questionnaire that determines whether you have a secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS) or a primary progressive MS (PPMS). The score in this category ranges from 0 to 25. Your score will be assigned based on how your symptoms compare with those of people who do not have the condition. If your scores are above 20 you may qualify for disability benefits under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), if your scores are below 15 you may not be eligible. A score higher than 30 indicates a greater likelihood that you have SPMS. This is also known as a grade 3 or 4 case of SPMS. It can be very challenging to distinguish between an individual with PPS and a person with SPMS, especially since both conditions occur at roughly the same time in life and the two conditions often present together in the form of joint pains (joint pain and spondyloarthritis). The criteria used to determine which group you fall into depend upon the type of symptoms that were reported by patients (e.g., sensory, motor, psychiatric) and their age when they first presented with these symptoms. For more information about the MDDS and how it applies to you please contact the office nearest you directly.

We take blood samples to test for clotting factors and monitor cholesterol levels. You may receive treatment using injections or medication, either alone or in combination with exercise therapy. As indicated by the doctor performing your tests and examination, we believe that there are no significant risks associated with your treatment. However, we cannot assure you against some side effects. These include allergic reactions, gastrointestinal problems, sleep disorders, urinary retention or incontinence, muscle cramps, headaches, increased risk of infection, dizziness and nausea. Other possible side effects include seizures, mood changes, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, loss of appetite, depression, anger, anxiety, insomnia, headache, diarrhea, skin rash, rashes, and impotence. [0116] Q: What is the difference between secondary progressive multiple sclerosis and primary progressive multiple sclerosis? A: Primary progressive MS occurs first, but there are some important differences. [0117] Q: Why do many people have signs of both? A: It's not unusual for a patient with one to develop symptoms later in life as well, which may be related to inflammation or other factors that are independent from the disease process. [0118] Q: When does a person become symptomatic after having been diagnosed with secondary progressive MS? A: The risk of being affected by secondary progressive MS increases dramatically when the disease has progressed to the point where it affects daily activities such as walking. [0119] Q: How can I tell if I've developed signs of secondary progressive MS? A: There will usually be an increase in your body mass index (BMI) at puberty. If you're underweight at this time, you may need more weight loss before your BMI drops back down to normal. Also, the type of physical activity you do will determine whether you progress further into secondary progressive MS. For example, those who spend most of their days sitting, especially if they wear wheelchairs, may experience less rapid progression into secondary progressive MS. You'll need to make decisions about how much exercise and what types of activity you do to keep your condition stable. [0120] Q: Where can I find out more information about secondary progressive MS? A: More information about MS treatment, including symptom management, is available through the National Multiple Sclerosis Society on its website. To learn more, visit www.multiple-sclerosis.org.
answer3:
Multiple sclerosis, a neurodegenerative disease of the central nervous system that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord.

3. What is the difference between primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS) and secondary progressive multiple sclerosis?

a. Primary progressive MS includes all forms of PPMS where there are focal lesions on the brain, spinal cord or optic nerve. b. Secondary progressive MS refers to those cases where there are no focal lesions on the brain, spinal cord or optic nerve but symptoms begin after a certain age and have progressed over time with neurological deterioration. c. In the late stages of PPMS, relapses occur. d. Some individuals develop progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) in their first year of life when they are still very young. e. There is no cure for both types of MS. f. The condition can be controlled by medication and/or surgery, which usually involves removing lesions from the CNS through surgical excision or excision with radiation. g. People who experience partial recovery from PPMS may have more severe symptoms later in life; however, this does not necessarily indicate that they will develop advanced neurodegeneration or death. h. The clinical course of PPMS varies based upon its onset, the location of lesions and the severity of symptoms. i. It typically starts before 20 years of age. j. The majority of patients present at an early stage where there is often no clinically significant progression until about 60 years of age. k. PPMS tends to start with an attack (spasm), which last 2-5 minutes and then subside without lasting damage or disability. l. An individual's risk of developing permanent disability or death increases significantly as his/her risk of other chronic conditions increases. m. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathies do not always cause disease that progresses to multiple sclerosis. n. There is no effective treatment for either type of MS. o. These disorders affect people of any age, including children. p. Treatment options include medications and/or surgeries. q. Patients should be evaluated for potential coexisting medical conditions such as HIV infection or thyroid disease prior to having the procedure done. r. If a patient has had one episode of PPMS, he/she should be evaluated for further episodes within 1 week of surgery. s. Surgery cannot reverse damage caused by previous episodes of PPMS. t. Patients should have follow up visits every 3 months. u. Patients should receive at least 8 weeks of oral medication before surgery

SIDE EFFECTS OF SPINAL CORDIOLIN EXTRACURRILISATION*

Elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) levels have been reported in patients with spinal cord injury, including atrioventricular septal defects and cervical dissection. Elevation of CSF proteins has been associated with peripheral nerve compression (e.g., primary axonal neuropathy), decreased myelination and impaired axon regeneration (secondary stroke). In addition, elevated CSF glutamate may contribute to the pathophysiology of secondary stroke. As such, it is important that the physician consider all possible neurologic complications when performing spinal cord surgery.

Risks related to spinal cord surgery include infection, bleeding, thrombosis, muscle atrophy, respiratory depression, and central nervous system (CNS) dysfunction. Spinal cord surgery can also be associated with increased morbidity and mortality compared to other surgical procedures; however, most cases of spinal cord injury are non-traumatic. However, if there is a suspicion of injury or disease (i.e. suspected or confirmed MS, ALS, etc.), patients should undergo detailed evaluation before initiating spinal cord surgery. For more information about medical concerns related to spinal cord injury, please refer to our fact sheet on Management of Neurosurgical Complications Associated with Spinal Cord Injury.

Treatment of secondary progressive multiple sclerosis and chronic fatigue syndrome by interferon beta-1a therapy

The effect of intramuscular interferon beta-1a therapy on the progression of chronic fatigue syndrome in healthy volunteers has been evaluated in three double-blind, placebo-controlled trials. The results have shown that there is a statistically significant improvement in fatigue severity as measured by the Pittsburgh Fatigue Inventory score at 12 weeks from the start of treatment. In addition, the percentage of patients who responded to the first dose of interferon was similar between the active (10 mg/day) and inactive (placebo) groups at 4 weeks (12%). This suggests that this drug may be useful for treating fatigue associated with chronic fatigue syndrome. Furthermore, when compared with placebo, the incidence of adverse events was significantly lower in the interferon group at baseline (3% versus 10%, respectively). At 24 weeks posttreatment, there were no clinically meaningful differences between the two groups in terms of quality of life or other measures related to disease activity. Further studies are warranted to evaluate whether higher doses of interferon Î²-1a or its main metabolite interferon beta-1b could increase fatigue severity in some patients.

Efficacy of intrathecal administration of interferon beta-1a in the treatment of refractory acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)

In vitro cell culture and mouse model studies indicated that intrathecal injection of interferon beta-1a administered by subcutaneous route could stimulate proliferation of human B-lymphocytes. These effects appeared to be mediated through the inhibition of cyclin D1 expression. Intrathecal immunization against an adjuvant containing the monoclonal anti-CD20 antibody, autologous bone marrow transplantation, or both, increased the numbers of CD19+ cells in vivo. Administration of high levels of interferon alpha-2b (40 Î¼g/kg), the highest dose tested to date, significantly decreased the number of CD19+ cells but did not alter cytokine production. In conclusion, intrathecal delivery of interferon alpha-2b appears to enhance allogeneic B-cell expansion and the function of the immune system.

J: Huntington disease (HD); also known as "adult onset" Huntington's disease (ASD). This disorder has been described with increasing frequency in recent years and may have a genetic component. It causes a gradual deterioration and loss of motor skills over time, often resulting in death after only one to two years of age. Symptoms typically begin between ages 10 and 40 years old and may include facial paralysis (brachydactyly), limb weakness, and dysarthria (a slowing of speech) that continues into adulthood. Although HD affects men and women equally, males are twice as likely to be affected by it. Signs and symptoms can vary significantly from person to person. Most people with HD do not develop any neurological problems at all (see below for details on hereditary forms of Huntington's disease).

K: Epilepsy, including partial epilepsy, generalized seizure disorder, tonic clonic seizures, recurrent partial seizures, focal epilepsy, and temporal lobe seizures. See Neurological Disorders for more information about these types of seizures.

L: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). This rare condition is characterized by progressive muscle atrophy and loss of voluntary muscles. Patients typically experience respiratory failure, weakness on one side of their body, and eventual paralysis. ALS usually begins in late adolescence or early adulthood and does not appear until many years later. Although most patients survive into middle age, around 20 percent die within three years of diagnosis.

M: Multiple system atrophy. This condition occurs when a group of nerve cells degenerate and become smaller and less active

Secondary progressive multiple sclerosis.

Q: Is there a good clinical trial to prove that the natural treatment of MS is curative?

A: Yes, there is a randomized placebo-controlled study (RCT) called Efficacy and Safety of Cytokine Treatment in Multiple Sclerosis, which was approved by the FDA in 2008. There have been only two published studies on the benefits of the anti-inflammatory cytokines in humans (Cytokinetics in Relapsing Multiple Sclerosis: A Randomized Controlled Trial and Cytokines for CNS Toxicity in Patients with Relapsing Remitting Multiple Sclerosis). The results from these two studies were positive and demonstrated that the administration of IL12 and IL8 for 6 months reduced the number of relapses as well as improved the quality of life in patients with relapsing MS. More recently, an RCT has shown that IL6, IL18, and IL10 can decrease brain inflammation associated with Alzheimer's Disease. These findings are exciting and suggest that this type of treatment could be beneficial for other neurodegenerative diseases. Additionally, several small trials have found that the injections of IL20 reduce symptoms and slow disease progression. However, more research is needed before any long term data can be presented.

Q: Why aren't we seeing enough MS patient participation in clinical trials?

A: Because it is very hard to get funding to conduct a major medical trial like this. Currently, there are approximately 3 million people living with MS in the United States alone. Most individuals who do participate in clinical trials receive either a grant or a stipend. While we believe that everyone should have access to care through insurance, many patients cannot afford these costs so they often choose not to participate. As such, if you don't qualify for coverage through your employer, you may still be able to take advantage of private insurance and/or Medicaid to help pay for your care. In addition, in some states, health plans may also cover the cost of therapy but must charge additional amounts depending on what medication and procedure is used. For example, if you use a laser for hair loss, then the laser company will likely bill you at a higher rate than if you simply go to the pharmacy and pick up the medicine yourself. Another option is to enroll in Medicare Part D which provides subsidized drug coverage for those 65 years old or older (see below), or a private plan. Finally, you may still be eligible for free screening tests via www.medicare.gov/

Treatment of primary progressive multiple sclerosis with antiepileptic drugs is difficult, and there are no approved drug regimens for this type of disease. Treatment consists primarily of symptomatic control through analgesics and antihistamines that have minimal side effects.1-3 The main aim of treatment is to increase motor recovery by controlling the inflammation caused by the brain lesion.4 It has been proposed that the addition of methylprednisolone may alleviate symptoms, but further studies are needed to determine whether this approach is effective in patients.2,5

The first clinical case series describing a patient treated with steroids was published almost 20 years ago,6 with the publication of additional cases of steroid use over time.7 In 1989, Cairns8 described a 28 year old woman who had progressed rapidly with progressive focal neurologic signs in both eyes. She received corticosteroid injections weekly throughout the course of her illness. Eventually she developed partial visual loss; however, her vision was partially restored after a course of oral prednisone. Following the publication of the study of Cairns,9 other reports on steroids were reported.10,11 More recently, a series of 16 patients with Sjogren's syndrome 12 and progressive unilateral paralysis who began steroid therapy during their second or third year of illness 12 described how steroids continued to be used until 6 months before death.13 These cases provided more evidence of benefit to steroid therapy than previous reports.14 The lack of consistent findings regarding adverse events and efficacy among these reports suggests that steroid therapy may cause serious complications if not carefully administered.15,16

In 2003, Jang et al17 conducted a prospective multicenter trial comparing the effectiveness of intravenous dexamethasone versus placebo in the treatment of patients with primary progressive multiple sclerosis. They found a significant reduction in disability scores at 3 and 6 months, suggesting that dexamethasone could be safely used in patients who responded to corticosteroids. However, they also noted that the response rate was low at only 31% in this subgroup, making it unlikely that all of the patients would achieve a response. In 2006, we followed up those patients whose corticosteroid treatment was stopped early when symptoms declined.18 Of 17 patients treated with

the etiology and symptoms of fatigue in MS \r

MS is a disorder characterized by chronic pain, loss of strength and mobility, sleep disturbances, and an exacerbation of other health problems. Many MS patients experience fatigue with or without other symptoms that can be debilitating, disabling, and disabling to their quality of life. MS often goes undiagnosed for many years, which leads some patients to have significant disability as well as to suffer from symptoms that impair functioning at work and home. The current study aims to identify potential risk factors and treatments targeting these common fatigue/disability symptoms in MS. The results will help clinicians better understand this complex condition and provide them with information about specific treatment options.

The purpose of this pilot study was to investigate whether there were differences between individuals who report fatigue-free periods during MS course and those who do not in terms of their responses to three self-reported questions related to cognitive functioning (e.g., memory, attention, executive function). Additionally, it was expected that fatigue-free intervals would correlate positively with performance on cognitive tests assessing executive function performance, but that it would be non-significant in relation to measures measuring memory or attention. Lastly, we sought to determine if fatigue was associated with changes in physical activity levels among people reporting fatigue-free periods. In addition, fatigue-free interval status was assessed using a validated questionnaire and multiple measurements of fatigue. These variables are presented in Table 1.

Table 1: Measures used in the study Full size table

Measures

Cognitive Functioning Questionnaire

This questionnaires has been shown to be sensitive to biological age, gender, race/ethnicity, education level, physical ability, alcohol consumption, smoking history, and use of medication. In fact, the most commonly reported symptoms of fatigue in MS are not exactly the same across all studies. Therefore, our primary measure of cognitive function was the Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE), a 16 item test of mental stability and cognition based upon the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory [30]. We asked participants to rate their cognitive abilities using the following items: "In general, how well would you describe yourself?" followed by "How much trouble would you say you get every day?":

I am not very good at remembering things: I need time to organize my thoughts before I can remember things easily;

I rarely forget anything important;

My thinking process isn't always easy or quick;

I tend to think in pictures rather than words

I have a question about the cause of my fatigue. I am starting to get a lot more tired and can't keep up with my daily work duties, how do you think this is caused?


Thanks!

(I don't know if it's just me or not but since this has been asked by so many people here, I thought I'd add my answer)

This might be related to your other symptoms, as many things that are not related to MS can affect your sleep such as headaches, neck pain, back pain, joint stiffness, etc... For example, some people who take an over-the-counter headache medicine report feeling worse during the day on days when they were taking their medication, and then feel better after the drug wears off...this would also apply to anxiety and depression. If these feelings persist, it may be worth having a neurologist look at them for possible underlying problems.

For example, I had a symptom called "exhaustion" that started happening around Christmas time (early January), I was already getting a little tired from being in school most of the year, and when I looked into it further, I found out that I had a very rare genetic condition called Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD). The gene responsible for DMD is present in only one person in every billion (1 in 50,000 people), hence the name Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy.. The main symptom of DMD is muscle weakness (a limp), which is why this disease makes people feel pretty much completely worthless. Also, although there are other muscular disorders like lupus, Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy usually shows up first in its milder form, typically between the ages of 16-18 years old, and it tends to improve before showing up in any severe form at all later on (usually after age 40-50 years old). As far as this illness goes, we really don't understand what causes it - whether it is due to something in the body itself, or because of a problem in the brain causing the muscles to weaken, or both...at least at the moment we aren't able to find anything specifically that will make people with DMD stronger, or live longer. We've done studies trying to see if certain drugs can help control symptoms of DMD, but we haven't managed to show any improvement yet in terms of DMD symptoms.

The bottom line is that there isn't anything specifically that can actually cure D
answer5: the common pathway of fatigue A2B: the pathophysiology of fatigue C1D: the underlying mechanism of fatigue D: management and prevention E: other important issues 1. The common pathway of fatigue (also known as the'motor fatigue syndrome') is characterised by a pattern of muscle weakness, muscle twitching or tingling sensations in the arms or legs that persists for days to weeks or even months after a period of rest, and is more likely to occur with physical activity than without it. This fatigue occurs at a time when muscular strength has returned to normal. Muscle weakness, or stiffness may result from damage to the muscle fibres themselves which are not completely healed. These damaged fibres can no longer conduct electrical impulses normally. Muscles become unable to contract effectively and are less able to produce force. It is this loss of voluntary energy output that makes some people feel tired, and it leads to a feeling of being physically exhausted during the day and even throughout sleep. However, there is much debate over whether such feelings are actually due to fatigue rather than some form of muscle damage. In the absence of any exercise, the muscles will lose their ability to supply energy and so start to deteriorate, leading eventually to fatigue-related symptoms. 2. Motor fatigue is often caused by an imbalance between nerve cells in the spinal cord. It is believed that this can be prevented by restoring the balance and preventing the release of neurotransmitters that cause the problem. The most effective way to restore the balance of these neurotransmitters is through exercising the body's motor system. Exercise helps to reduce levels of lactic acid produced by the contracting muscles and also stimulates the body's immune system. 3. The 'ticking' effect seen following strenuous exercise could well be due to the fact that the nervous system is still working on recovering from the effects of the previous bout of exercise. As it recovers, the nerves grow stronger again, allowing them to communicate quickly and efficiently with the brain. 4. Some theories suggest that the reason for prolonged muscle pain in MS patients is the gradual destruction of myelin around damaged axons, but a recent study into patients who had been treated with antimalarial drugs shows that in all cases the inflammation was not due to breakdown of myelin, but to the failure of the drug molecules to cross the blood-brain barrier properly. 5. If you suspect your health problems might have a physical source (such as a weakened central nervous system), ask your doctor to check your muscles before or immediately after exercise - they may
answer6:
fatigue; nB: an inability to work efficiently

Fibromyalgia

Flexibility and mobility are compromised by the muscle pain associated with fibromyalgia. In MS, there is a loss of flexibility due to the inflammation of the central nervous system, which is one reason that the symptoms often become more severe over time (e.g., after an illness or injury). Many studies suggest that the ability of individuals with fibromyalgia to walk, climb stairs, swim, swing, etc., may be reduced. The most common cause of the loss of range of motion is caused by the tightness in muscles that support the spine or neck, such as those surrounding the eyes and jaw muscles. Flexible joints can also become strained through improper posture during activities, for example, while standing, sitting, or lying down.

The muscles responsible for the movement of the head are also affected by MS, and many individuals experience headaches when they try to focus on their vision and/or move around too much. An imbalance between the brain and the spinal cord makes it difficult for people with MS to perform basic tasks such as reading, writing, or using tools. There have been reports suggesting that certain medications used to treat MS may actually worsen the physical effects of this disease, including increased pressure behind the eye, changes in vision, problems moving around, weight gain, decreased mood stability, anxiety attacks, depression, sleep disturbances, irritability, and sleepwalking.[6]

For the purpose of this article, we will consider some possible mechanisms that could contribute to the decrease in flexibility and mobility in fibromyalgia:

Damage to the nerves in the brain stem

Increased stress on the nerves in the back

Tightness of muscles around the mouth and face (i.e., temporomandibular joint dysfunction)

Muscle spasm or excessive tension

Decreased muscle tone and size

Migraines

Gastrointestinal disorders

Headaches

Nerve damage from repeated trauma (such as surgery) or drugs (eg, steroids)

Cognitive impairment

Chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS)

Diagnosis

Although fibromyalgia has been considered since 1841, diagnosis has remained elusive until very recently.

There are two main types of fibromyalgia: primary and secondary. Primary fibromyalgia occurs only if it affects your entire body â€” i.e., you don't have any other medical conditions. Secondary fib

Cognitive impairment.

Dementia, cognitive, and/or emotional problems (including depression) that are not improved by treatment with a second drug or by other treatments have been reported as the primary reason for discontinuation of treatment. In addition to psychological symptoms, there may be physical manifestations of dementia such as weakness, poor balance, blurred vision, and impaired coordination, which may cause an individual's ability to perform tasks to decline. The presence of these signs should raise concern for an underlying medical condition, but they do not necessarily indicate disease progression. Some patients develop milder forms of dementia with symptoms similar to those seen in Parkinson's Disease.

Symptoms and signs of dementia include difficulty remembering things; confusion about how events unfolded earlier in life; and a loss of short-term memory. These changes can also occur without any obvious cause. In some cases, it is possible to prevent the onset of dementia by controlling the patient's activities. However, others become progressively worse over time.

Treatment with the first drug has no effect on the severity of these changes in the long term. This suggests that drugs that treat Alzheimer's Disease should target different mechanisms than those used to treat other diseases. Also, it appears that the longer a person continues to take a drug, the more severe their cognitive deficits become.

query: Q: Does multiple sclerosis relate to sleeping problems and forgetfulness in older people?\nA:
answer1:
It is possible that there are links between these two conditions. \r

However, further research into this subject would be required before a definitive answer could be given. \r

The exact mechanisms of how the immune system affects sleep at the cellular level or the way it affects our physiology as individuals need more investigation to prove whether MS and other neurological disorders have similar underlying factors which affect the way we sleep. \r

\r

"There is growing evidence that several diseases can cause changes in the amount of time spent asleep," said Dr Mascola from Newcastle University's Institute for Sleep Research. "This may explain why some patients with insomnia seem to suffer more from sleep problems than others." \r

According to the National Health Service (NHS), approximately one third of adults aged 65-74 will experience some type of daytime sleepiness, including trouble falling asleep, staying asleep or getting back to sleep. \r

If you're concerned about your ability to fall asleep tonight, try these tips: \r

Get some shut eye â€“ if you feel sleepy and unable to get off to sleep, take a short nap first thing in the morning. This can help improve your chances of falling asleep again. Get up early â€“ don't stay out too late doing something you enjoy, like watching TV or having a drink. Avoid caffeine â€“ it makes you tired and less likely to sleep well. Don't eat too much sugar, alcohol or tobacco â€“ they'll make you sleepy too. Drink plenty of water â€“ you should have a glass of warm milk to drink every four hours during the day. Exercise regularly â€“ walking, swimming, cycling and aerobics can all keep you awake if you want to get up earlier. Take an afternoon nap â€“ you'll still feel tired but you won't be so groggy when you wake up. You might find yourself waking up feeling refreshed. \r

Dr David Anderson, of the Royal College of Psychiatrists' health advisory committee, says: "While sleep disorders such as insomnia are common, it is not clear how many cases are actually caused by lack of sleep and how often they are preventable. This is particularly important for elderly people because poor quality sleep affects their mental and physical wellbeing." \r
answer2:
Yes, MS is a disorder that causes the brain to lose its ability to process information properly. As a result, it often does not send out signals to tell your body when you are tired or needs rest (this can lead to an extended period of sleepiness). The most common symptom for people with MS is trouble falling asleep. Other symptoms include headaches, fatigue, pain on one side of the head, and trouble focusing. \r


Q: How do I know if my MS affects my ability to get up at night?\nA: A study conducted by the National Sleep Foundation found that more than half of adults who have MS also suffer from insomnia. People with MS may be unable to wake up at the same time each day because they cannot function as well during the daytime. This may be exacerbated in people who also experience chronic pain due to nerve damage. It's important to take a regular nighttime pill to help manage this problem. While taking naps will make you feel better throughout the day, it won't necessarily fix the underlying cause of your insomnia. \r


Q: What are some other factors that increase risk of developing MS?\nA: Another reason why people develop MS is an abnormal immune system response. An abnormal immune response increases inflammation and damages nerve cells causing them to die. In addition, certain viruses or bacteria called coxsackievirus B1 and B2 may trigger autoimmune reactions to build up in the nervous system leading to MS. One study shows that a type of coxsackievirus called JC virus is associated with an increased risk of developing MS. Other studies show that exposure to air pollution may contribute to MS development, but further research is needed to determine whether air pollution itself could play a role in the disease. Finally, there is increasing evidence that people with MS tend to eat unhealthy diets, such as fatty meat and high-sugar drinks, which might reduce the levels of vitamin D in their blood. Some experts believe diet may be just as important as medications in helping control the disease.


Q: Does eating gluten affect the course of MS?\nA: Gluten is a protein found in wheat, rye, barley, and oats. Studies show that people who have celiac disease, a disorder caused by an intolerance to gluten, are twice as likely to develop MS compared to people who don't have celiac disease. However, another study showed no link between celiac disease and MS. Also, some doctors believe that gluten sensitivity or intestinal infections (such as UTIs
answer3:
Yes. Multiple Sclerosis is a condition that causes weakness of the muscles. It also affects your brain, which can lead to memory loss.

Q: I have been having difficulty concentrating recently. What should I do?\nA: Concentrate on remembering one simple word or phrase at a time while taking regular breaks for breathing exercises (like counting backwards). This will help you remember what you are trying to learn. If this fails then try repeating it out loud (using your voice) several times and see if that helps. Your ability to concentrate and recall important information may improve with practice. See How to Get Better At Concentrating for more tips.


Forgetfulness

Q: Am I forgetting things, and how often does it happen?\nA: In most cases it happens after a few minutes, but it can take up to half an hour for symptoms to appear. The sooner you get to know your own body, the better able you'll be to manage it. Symptoms include: fatigue, headaches, confusion, slurred speech, trouble thinking clearly, nausea, dizziness, numbness, tingling, pain and itching. For some people there are physical effects as well such as muscle tension and joint pains.

Q: Is it normal for my doctor to prescribe medication to me before seeing another specialist?\nA: Yes. Many doctors who work in primary care clinics or hospitals use medications to treat conditions like MS. However, it's not unusual for other specialists to have similar prescriptions. Sometimes these prescriptions aren't medically necessary. Talk to your doctor about your treatment options and ask if he has any recommendations.

Q: Why isn't my doctor seeing me right away when I start showing signs of MS?\nA: A good first visit is made between a couple of weeks and six months after diagnosis. This is because many patients continue to experience symptoms long after they're diagnosed. However, sometimes symptoms don't occur until years later.

Q: I have had no improvement in my MS symptoms since starting medication. I feel helpless. How can I cope with the pain of being unable to walk properly?\nA: You must understand that you cannot control everything about your symptoms. Some days you might find them manageable, others not so much. There are no quick fixes; you have to accept that things won't change overnight. Try to think positive. Remind yourself of what makes you happy and try to make the best of each day. It can be hard at times and
answer4:
Yes. It is widely accepted that the number of MS patients with sleep disorders increases as we age, due to increased prevalence of sleep disorders in older individuals. Sleep apnea, restless legs syndrome (RLS), chronic fatigue syndrome, narcolepsy, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) are all associated with MS. The symptoms of these diseases include daytime hyperarousal, daytime insomnia, frequent snoring and other sleep-related complaints.

Q: What causes MS or any autoimmune disease?

It has been proposed that MS may be caused by an immune response against nerve cells in the central nervous system (CNS). This hypothesis arose from studies showing a correlation between lesions on immunological assays for T cells and MS lesions at autopsy. However, there have also been recent reports suggesting that other factors contribute to the development of MS, including autoimmune diseases such as lupus erythematosus (lymphocytic myelitis), rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). These studies suggest that the pathogenesis of MS may involve more than one mechanism; however, it seems likely that both direct and indirect effects of cytokines play a role. Evidence suggests that the mechanisms involved may differ among different types of autoimmune diseases, but they are almost certainly not identical. For example, some studies show that IL10-producing T lymphocytes are responsible for causing SLE, while others do not. In addition, both lupus erythematosus and RA produce high levels of interferons (IFNs), which can stimulate production of proinflammatory cytokines. Several reports indicate that IFN-Î³ may contribute significantly to the pathogenesis of MS, although their contribution to disease severity remains unclear. Finally, evidence indicates that many autoimmune diseases are characterized by changes in the metabolism of certain hormones, and MS is no exception. Thus, these conditions appear to act through similar pathways in promoting the inflammatory cascade leading to MS.

The majority of studies assessing the relationship between autoimmunity and MS focus on the pathophysiology of specific autoantibodies; however, there appears to be little consensus about whether and how these autoantibodies interact with MS pathology. A recent review concluded that in light of emerging data, autoantibody studies were insufficient to make definite conclusions about the etiology of MS.

Autoimmune diseases also affect brain function. Multiple sclerosis is commonly thought to result in damage to the white matter
answer5:
Sleep disturbance has been reported as a common symptom of MS, both in the early stages (pre-MS) and in more advanced disease. Although sleep disturbances may be caused by many factors including fatigue, pain, depression or other mental health disorders, there is also evidence that they are related to systemic inflammation.\r


Q: Do you have any concerns about how your research will impact on our understanding of the causes of MS? If so what might these impact on our understanding of MS?\nA: We believe we have found a possible mechanism for how MS develops and we plan to examine this further with larger scale studies. However, we do not expect our findings to alter current treatment guidelines and treatments. For example, given that current therapies target only symptoms, it does not appear likely that our results would change the way we treat MS patients or contribute towards developing new ways to diagnose MS, because currently only one biomarker is used and MS is diagnosed through clinical examination using MRI scans. Another reason that we don't anticipate changing existing drug development programmes is that although drugs have shown some efficacy in treating certain aspects of MS, they have no effect on how MS progresses.\r

Dr. Ebeling is an internationally recognized expert on MS and its associated diseases, including autoimmune neuroinflammatory disease (e.g., demyelinating polyneuropathy), spinal cord injury, metabolic syndrome, stroke, and systemic lupus erythematosus. In addition to her work as a researcher in immunology, she also serves as Chief Medical Officer for the National Multiple Sclerosis Society (NMSS) and Board Member of several other organizations focused on research related to MS.
